author: {'steamid': '76561198126725618', 'num_games_owned': 363, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 1590, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 158, 'playtime_at_review': 1590, 'last_played': 1678354071}
review:
I went into this game with an open mind knowing that this was almost released 21 years ago. Unlike 90%+ of the reviews here who are absolutely blinded by nostalgia, this game has aged pretty poorly. Before thinking that my opinion is wrong and that I didn't play enough, I was on the third last mission called Espresso-2-go where I gave up. I had to drive around trying to find coffee stalls on a map that didn't help me at all, nor gave me their location unless I got really close to them. Below I'll give a list of positive and negatives about this game.

[h1]Positives:[/h1]
[h1]Graphics[/h1]
For a 2002 game, I was expecting the graphics to not be that great, but upon loading the game I was pleasantly surprised with how good it looked. Sure, things like textures were blurry at times and appeared stretched, but they didn't look that bad. Character models looked decent, and had a nice art style.

[h1]Voice acting[/h1]
For a decent amount of games in the early to mid 2000's, voice acting was usually pretty cheesy, or just wasn't that good. GTA 3's voice acting is pretty decent for it's time. The use of emotion when speaking can be heard, and I really like that.

[h1]Use of humour[/h1]
Whilst playing, you can already hear and see Rockstar's funny use of humour. Of course it's not as overboard as it is today, but it still is funny. For example the radio station called Chatterbox, where people call in and talk about funny and random topics. Not only that, but I remember in one mission called escort service where you have to escort a van with a logo of a company called Gruppe sechs. It honestly made me laugh.

...And that's where all the positives for this game end.

[h1]Neutral:[/h1]
[h1]Story[/h1]
I don't necessarily think the story was bad, I just couldn't really get into it. Not only that, but I didn't really connect with barely any of the characters. They were forgettable.

[h1]Side missions[/h1]
I didn't do any of the side missions, so that's why I'm putting it here.

[h1]Negatives:[/h1]
[h1]Very average PC port[/h1]
Now where do I start with this? The game doesn't even run at 60fps, it runs at 30 by default. Turning off the in-game frame limiter makes the game run above 30fps, but causes problems like timing issues and general bugs and physics problems. It can also cause problems when in the menu, as you can't even see any of the buttons. Not only that, but weapons fire faster, some audio like NPC's talking cuts off mid-sentence, the firetruck can't fire water, it's effects are broken and this makes the side missions not possible to play. In order to fix this you have to download a mod. This caps the fps to 60 which allows the game to be played normally, however, the car physics are a bit messed up and NPC voices still get cut off. Not only that, but connecting a controller doesn't show it's controls and only shows keyboard controls. You need another mod to also fix this.

[h1]Very poor gameplay design[/h1]
I have no clue what Rockstar were thinking when they did this, but there is no restart checkpoint or mission screen if you fail a mission. For example, if I was to start a mission and go to the other side of the city and fail, I'd have to drive all the way back to the mission marker and do it all over again. This seriously tested my patience at times. Not only that, but if you died anytime while free roaming or in a mission you'd get revived at a hospital. Doesn't sound bad right? Wrong. All your weapons and ammunition are now gone, and you have to go back and buy them all over again. What's that? You want to know where the ammo store is because we took your guns from you? Too bad. We're not going to put it on the map at all, you have to drive around aimlessly hoping to find it.

[h1]No map screen[/h1]
This one is pretty common if not standard in all open-world games nowadays, so it's extremely frustrating knowing this game doesn't have it. I failed miserably trying to remember where things were, so only giving me a small map at the bottom left of the screen doesn't really help me.

[h1]No save button in the menu[/h1]
What was Rockstar thinking with this? Not being able to save in the menu itself and only at your safe house is such a dumb decision. Having the ability to save right outside where a mission started would save me so much time, rather than having to drive all the way to a safe house to save.

[h1]Summary:[/h1]
Overall, I know that this game was released almost 21 years ago, but I just couldn't get into this game. I really tried to like it and see the positives, but the negatives it had outweighed them. I can clearly see that this game was extremely visionary, advanced and well above its competition for it's time. It really gives evidence as to why people say that Rockstar helped create the open-world genre as it's 100% true. While this game was well ahead of its time, it hasn't aged very well at all. From things such as a no restart checkpoint or mission menu to a very poor PC port, the experience I had at the start of the game to the end went from one of positivity to one of anger and frustration.

I'd honestly recommend you just watch a play through on YouTube rather than playing this. Or wait for a discount on the remastered series. I really hope that Vice City and San Andreas are better. Overall, I'd give this game a 3/10.

author: {'steamid': '76561197970458445', 'num_games_owned': 258, 'num_reviews': 297, 'playtime_forever': 1693, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 318, 'playtime_at_review': 1693, 'last_played': 1677373274}
review:
Playing a lot of this game when I was 16 probably didn't help when I failed my driver's test for the first time, but it was worth it t hen and it's worth it now. While it's "3D universe" successors, Vice City and San Andreas, are better games, this one holds a place in my depraved heart for its gritty liberty city setting and the excellent dialogue of Claude, the protagonist. 

This discontinued Steam version didn't work for me until I used [url=https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=1425412812]this handy guide.[/url] After one minute of following that guide, no problems on my Windows 10 machine!

And the game was a blast, still some frustrating missions (I can't stand the one where you have to[spoiler]escort the securicar and the Cartel hounds you through the tunnel[/spoiler] and it lacks some nice quality of life upgrades, the better radio stations and satisfying endgame from Vice City and San Andreas (at the end of GTA III, you don't[spoiler]"run this town" like the other games, rather almost all the gangs want to kill you[/spoiler], but it's just a lot of good honest fun.

Also I spent the first several hours driving ambulances and taxis, which suggests that maybe I was playing the right game...

author: {'steamid': '76561198038293797', 'num_games_owned': 613, 'num_reviews': 124, 'playtime_forever': 1471, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1471, 'last_played': 1543073053}
review:
Grand Theft Auto III's gameplay is centered around exploring Liberty City and completing a series of missions that advance the game's story. The game features an open-world environment that allows the player to roam freely, interact with non-player characters, steal cars, and engage in various criminal activities. The game's missions range from simple tasks like delivering packages to complex heists involving multiple objectives and locations. The game's combat system is a mix of hand-to-hand combat, gunfights, and vehicular combat, which adds to the game's depth and variety.
At the time of its release, Grand Theft Auto III's graphics were considered groundbreaking. The game features a fully realised 3D environment with detailed character models, realistic physics, and dynamic lighting. Although the game's graphics may appear dated by today's standards, they were a significant achievement for their time and helped establish the game's immersive world.
The game's soundtrack features a wide variety of music genres, including rock, rap, and pop. The game also features voice acting from a talented cast of actors, including Michael Madsen, Frank Vincent, and Robert Loggia. The sound effects in the game are realistic and add to the game's immersion.
he game's story is one of its strongest aspects. The narrative is engaging, and the characters are well developed, with their unique personalities and motivations. The game's story is a mix of drama and comedy, which keeps the player engaged throughout the game.

Overall, Grand Theft Auto III is a classic game that has stood the test of time. The game's innovative gameplay, immersive narrative, and attention to detail make it a must-play for any open-world gaming fan. Despite its age, the game is still enjoyable and relevant today, and its influence can be seen in many modern games. If you haven't played Grand Theft Auto III yet, it's worth giving it a try

author: {'steamid': '76561198049459983', 'num_games_owned': 375, 'num_reviews': 30, 'playtime_forever': 650, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 650, 'last_played': 1479430203}
review:
Grand Theft Auto 3, also known as GTA 3, is an absolute classic in the world of video games. This game revolutionized the open-world genre and set the bar for future games in the series. If you're a fan of action, adventure, or sandbox-style games, then GTA 3 is a must-play.

One of the standout features of GTA 3 is its vast and immersive open-world. The game's city of Liberty City is vast and detailed, and players can explore every corner of it, from the bustling downtown area to the quiet suburbs. The game's graphics are also top-notch, with detailed character models and atmospheric environments that bring the world to life.

Another great aspect of GTA 3 is its entertaining and over-the-top gameplay. The game's missions are a blast to play, and they range from fast-paced car chases to explosive shootouts. And with its wide variety of weapons and vehicles, players can tailor their playstyle to suit their preferences and take on the city in their own unique way.

In addition to its great gameplay, GTA 3 also features a fantastic soundtrack. The game's radio stations feature a wide range of music styles, from rock to hip hop to classical, and they provide a great backdrop for the player's adventures. And the game's voice acting is top-notch, bringing the characters and world to life.

Finally, the game's freedom and replayability are another highlight. Players can explore the city, complete missions, and cause mayhem however they see fit. And with multiple endings and hidden secrets, the game offers endless replayability, making it a great option for players who want to experience everything the game has to offer.

In conclusion, Grand Theft Auto 3 is an absolute classic in the world of video games. With its vast and immersive open-world, entertaining gameplay, great soundtrack, and freedom, GTA 3 is a must-play for fans of action, adventure, and sandbox-style games. So if you're looking for an awesome gaming experience, be sure to check out Grand Theft Auto 3!

author: {'steamid': '76561198093530373', 'num_games_owned': 203, 'num_reviews': 26, 'playtime_forever': 185, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 185, 'last_played': 1653783880}
review:
I'm 19 years old, not really old enough to grow up on a game this old, but i did grow up on vice city, gta4 and san andreas on my brother's PS2/PS3 (got my own consoles later when my mom got her bread up)

I knew about gta 3, never really touched it, even having it sitting in my steam for years, but this year i wanted to beat every gta game, holy fucking shit is this game incredible, this game's quality coming from a 2001 title is absolutely insane. This game could come out TODAY and it will still be way better than 95% of the entire market.

I cant even describe the amount of polish and amount of gameplay value this game has for it's time, everything is just.. wow.

author: {'steamid': '76561198014925133', 'num_games_owned': 322, 'num_reviews': 20, 'playtime_forever': 2722, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2722, 'last_played': 1625678411}
review:
This is a really hard recommend for me because this game's sequels improve on every single aspect of this game. They're just this game but better in 100 different ways. That being said, this is one of the most significant video games ever released. This baby changed everything. GTA, Saint's Row, Just Cause, Red Dead, and many many more... You can kiss all those series goodbye if this game was never released. If you're into experiencing watershed moments in gaming for yourself, I'd urge you to play this just based on that alone. That being said, the game is good. It's old, but you can find some patches to pick things up a bit. The story is mid but at least we have a colorful cast of characters. The music is decent, nothing that stuck out to me. It just felt like such an incomplete game because I was accustomed to playing its sequels. But that's not this game's fault, and it's a certified classic, so try it. Just don't expect the same polish you'd get from a GTA 5.

Also, learn how to fucking swim, Claude, you piece of fucking shit!

author: {'steamid': '76561198069030313', 'num_games_owned': 729, 'num_reviews': 110, 'playtime_forever': 1641, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1641, 'last_played': 1665880416}
review:
GTA3 was a cutting edge game back in the day; it released the same year as Metal Gear Solid 2, Halo CE, and Smash Bros. Melee. But unfortunately the original PC port is now lost to time.

Rockstar famously does not give a single f**k about their older titles and was content to remove all three classic 3D GTA games from sale in order to sell their "DE" (Defective Edition) versions of the games. Of all the choices to make they decided to go with the worst one. So many titles like GTA, GTA2, GTA: London, Liberty City Stories, etc. have either never been available on Steam, or were removed a long time ago and reduced to hard-to-run abandonware downloads at best.

Instead of bringing a new generation's attention to updated versions of games that actually *needed* it, Rockstar butchered some of the most beloved games in their franchise.

author: {'steamid': '76561197979985577', 'num_games_owned': 401, 'num_reviews': 179, 'playtime_forever': 25, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 25, 'last_played': 86400}
review:
Grand Theft Auto III


"Notice: Notice: Grand Theft Auto III is no longer available on the Steam store."

𝘙𝘰𝘤𝘬𝘴𝘵𝘢𝘳 𝘥𝘦𝘭𝘪𝘴𝘵𝘪𝘯𝘨 𝘵𝘩𝘪𝘴 𝘨𝘢𝘮𝘦, 𝘎𝘛𝘈 𝘝𝘪𝘤𝘦 𝘊𝘪𝘵𝘺 𝘢𝘯𝘥 𝘚𝘢𝘯 𝘈𝘯𝘥𝘳𝘦𝘢𝘴 𝘧𝘳𝘰𝘮 𝘚𝘵𝘦𝘢𝘮 for a cash grab so you buy the "𝘋𝘦𝘧𝘪𝘯𝘪𝘵𝘷𝘦 𝘌𝘥𝘪𝘵𝘪𝘰𝘯" directly from rockstar.

I do not understand why they do not sell  "𝘋𝘦𝘧𝘪𝘯𝘪𝘵𝘷𝘦 𝘌𝘥𝘪𝘵𝘪𝘰𝘯" on steam and give the other 3 away for free if you buy it. Even if they charged for all 6 games but they do not sell any of them on steam. If you going to do a cash grab you would make more money selling all 6 games on steam so I do not get the logic there.

There is some people who only play steam who will never try the old or new version now.

You can still buy the key of this original game on Eneba for under $3 as of today for the steam version so that is cool. Some games delisted from steam it is almost impossible to find a key to buy them.

I have never played the DE to give my opinion on that but if I was you I would either buy the key of the 3 old versions or buy the DA on whatever platform you want to play it even if it means buy from rockstar directly for pc.


--------------------------


As for the actual review of this game it is like playing the original COD.


GTA 1 and 2 were never as good as 3.

If you a GTA fan you should try either this old version or the new one at least once. The DE has much better graphics but the atmosphere is much more happy and in this old version it is more gloomy. 

"GTA III was meant to be a game that's very grey-ish, gritty and gloomy. It is not supposed to be another San Andreas, yet that is just what Grove Street Games gave us."

Rockstar did not even make the DE themselves.

The old game is good but check out a video of the gameplay of this version and DE but you should pick at least one or both.

This old game was really popular on PS2 in 2001/2002/2003.

author: {'steamid': '76561198347895625', 'num_games_owned': 52, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 26, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 1, 'playtime_at_review': 25, 'last_played': 1677462580}
review: I am a 50 year old father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my son, who is now 14. My son recently started gta 3 and in less than a week, he had already played for over 20 hours. This was terrible for me, as it was already hard enough for me to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching videos on Tiktok. So i decided to make a Steam account and download this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, looked at the menu, but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought my son and I closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

author: {'steamid': '76561198847902512', 'num_games_owned': 70, 'num_reviews': 86, 'playtime_forever': 810, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 810, 'last_played': 1638822269}
review:
Grand Theft Auto III. A true classic. Released in 2001, this game is one of the best ever made, alongside the other 3D Universe GTA titles.

Gameplay is fun, but dated. Gunplay feels awkward, and vehicles control slightly strange at times, but it is still a great experience.

Graphics are good for early-2000s standards. Its an old game, don't expect a beautiful game.

Overall, it's a fun game that runs perfectly on both old and new hardware, and it is a quintessential piece of nostalgia for any gamer.

author: {'steamid': '76561198120469552', 'num_games_owned': 1271, 'num_reviews': 135, 'playtime_forever': 860, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 860, 'last_played': 1661682394}
review:
[h1]▶️Introduction[/h1]
Grand Theft Auto III, or as most of us call it, GTA3, is an open-world, third-person crime game taking place in the early 2000s. All of the events happen in Liberty City. Liberty City which is based upon cities known for gang activity and crime, like Detroit and Philadelphia. Lastly, I should mention that GTA3 is the first mainstream, 3D open-world game, which is still a formula of success.

[h1]🎮Gameplay[/h1]
As mentioned above, GTA3 is the grandfather of modern games. We see more and more games opt in for an open-world setting because of the success that the Grand Theft Auto series had. Having never played this GTA installment, I decided to play through it more than twenty years after release and see how it holds up.

Let's start with the open-world mechanics, as they were the highlight of this game. Liberty City still feels like a dynamic place. People walk around in a funny and animatronic manner, with vehicles going around city streets, planes gliding through the sky and boats dashing through the waves. The result of that randomness gives the sensation and atmosphere of a life-like city with how things are going. Of course, being the protagonist will also get you the chance to take part in various activities and missions. You discover more areas of the map by progressing throughout the story. Keep in mind that with every new part of the city, you will be able to complete side missions and mini-games.Talking about missions, most of them are well crafted. Their design is  simple, go to point A, steal or kill your target and return to base. That may sound easy, but in practice, it can get a lot more entertaining and challenging! The variety of the missions also helps in keeping you engaged. Every mission has a different theme or agenda behind it, sometimes you drive in a win or lose race, and other times you start a gang war with the Chinese. That is a very strong aspect of this game.

https://youtu.be/CJeIqOmgMRk

Being a fantastic sandbox it allows you to waste time on this game. Fighting against the police with your comically large inventory is a classic gaming moment. Stealing a nice sports car and exploring Liberty City is something everyone should do.

The shooting mechanics have aged badly, which isn't a surprise. Aiming might feel rusty and unresponsive, especially with a scoped weapon. Hit reg is also abysmal, although it is excusable due to the age.

[h1]🎭Story[/h1]
[h2]This review contains no spoilers.[/h2]
Something to be expected is that the story has a lot to do with crimes, backstabbing and revenge. You being a silent protagonist makes the entire story hit or miss. You never see Claude react to much at all. He feels programmed and stoic. It might seem like a terrible aspect, but at the same time, it makes everything seem deeper story-wise. I found myself constantly wondering about Claude's motives because of his mysterious and quiet persona. The other characters presented throughout the story are memorable and also impactful. The entire plot gave me the idea that there is always a risk, someone you trust will betray you for their own personal gain. On your journey to redemption you do the same to others that helped you and use them as a tool. I am avoiding spoilers but these are the motives of the story to my understanding.


I spent 15 hours with the game, which is a decent time. Considering how engaging the events are, I would easily consider the story as another strength of this title.

[h1]🌇Graphics / Audio[/h1]
[i]Grand Theft Auto III uses the RenderWare game engine.[/i]

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2626638038

[*] [b]Graphics[/b]
In some way, Rockstar did revolutionize games graphically as well, although it also did fail in some other areas. Building and overall environmental design are beautiful to this day. You can't stroll through Liberty City and say that this game looks ugly. The issue in this game starts when you're looking at details. The characters do look geometrical even for their time. Textures seem as if someone painted with crayons on them.  Animations are also somewhat of a weak point.

[*] [b]Audio / Soundtrack[/b]
Arguably the best part of this game, despite having a silent protagonist; the voice actors were fantastic. Background sounds and noises were also a quality addition. The soundtrack is what makes this experience unforgettable, perfectly capturing the era of this game and also bombarding me with nostalgia… ah the 2000s… good times! Also, the entire presentation of the main menu is iconic. The screen is black, and you can hear the relaxing piano theme playing in the background as the menu slowly shows up. It makes you forget about your disappointing life and that you’re living from paycheck to paycheck…anyway, the soundtrack by itself is worth the money.[/list]

[h1]⚙️Performance[/h1]                    
[b]In Game[/b]
[*]AMD Ryzen 7 3700X, 32GB Ram, Nvidia RTX 2070S: The game ran flawlessly with max Settings and over 144 fps.

[*]In detail
                     Average framerate: 437.7 fps
                     Minimum framerate: 230.0 fps 
                     Maximum framerate: 612.9 fps

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2603476435

[*] [b]Bugs / Glitches / Crashes[/b]
Being such an old title, we have to expect technical difficulties. To bypass most of the issues I would suggest enlightening yourself with this guide: [url=https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=1744154318]Click here![/url].
In 15 hours of beefing with Chinatown people I experienced some minor glitches and bugs. Luckily for me, I had no crashes, although that could be the case because I installed most of the fixes. Trying to run the game without any patch might be frustrating as I couldn’t even start the game without crashing.
[/list]
[h1]⚖️Conclusion[/h1]
Grand Theft Auto III truly is a legend. It still performs 20 years later and was able to give me some good hours of entertainment. The game isn’t available anymore on the Steam store page, but you can find Steam keys using 3rd Party sites for the price of a coffee. 

[h1]📉Overall rating: Excellent[/h1]
[url=https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2492944911]The rating system I use.[/url]

author: {'steamid': '76561199089458962', 'num_games_owned': 9, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 391, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 350, 'last_played': 1658277441}
review: The first 3D game in the series! It gets a lot of slack compared to the newer games for being out dated, wack, and hard to play at times, but this game continues to live rent free in my heart. It has had such an impact on video games now-a-days and gives you a more dark look on Liberty City. It has dark colors, good characters, and the soundtrack is wonderful. I wouldn't be surprised if Rock Star took inspiration to make GTA IV the way it is because of the darker colors used for III, If you enjoy the GTA series you will enjoy this endless classic. It has it's flaws and such, but don't miss out on III.

author: {'steamid': '76561198329926861', 'num_games_owned': 90, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 2331, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2331, 'last_played': 1612108155}
review:
[h1] Grand Theft Auto III Review[/h1]
[b]A short description[/b]
Grand Theft Auto III is a 3D open world game developed by DMA Design (Now known as Rockstart North) that is set in the fictional Liberty City (based on NY). The story follows Claude Speed's seek for revenge after a robbery gone wrong.
As many know, this game is legendary, and it's gameplay has been documented and reviewed by thousands. In this review, I will focus on other aspects that many haven't really touched.

[b]Behind the soundtrack[/b]
This game's soundtrack is brilliant to say the least. With the musical background the Sam and Dan Houser, Rockstar managed to create a legendary sountrack. There is a total of 9 radio stations, 1 of which is a talk radio hosted by Lazlow Jones. Rockstar managed to mock the radio stations of the time that the game was released. The songs were written entirely in Rockstar's studios. They also used real DJs to portray those on the radio.

[b]The game before 9/11[/b]
The 9/11 attacks changed a few different aspects of the game. For example, one striking change was the original cover art(which was still used for the European version) which according to Rockstar themselves was "too raw". The cover used in US laid the foundation of what would become a legendary art style that would be used for the future GTAs. Another example is the police cars; initially their colour scheme was that of the NYPD cars, but Rockstar changed them to generic black-and-white design. One of the most beloved cut was the character Darkel which was a character that wanted to bring down the city's economy. Darkel was removed because his missions were a bit too violent.

[b]The Definitive Edition[/b]
GTA III has a few ports, including a mobile port developed entirely by War Drum Studios (now known as Grove Street Games) and the Definitive Edition (which isn't great and is based on the mobile ports). The latter is the reason why the original version was removed from the Steam store. The Definitive Edition fails to offer a good experience, as it is riddled with countless bugs, features that don't work properly and doesn't retain the original art style of the game. The dark and grim aspect of Liberty City is gone. The character's models look like cartoons. Personally, I dispise the definitive edition.

[b]re3[/b]
Thanks to the community, the original version was reverse-engineered by a team of six fans. The project is called re3, and they released the source code and executable not only for Windows, but for GNU/Linux too. With the help of their amazing work, now Linux players can play this amazing masterpiece natively and with a lot of modern touches.

[b]Conclusion[/b]
It is, and forever will be, one of greatest video games of all time. Shame on Take Two for making Rockstar remove the original and perfectly functional version in favor of a version that offers a bad and inconsistent experience. I recommend the original version, or even better, use re3. Don't support Take Two's mistake.

review:
[i]"Yesterday is gone forever, tomorrow will never be here, so live for today"[/i]

Equally as legendary as [i]Vice City[/i] because of its unique, gritty atmosphere and memorable songs, but far more difficult because of a complex map combined with tougher controls and relentless timed missions. Still, it remains one of Rockstar's masterpieces that still holds up very well thanks to the amount of details and care that went into crafting this game. Definitely a must-play, even after all these years.

author: {'steamid': '76561198066129673', 'num_games_owned': 588, 'num_reviews': 245, 'playtime_forever': 862, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 862, 'last_played': 1408631884}
review:
Vintage chocolate chip cookies

Ingredients
150g salted butter, softened
80g light brown muscovado sugar
80g granulated sugar
2 tsp vanilla extract
1 large egg
225g plain flour
½ tsp bicarbonate of soda
¼ tsp salt
200g plain chocolate chips or chunks
Method
STEP 1
Heat the oven to 190C/fan170C/gas 5 and line two baking sheets with non-stick baking paper.

STEP 2
Put 150g softened salted butter, 80g light brown muscovado sugar and 80g granulated sugar into a bowl and beat until creamy.

STEP 3
Beat in 2 tsp vanilla extract and 1 large egg.

STEP 4
Sift 225g plain flour, ½ tsp bicarbonate of soda and ¼ tsp salt into the bowl and mix it in with a wooden spoon.

STEP 5
Add 200g plain chocolate chips or chunks and stir well.

STEP 6
Use a teaspoon to make small scoops of the mixture, spacing them well apart on the baking trays. This mixture should make about 30 cookies.

STEP 7
Bake for 8–10 mins until they are light brown on the edges and still slightly soft in the centre if you press them.

STEP 8
Leave on the tray for a couple of mins to set and then lift onto a cooling rack.

RECIPE TIPS
FREEZING THE BISCUITS
If you’ve frozen the biscuits, take them out and arrange them on a lined baking sheet. Once defrosted, pop them in a medium oven 190C/170 fan/gas mark 5 and heat for 2-3 mins to crisp up. Don’t leave them too long or they’ll dry out.
STORING DOUGH
You can keep the uncooked dough in a sealed container in the fridge for up to two weeks. Simply take some out, dollop on a lined baking tray and allow to come up to room temperature for 5 mins before baking
Comments are disabled for this review.

review: Speaking from a modern viewpoint, and from somebody who has no nostalgia for this game or prior experience with it, this is pretty bad by today's standards. One final thing I'll say is, unless you have never played any modern videogames past somewhere around the year 2000, do not waste your time with this.

author: {'steamid': '76561198119490881', 'num_games_owned': 424, 'num_reviews': 80, 'playtime_forever': 419, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 419, 'last_played': 1656220095}
review:
Note: this is my first time actually playing through a GTA game.

I'm trying to get out of the habit of reviewing games without beating them (I only finished the first island), but you can't buy this version anymore anyway, and as far as I can tell I can't actually progress further without using an exploit (will explain).

+ The radio is the one saving grace of this game. This game deserves one positive thing, so I will give it that. There isn't [i]that[/i] much variety, and it got repetitive, but I did actually enjoy listening to insane rants on 109 The Chatterbox, or the satirical commercials about buying monkeys.

= Story and voice acting are middling.
= Graphics are terrible, though that's to be expected.

- [b]In order to be playable, this game needs driver-level vsync enabled, as it was only designed to run at 30 fps.[/b] On my GPU, at least, this forces the game to run at 60 fps. At unlimited framerates, reversing in vehicles (among other things) is completely broken, taking multiple minutes to move one car length.
- Aiming is absolutely awful, especially with the sniper rifle.
- Driving sucks. Controlling vehicles just doesn't feel good. On top of that, vehicles seem very easy to damage, and when a small mistake means your vehicle is upside-down, on fire, and/or in the ocean, the game encourages [i]careful[/i] driving. This can be especially annoying during missions, where I failed a few times just due to a mishap while driving, not due to the mission's actual content.
- The camera controls are annoying, as is its behavior during reversing a vehicle.
- The minimap is basically useless. First of all, it is zoomed so far in that it's hard to see anything of value, and I had to memorize the shape of city blocks to remember where to find things. It does show significant location icons outside missions, but during a mission they all disappear. This makes finding the Pay 'n' Spray during a police chase mission obnoxious. It feels intentional, but...that's why the Pay 'n' Spray exists, is it not? The map is also buggy -- in the following missions, the target's location often disappeared, so I couldn't complete the mission.
- If you fail a mission, you have to go back to the person you got it from and re-accept it. This wasn't a big deal, until it was. I failed "Last Requests" and was respawned in Portland. My boat despawned, and as far as I can tell, since Maria was already on Staunton Island, there was no way for me to get a new one to get back to Asuka with, outside exploiting the mechanics or plain cheating. Therefore, I'm just stuck.
- Nitpick: The cell phone icon reappeared to get the mission "Turismo" from El Burro, even after I had completed all of his missions.

3/10

author: {'steamid': '76561197991673744', 'num_games_owned': 1181, 'num_reviews': 187, 'playtime_forever': 899, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 899, 'last_played': 1655211460}
review:
I played this as a kid. Not completely by myself but through my older brother's save or something, I think. Anyway, I was maybe 14 at a time, so it was different than playing it now at age of 33. 

And boy, what a difference 20 years do make. Granted, reviewing this now is just for my own sake because no one can buy this version anymore, but what was more or less revolutionary 20 years ago in gaming, has not aged very well. A lot of things felt janky and lots of quality of life things that have come standard nowadays are missing here.

I think the biggest thing this game has in 2022 going for it is some of the characters. That's about it. The story isn't spectacular and has simply an light overarching connection altogether. 

But especially because of that, I would have preferred them to use this as a base of the "Definite Edition" they pushed out rather than what we did get.

There was no "I played this as a kid, I love it" nostalgia. It's more of a "memories grow sweeter with time" kind of deal. But to see what this truly was, and where it all became, playing t his was good.

At it's age, a lot of the "side-activities" of finding packages, doing odd-jobs as EMT etc. just don't feel like good waste of time. That being said, I guess it took me 10 to 12 hours to beat this with being sucky at games.

author: {'steamid': '76561198105400697', 'num_games_owned': 45, 'num_reviews': 30, 'playtime_forever': 545, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 545, 'last_played': 1653623710}
review:
Used to love this game as a kid, although between this and Vice City I'd pick Tommy Vercetti any day. Never noticed how flawed this game was till I went back to play it in today's times. For starters, the developers at GTA seem to be ironically anti-gun seeing as they went out of their way to make the AR15 to seem twice as deadly and have the highest capacity magazine -- which is usually something the left likes to do. Politics aside, it seems you get in trouble with the law in this game for defending yourself in a gun fight and that's pissing me off at this point. In the middle of a heist and just got pulled out of your car by some triads? Better not shoot back if you don't want the cops on your tail! 


... Then again I guess that's just California gun laws in a nut shell innit

review:
+ Great early 2000s NYC setting
+ Classic GTA gameplay
+ Compelling revenge story
+ Humor and comedic tones still hold up
- Needs mods for the best experience on PC
- Lack quality of life changes introduced in later installments
- Main story missions are quite short
- Vehicle damage can be a nuisance

Final rating: 8/10 with mods, 7/10 without mods.
Would recommend [b]with mods[/b] only.

author: {'steamid': '76561198411245252', 'num_games_owned': 78, 'num_reviews': 20, 'playtime_forever': 924, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 924, 'last_played': 1640077131}
review: Grand Theft Auto III is a 2001 action-adventure game developed by DMA Design and published by Rockstar Games. It is the third main entry in the Grand Theft Auto series, following 1999's Grand Theft Auto 2, and the fifth instalment overall. Set within the fictional Liberty City (loosely based on New York City), the story follows Claude, a silent protagonist who, after being betrayed and left for dead by his girlfriend during a robbery, embarks on a quest for revenge that leads him to become entangled in a world of crime, drugs, gang warfare, and corruption. The game is played from a third-person perspective and its world is navigated on foot or by vehicle. Its open world design lets players freely roam Liberty City, consisting of three main areas.

author: {'steamid': '76561198051376939', 'num_games_owned': 803, 'num_reviews': 449, 'playtime_forever': 347, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 341, 'last_played': 1648776898}
review:
To tell the truth, Grand Theft Auto III (2001) was without a doubt a phenomenal game to the industry of action genre.

Yet the game itself never was something I might call part of my childhood, but one more Grand Theft Auto someone would have found worthwhile and predecessor of legendary Vice City and San Andreas.

In my opinion the story in this part is just a skippable element of the background to make an aim for the missions, yet what definitely holds the story inside it is the city.

Atmosphere of the foggy and jazz-y town has its special attributes taking you into the early 2000.

Also, when we play through the whole trilogy of 3D Universe we can see how the gameplay and ideas of the developers vary from game to game.

reVote 7/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198006840534', 'num_games_owned': 178, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 4857, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3917, 'last_played': 1649629735}
review:
Considering the age, lets score it:
- Revolutionary.
- Open World (not a huge one).
- Main character won't say a word in the hole game.
- Guns and Cars.
- Needs to apply an easy fix for it to work on Win 10 and newer (see GTA3 Steam community guide).
- The Dodo can actually fly.

SCORE:
8 out of 10

This game made a revolution to 3D open world games, it's an absolute must have and play.
It's long enough to keep you driving, doing missions, shooting and exploding stuff on the open world, and short enough that makes it possible to actually complete 100% of the game without sacrificing your life to it.

TIP:
Before doing story missions read a "100% guide" so you can make the side missions you think are useful, or all if you want to get to the 100%. Paramedic missions will give health and adrenaline on safe houses, and gives you the useful unlimited running perk, hidden objects will give you guns and armor on safe houses, taxi missions will improve the taxi cars, and so on. You can do them later, but after the story missions some gangs will hate you and get in your way to make those side missions.
Money on this game does not matter that much, after a few missions (story or side) you'll have enough for the rest of the game, it will just pile up.

Have fun!

author: {'steamid': '76561198157743733', 'num_games_owned': 305, 'num_reviews': 66, 'playtime_forever': 1234, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1208, 'last_played': 1648203773}
review:
The original 3D GTA game.

Unfortunately this game is not for sale anymore (only included in the Definitive Edition), but let's review it anyway!

This is a pioneer of a game from the series humble 3D beginnings. That being said there's lots of things that the GTA series is known for that isn't in this game.

- The protagonist isn't voiced
- The story is really bad, uninspired and short (almost no dialogue)
- There are no motorcycles
- The missions are generic and mostly forgettable
- The characters are almost cartoony in their acting
- No map, only a mini map, can't stress how bad this is

That being said the Gameplay is quite fun. It uses the regular lineup of weapons that are being used in all games. The driving is fun - on PC definitely better than the GTA IV driving - and the missions serves their purpose of doing things that are fun.

The map is OK, but it is a three part Liberty City after all. The 2nd island is better than the 1st, but the 3rd island only has one proper mission attached to it. It shares the blandness, almost batman like, style of GTA IV and in my opinion a proper GTA game needs more color, as is the case with Vice City, San Adreas and GTA V.

The game is a bit cheap at times, and sometimes you just need to get lucky with the missions.

Do I recommend it? Maybe... just to see the beginnings of the franchise. GTA Vice City excelled the structure in every single way, and is my personal favourite of the PS2-era GTA games. This game is mostly forgettable though.

The missions unfortunately are often too frantic, timed and/or escort missions. There are very few missions where one can take their time and approach the goal as one pleases. There are no memorable heists and even after playing it I'd say there are few missions that I find all that interesting. The biggest problem is that there is no real story, and even though you are the active part it feels like you have no control of the story whatsoever - you just do what people tell you without question. You never feel like you know how things tie together, why Catalina is "the bad guy" (Catalina's character is very poorly told), and when you're done - what the heck did you accomplish?

Like said, the "story" is bare bones, the game is mostly just gameplay with some minor story elements attached to them.

On a positive note: the radio stations are amazing! You'll be introduced to Lazlo in the amazing Chatterbox radio station, one of the best GTA radio stations ever made. Chatterbox is truly GTA radio done right, and as a talk show - albeit short - it might just be the best in the series. Worth to play the game just for this radio station alone.

All in all score 5/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198333144715', 'num_games_owned': 105, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 844, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 844, 'last_played': 1647763946}
review: The game unfortunately is extremely dated without using lots of mods to fix a lot of issues. Which would be fine without the controls being the most frustrating to fix. Unless you're comfortable modding the game to an extreme amount, I couldn't recommend this version of the game to most people who would be interested in playing it. Despite the negative press, I think the Definitive Edition for the updates to controls seems to be the better version for most players today.

author: {'steamid': '76561198137804174', 'num_games_owned': 274, 'num_reviews': 40, 'playtime_forever': 695, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 695, 'last_played': 1647545773}
review:
Completed as of writing this review: Base Game.

As much as I appreciate this game for what shift in the series it created, [b] GTAIII [/b] is, unfortunately, an outdated game. Filled with missions that involve driving 85% of the time, shooting only like 3-4 times, ridiculous precision for how you need to complete them, and also a plot that goes nowhere until the very end. But this is the first time and the series has improved a lot following Vice City and San Andreas, so for its time, I would say it was a good game. Delivered something unique and was a big part of the evolution of open-world games. I'd recommend this only to see what was the start of the change from top-down to third person, but if you will get too frustrated to continue, just go play Vice City, it will be more worth your time.

review:
I am a 55 year old biker and trucker father, and probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So i decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my son many happy memories.

Thank you

author: {'steamid': '76561199189749702', 'num_games_owned': 161, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 19, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 6, 'last_played': 1645741228}
review:
Essentially unplayable without mods. Also, when I first launched this game it hard-crashed my PC and, the second time, it swapped my desktop and secondary monitors because why the heck not right?

Seriously: skip this one kiddos. I heard the remaster sucks too but like...well, maybe they should fix the glitches from the game that came out 20 years ago first. Sounds like a good start.

Helpful advice I found on a mod-page: if you want to change (fix) your resolution but can't see the game's menu screen/it's randomly invisible, toggle the Steam overlay. This also works with Vice City/S.A. Go team.

author: {'steamid': '76561197983584589', 'num_games_owned': 1148, 'num_reviews': 36, 'playtime_forever': 165, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 144, 'last_played': 1643246995}
review:
Played it back in the day on consoles, but never finished it.

Picked it up intending to finish it.

Just, no.  Not worth the time.  Amazing how (retrospectively) it becomes evident just how poorly designed a game is.  Vehicle physics pinballing you around.  A ported game that is broken by removing frame limiting (can't backup vehicles without a work around).  

Not worth the time.

author: {'steamid': '76561197960693835', 'num_games_owned': 1046, 'num_reviews': 130, 'playtime_forever': 1013, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 909, 'last_played': 1643208935}
review:
I have to be honest - this GTA is too long in the teeth to recommend playing today. 

Here are a few reasons why:

-Not sure if it is a bug but the cars and player can die/explode VERY quickly, you can go from 100 armor and 100 HP to dead in seconds
-A lot of missions have you escorting NPCs who can die very quickly
-This extreme damage ALSO applies to the NPCs you escort, making you fail missions regularly 
-Missions have no checkpoints, meaning if you fail them at any point you have to restart them
-If you need to restart a mission, you can not just restart it right away after you fail, you have to drive all the way back to the mission giver across the map to restart the mission
-You can not jump out of burning cars OR swim = in either situation it means you die instantly and have to restart the mission
-You have to stand still to fire any weapon bigger than an SMG, similar to older games like Resident Evil (it feels OFF)

I loved this game back in the day, Don't get me wrong - it paved the way for its sequels and most open world games even to this day. But if someone asked if they should play this now, I would say it is really frustrating to play now, and it best to skip it and play the later entries.

author: {'steamid': '76561198052043354', 'num_games_owned': 277, 'num_reviews': 53, 'playtime_forever': 464, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 422, 'last_played': 1662149807}
review:
I will make this very simple and very fair to the community for the publishers lack of understanding for their message below on the store page.

 (Notice: at the request of the publisher, Grand Theft Auto III is no longer available for sale on Steam.) 

               The gaming community did work to update this game outside of steam PC application platform, extensive programming for many hardware fixes and startup patch's for the game.                       They simply disrespected all the programmers who fixed their product, just for the end result of this classic game being removed due to carelessness of the publisher and developer.  They want to push sales of their new remake, when they could not even finish it.

The game is still better than GTA 5 online on a good day when no one bothers you, just because it still has its rough magic touch of old simplistic perfection with-in a nostalgia educed dazed perspective.       That is my simple opinion about the new and old idealistic views on the games of its kind.        The programming community would fix games as a side project even when they don't get paid to make people at the companies look bad, whats their excuse for not making a patch for a game that had some of the record breaking sales of over 155 million, last date of earnings count was Nov 3, 2021, really and they could not pay two programmers for less than two months or less to fix the game and update it, just to earn a million or more for paying for work and updating a legal copy right licence for the PC version on the digital market, or even release a game update patch, for continued sales.   

The game I bought works just okay after the community fixes, some basic windows security settings changes but, the people who wanted the original game have to resort to other means to get it <("_")>P  or find a legit key steam key seller online shop.

review:
Fernando's New Beginnings (commercial)

Fernando: "Has your marriage gone stale? Has the spark gone out of your 
          love life? Looking to add a little adventure to the monotony 
          of monogamy? Hello...I am Fernando Martinez, founder of 
          'Fernando's New Beginnings,' a revolutionary new way of saving 
          your marriage. We understand how 2 kids and a mortgage can 
          take the passion out of your life. With our three-step 
          program, you'll re-discover romance...guaranteed!"
Phil: "Hi, my name's Phil. I've got 3 kids, 2 cars and a mortgage. My 
      love life was going stale, even before my wife's car accident! 
      Then I called 'New Beginning!' Thanks to Fernando, I'm still 
      married. But on Wednesday afternoons, I meet Barbara at the motel 
      by the turnpike."
Fernando: "See...the passion, she is back. Phil's marriage...is saved. And 
          his kids will have a daddy to look up to. Call 'New 
          Beginnings' today...cinco cinco cinco- nueve dos nueve dos". It 
          will be a miracle, I guarantee it! 'Fernando's New 
          Beginnings,' we turn an ending...into a new beginning!"

author: {'steamid': '76561197965118877', 'num_games_owned': 203, 'num_reviews': 27, 'playtime_forever': 739, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 739, 'last_played': 1336633200}
review:
The first time I played this game 20 years ago, my uncle handed me the controller and an old guy came up to me in the game and beat me up. This had a profound impact on my life, and I had no idea old people enjoyed beating people up. 

Oh, and also the game's storytelling has had an impact on gaming as we know it.. but that's not as important.

author: {'steamid': '76561198066238704', 'num_games_owned': 692, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 190, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 190, 'last_played': 1640420311}
review:
Great game, it was great to see how modern GTA got its roots. However, this version is very very broken and needs a lot of mods to work, even then it has a hard time running on anything modern. I ended up playing about 3/4 of the game until it stopped spawning in the essential NPCS.

The story itself is great, but it has a hard time really conveying said story with a silent protagonist. Even then though, it's still fun as ever to drive around this old version of Liberty City and get lost in the retro atmosphere. Shame this game doesn't technically exist anymore.

author: {'steamid': '76561197975995617', 'num_games_owned': 248, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 1966, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1291, 'last_played': 1644684027}
review: This is a Piece of Gaming History. I have to admit, I have a lot of nostalgia bonus points for this one, but still. Every f***ing thing is just on point. This was the very first 3D GTA, which pretty much established a whole new genre in games. The new official GTA Trilogy (essentially a remake) is a joke compared to this gem coupled with a mod called "Definitive Edition" (go google it, in case you have this basic game), which improves a lot of technical stuff for modern PCs, since the game is fairly old.

author: {'steamid': '76561198296045521', 'num_games_owned': 267, 'num_reviews': 31, 'playtime_forever': 484, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 484, 'last_played': 1636232630}

author: {'steamid': '76561198040145997', 'num_games_owned': 318, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 1083, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 324, 'last_played': 1675621225}
review: This is definitely my favorite iteration of Grand Theft Auto, bar none. It chaps me to think that they took this off of the stores just for some low rate remake which wouldn't sell otherwise. This manifestation may not be perfect but it is certainly the most free roaming experience of old school gaming. You can either play the missions or shoot random people, imagining they are the assholes that pissed you off that day. People say this game insighted violence, well they are wrong, it prevents real life violence by allowing you some cathartic and therapeutic gore.

author: {'steamid': '76561198392026144', 'num_games_owned': 127, 'num_reviews': 90, 'playtime_forever': 718, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 718, 'last_played': 1640376690}
review:
not gonna lie I tried so hard to finish this game, but it feels like such a chore to play. it can be fun at times, and certainly was fun 2 decades ago, but it just is way too dated nowadays, if you get it in the trilogy bundle on sale this game will run you like 1.40, and its worth it at that, give it a try, but after so long and being pretty close to beating it I just cant bring myself to launch the game, there are so many random bugs and technical issues that make playing it a total chore. i almost never uninstall games before completing them, but this is one of them.

maybe if you play it heavily modded, or get the remaster it would definently be worth it, but vanilla gta 3 is not worth playing now.

a handful of missions are near impossible, if you fail a mission you have to completley restart, driving feels like aids a lot of the time and cars have no health, if you have 2 monitors you literally cant click on your mouse, things pop in 10 feet from you when driving. 

there definently is fun to be had here, but its so bogged down with all of the technical issues and poor aging, just buy the remaster even though this is dirt cheap

author: {'steamid': '76561199019983310', 'num_games_owned': 370, 'num_reviews': 67, 'playtime_forever': 2071, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2071, 'last_played': 1625607924}
review:
This might be a controversial take, but I don't like this game and I think it sucks. I have valid reasons on why this game is not good but first I just want to say there is aspects and glimmers of greatness in GTA III. It's groundbreaking for the series and open world games in general and there was never one like this back in the early 2000's. There is not many games at that time where you can murder pedestrians with a big arsenal. The cars in the game are surprisingly varied and have a good sense of weight and speed to them. There is a certain freedom in the mission design unlike the latest GTA and RDR2, sometimes limitations can be a blessing. 
With all the good things out of the way, the bad things outweigh them all and causes me to lose my mind. First things first, the story: It's very unique compared to other GTA's because you have a mute protagonist. The intro to the game gives us context to why our protagonist, named Claude, does all these jobs for these rich and hardened criminals. It's because his girlfriend betrays him, shoots him in the face and leaves him for dead. Claude wants revenge of course and he doesn't care how many suicide missions he has to go on, just to kill this one broad. He's a nothing character, he has one goal, he does not speak, doesn't have a clear personality, we can't hear his thoughts, he's just you, the player. There is many games where they make a silent protagonist work, like Link from TLOZ or Crash from Crash Bandicoot, there's so many ways to give these characters charming personalities while telling a fun story. In GTA III, the story revolves around Claude just doing jobs for multiple people then betraying those people to do more jobs for a different group of people, it's easily exhausting and not fun to experience. 
The controls have aged so poorly that drinking expired milk would feel more rewarding. I get that it's an old game but not even the definitive edition fixes these janky controls. The shooting is bad, the trilogy is often sighted for having terrible aiming controls, it's hard to explain but you just have to play it to see for yourself. Driving is fine and works but driving the boat or the plane is easily frustrating, it's nothing but bad missions when it comes to driving these floaty and drifty  vehicles in order to progress the story.
Most missions are pretty simple, drive this car to this destination, kill these guys or collect this item. Some of them get pretty inventive and you can beat them in a certain way, one of my favorite things to do is to park a bunch of cars in front of a enemy spawn, blow them up and watch as my enemies die in a horrific, explosive manner. But sometimes these missions are some of the worse I have ever played in a game. Some require patience and trial-and-error attempts, but these missions feel almost never-ending, one after another as they get progressively longer and difficult. The final three missions are the worst for me, one in which you have to find and destroy these coffee stands that are peddling out drugs. This mission has a time limit and you have to find every stand, you don't get a marker or hint where they are at so you either have to do trial-and-error runs or just be a cheating bastard like me and search up a guide. The mission after that is the one where you have to drive to a pier to get this boat, then drive said boat near this landing strip, then blow up a plane with an RPG, retrieve the packages from said plane, then drive back to where you started the mission. Sounds like an exhilarating mission, but it's not. You have a timer and you get a four star wanted level after blowing up the plane, it is ruthless if you are playing the original version, the cops are dedicated and will stop at nothing in order to kill Claude. If it weren't for the controls it would be an easier and probably a good mission but sadly it's more trial-and-error bulls*it. The final mission you have to get $500,000 in order to even start but if you haven't been dying and getting arrested, it should be easy. They strip you of all your weapons, all of them you have worked so hard to get, all gone. Claude then has to shoot his way out of this cartel compound by picking up a pistol off the ground, you get other weapons after it's over but it doesn't end there. He has to follow this helicopter that leads to the dam where his ex-girlfriend is trying to escape from. You then have to shoot your way through hitscanning cartel members, all while avoiding rockets and this big truck that's trying to run you over. Then blow up the helicopter with an RPG and don't miss because if you do, you will probably fail due to you getting killed or the time limit running out. This mission throws everything at you and doesn't stop, it gets progressively harder and you have to use cheap tactics in order to win, that is if those tactics can even be done fast enough because of that stupid time limit. After the game ended, I was happy, knowing I will never play it again. How did I even beat this game when I was a kid? This is easily the hardest game I have ever beaten and most of the time, I was hating every tedious, frustrating, janky second.
Yeah, this game has not at all aged well. In some aspects it's commendable, but playing it nowadays is frustrating and makes you want to rip every hair out of your head. The definitive edition is even worse. The graphics are awful and has glitches galore. Not even the shooting or controls were fixed, you might as well play the original and mod it to make it way better. But sadly, you can't because now it's off steam so they can try to sucker in hardcore GTA fans to buy their failed remaster trilogy. What a joke. Do I recommend this game? Maybe, if you have patience unlike me and don't mind doing the same missions and just want to goof off.

author: {'steamid': '76561198035374153', 'num_games_owned': 148, 'num_reviews': 100, 'playtime_forever': 733, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 442, 'last_played': 1640092685}
review:
Having escaped from a prison transport Claude soon gets back into a life of crime and seeks revenge on the former girlfriend that betrayed him and left him for dead.

As a game Grand Theft Auto III certainly has its flaws, including fairly poor controls as well as some horrendous difficulty spikes. The open world of Liberty City is simply astounding, but there is no way to look at the full map, which makes it extremely hard to find critical places.

Still worth a play through despite its age. I never got around to playing it until now and I enjoyed most of it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198544125410', 'num_games_owned': 30, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 1615, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1607, 'last_played': 1639993618}
review: While this is an old game and you can feel that in certain sections, it is still a great ride to go on. You will have fun exploring Liberty City and be amazed at times by all that this game has to offer. The driving is fun, the missions can be intriguing as well. There is something about the way that this game looks that gives it a certain dark and enticing look.

author: {'steamid': '76561198369716359', 'num_games_owned': 257, 'num_reviews': 50, 'playtime_forever': 4024, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1817, 'last_played': 1641459936}
review:
When it comes to portraying the world in which we live through a darkly humorous, rough-and-tumble lens, the folks from Rockstar and DMA surely win the prize.
Grand Theft Auto III is a hybrid game comprising driving, shooting, exploring, and in the truest sense, role-playing.

Players start as an nameless crook, who amidst a bank theft, is betrayed by his girlfriend, shot, and left for dead. As the "kid," "companion," or whatever your most recent supervisor chooses to allude to you as, you escape from the police through a secretive undeniable level quick in and out, and start life again with the assistance of your companion 8-Ball and the Italian Mafia. From that point, the game leads players through an odyssey of non-straight missions for different groups of organised crime, from the Italian to the Japanese mafia and so on. The 3D universe of Liberty City is on a scale that is really epic, comprising of three huge cities, the urban, industrial and suburban areas, each with proper engineering, scenes, and aggressive, distinctive AI.
What makes Grand Theft Auto III so different from other games in the series is the volume of characters, cut-scenes, and story embedded in virtually every mission, huge or little. Players observe that their missions are loaded with characters who are carried on at an expert level, and who maybe solid more undeniably more realistic than their simplistically visual caricatures uncover.

author: {'steamid': '76561198053980930', 'num_games_owned': 518, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 1913, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1913, 'last_played': 1638638542}
review: Very nostalgic game to see where the 3D roots of GTA came from. There is no map in the game which is unfortunate. The missions get quite difficult in the late game with police essentially spawning on top of you during a police chase. S.A.M and The Exchange seemed to be the most difficult missions in the game. The cars are pretty good for its time. The Cheetah, Infernus, and Banshee were the best cars in the game in terms of speed. Gun mechanics arent the greatest, but it is good enough for its time. Cant swim in this game which really sucks if you ever hit water. Overall a great first 3D entry for the series. 4/5

author: {'steamid': '76561198358348298', 'num_games_owned': 103, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 24162, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 23456, 'last_played': 1669933019}
review: 20 years later, and I still love this game. GTA III has definitely aged poorly but, it still holds up as an enjoyable experience.

author: {'steamid': '76561198099088813', 'num_games_owned': 105, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 1028, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1028, 'last_played': 1638588078}
review:
Many missions are trial and error heavy, so if you don't like dying/failing a lot, this game might not be for you. Otherwise, this is a classic and a game history landmark you should NOT miss!

Something to keep in mind before you play: If you prefer standard keyboard/mouse control and free aim, please either turn off widescreen in setting or install the widescreen fix mod, otherwise your aiming will be completely messed up.

author: {'steamid': '76561197977492618', 'num_games_owned': 1528, 'num_reviews': 124, 'playtime_forever': 618, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 309, 'last_played': 1639311646}
review:
The game mechanics are impressive and the base game is quite good, even revolutionary for it's time. 

What's not revolutionary however is the actual missions in this game. They seem to have been made by complete retards and idiots. The level of stupidity in the layouts and mission objectives is staggering. 

The games enormous potential, years ahead of it's time in technological terms, is coupled with level design and script of the lowest standard. The contrast between this is shocking to say at least. 

They could have handed it over to any random writer and still gotten a better result then the abomination that is GTA 3 script and missions. It's unbelievable how badly written/balanced this game is. The weakness of vehicles and the amount of suicide cops spawning is also something annoying that anyone should have caught in basic testing/balancing if any such events took place at all.

It still blows my mind that this game is made in the same era as Baldurs gate 2, Diablo 2 and four years after Goldeneye. Playing any of the mentioned games is like tasting fine wine, even today. Playing GTA 3s story today is as much fun as getting a ulcer.

review:
CLING CLANG

honest review:

playing this game was very enjoyable, and as a first ever entry to the GTA series we know and love today. it does hold up so much value! yes there are some bugs to this game and controls feel a bit weird but hey its a 2000s game and time was so different back then.. this game has a amazing story for our silent anime protagonist, the gun play was very enjoyable,  missions were a blast to run through even the side missions, and the sandbox was very fun to explore and drive around during those rainy days/nights.. this game is one of the all time CLASSICS for games.  
p.s.
i was one of the lucky ones to get this in a "original trilogy collection" many moons ago on sale. i feel bad for those that do want to play this game and cannot anymore because of stupid ass rockstar smh smh. honestly you are better just emulating this and finding mods to enjoy it much more. since this game is no longer on here, 

rip to those fellow-gamers. </3 

8/10

author: {'steamid': '76561199095042402', 'num_games_owned': 105, 'num_reviews': 63, 'playtime_forever': 99, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 64, 'last_played': 1653325347}
review:
When it comes to portraying the world in which we live through a darkly humorous, rough-and-tumble lens, the folks from Rockstar and DMA surely win the prize. I mean sure, there is corruption in the world, there is lots of crime and undoubtedly far too much drug-dealing, prostitution, cruelty, etc., etc. These things we get to read about in the newspaper, if not live out in our own little lives. They're not pleasant. So can these elements comprise a game? What happened to simply solving happy little puzzles, saving penguins, and receiving kisses from princesses?
Apparently, enough gameplayers and gamemakers have grown up to want something more in their games, and in the last four years videogames have grown. In Rockstar's fourth effort on PlayStation 2 (Midnight Club, Smuggler's Run, Oni), Grand Theft Auto III truly incorporates everything that its creators have strived for in a "proper game" since Take-Two created the upstart game division in 1998. In it, gamers have the chance to get dirty, to play the role of an ambitious, low-life criminal. The game is riddled with a breadth of goodies starting with the Mafioso rags-to-riches story, high-quality music, telling cut-scenes, and not ending with its giant, bristling, extraordinarily complex landscape.

What makes Grand Theft Auto III so much different and so brilliant in this third iteration is that while, with its huge scale, we might find familiar gameplay elements, the whole thing, the monstrous size and scope of the game, delivers something more than just the actual value of its parts. Having taken advantage of PS2's new technology to expand and develop their vision, the makers of Grand Theft Auto III have created a complete videogame experience like few, if any, before it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198275983662', 'num_games_owned': 219, 'num_reviews': 56, 'playtime_forever': 1385, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1385, 'last_played': 1638005933}
review: Hardest GTA game I've played. Vehicles are made of paper mâché and blow up after a few bullets. Hostile NPCs are equipped with shotguns that can blow up your car in one hit. M16s capable of killing you in in less than a second even with body armor on.  The game has a very basic map, you cant set waypoints. And there is no way to view the full map in-game. And places such as a pay n spray do not appear unless you are playing a mission that requires you to respray the car. Saving the game doesn't restore your health. You must memorize where health pick ups are in the map because they are the only way to regain health.The game has very a low rending distance. If you turn around cars will disappear and npcs vanish. Which is problematic because if you are standing around gang territory, and turn your camera they can spawn behind you and start shooting. The spawn rates of hostiles is insane, you could be on an empty side walk and the next second there could be 4 gang bangers or like 6 Mafia members with shotguns going to insta-kill you. You can't lose the cops by saving either, but you can get around this by saving and then reloading your save. Pay n spray still removes wanted levels. The AI is so good at shooting that carrying a sniper rifle becomes almost manditory, because if the NPCs get too close they will tear you up if they have anything better than a pistol. You will find yourself running over people to finish frequently because it's the easiest way to kill a hostile. You will probably save after every mission because if you dont you might die to something janky like your car flipping over. The main menu has a weird opacity problem where nothing is visible unless you wait 10 seconds for the options to become visible.

author: {'steamid': '76561198043176090', 'num_games_owned': 371, 'num_reviews': 21, 'playtime_forever': 59, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 33, 'last_played': 1648094694}
review:
Don't let the 33 minutes fool you because I've played (this particular version) for well over 4 hours and I have countless hours on other versions (OG XBOX).

A timeless piece of Gaming History that can be improved if you so wish via modding.
(Shout out to SilentP & GInput)

although original graphics are dated (ditto control scheme for PC) they are aesthetically pleasing, with the art style being consistant. The cutscenes in particular gripped me even after all these years and in my opinion the devs were correct in their stylistic choices & compromises with the cutscenes still holding well today (2021)

Although there are complaints with the PC Port they are reletivaly minor and somewhat able to be fixed or compensated for via mods.

If you have never played a grand theft auto and wish to start at the beginning... :p
 well this ain't it BUT it is much more approachable than GTA 1 or 2 & their expansions and is a good starting point to jump in. (Buy $$$)

If you have already played or finished GTA 3 then I would instead say wait for a sale unless you simply must finish your 'aughties retro' collection NOW.

The originals are coming back.

We will be adding the classic PC versions of Grand Theft Auto III, Grand Theft Auto: Vice City, and Grand Theft Auto: San Andreas back to the Rockstar Store shortly as a bundle. Additionally, everyone who has purchased Grand Theft Auto: The Trilogy – The Definitive Edition for PC from the Rockstar Store through June 30, 2022, will receive these classic versions in their Rockstar Games Launcher library at no additional cost. We will update everyone as soon as these are back in the Rockstar Store.

review:
Still a classic game, and a must play for fans of the series. It's really a piece of gaming history as the title most responsible for the proliferation of the open world genre. Playing it now, many years after the original launch, I only had two problems with it: the massive difficulty spike towards the end, and the how easily you can lock yourself out of a one hundred percent run.
Beware you'll need some fixes and mods to get the game working properly on modern systems. Check the community Guides section for more information.

review:
lucky I still have the original copy since 2016, so I can grab the "definitive" patches from the community and it honestly looks and play even better than the "definitive" edition everyone is talking about.

[spoiler]what I'm getting in community "definitive" patches are...  : 
- Restored PS2 contents (ex: newspaper, lighting, etc)
- Proper 60 FPS support with fixed physics especially vehicle physics 
- Proper 16:9 aspect ratio HUD 
- Upscaled HUD so it can look nice on HD display
- Camera control in vehicle!!!!![/spoiler]

review:
Man, what the hell is wrong with this version of the game?  Why does all the dialogue sound sped up and not like a witness protection program filter?  Why isn't the rain bright white and easily visible at all times?  Why don't the character models look like characters from The Sims???

Shameful job that Rockstar North did on this port, an absolute dishonor to the hard work done by the acclaimed dev team at Grove Street Games.  No wonder it's no longer for sale on Steam anymore.  So far from being definitive it's ridiculous.

author: {'steamid': '76561198312153282', 'num_games_owned': 1316, 'num_reviews': 323, 'playtime_forever': 96, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 96, 'last_played': 1498710855}
review:
In 2021, Take-Two Interactive and Rockstar Games sued modders just because they created mods (and offered them for free, of course) which drastically improve the Grand Theft Auto original 3D trilogy.

Then, Rockstar / Take-Two released a "definitive" (more like "definitively horrible") edition of the original trilogy which is exclusive to their launcher, has an art-style which can be accurately described as lazily abominable, and is riddled with bugs. Oh, and it costs [b]$60 dollars.[/b]

As of November of 2021, many people are demanding refunds for this terrible product and haven't received it.

And to top it all off, Rockstar / Take-Two removed the original GTA trilogy from all storefronts. The original GTA trilogy can no longer be obtained legally, unless you buy used physical versions for PC or consoles.

[b]DO NOT BUY ANY PRODUCT from Rockstar Games and/or Take-Two Interactive.[/b] They treat their customers like complete filth, and do NOT deserve your hard earned money. Not even half a cent.

author: {'steamid': '76561199007841957', 'num_games_owned': 82, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 1109, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 990, 'last_played': 1649447012}
review:
If you plan on getting the definitive edition, don't. Just get the old ones, even if it includes pirating it (which i agree, can be wrong. But due to R*'s choices and actions, is the only way to get it if you don't own them already).

The old game's graphics are way better than give way more detail to the game than the definitive edition does. It gives genuine ambiance and actually makes you feel as if you are playing the games as you were supposed to. All you need is a few mods that are free to get to fix the quirky stuff and that's it.

The original trilogy is something we all can agree is better than a dumb UE4 remaster made by some lazy devs.

I don't hate R*, I just think they did a mistake. And I think they know that as well.
