review:
I've completed this game several times on my xbox when I was like 11 years old, it's clunky and old but it layed the groundworks for one of the prime examples of how good a video game could be, it's just a shame that it also made Rockstar and Take Two heaps of money and they decided to outsource the game to some rando devs who cleary don't know what they're doing.

I don't suggest piracy, but even the DE is unplayable on pc at the time of this review, you can make that decision.

author: {'steamid': '76561198036637358', 'num_games_owned': 72, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 1126, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1126, 'last_played': 1614487835}
review:
This is an absolute embarrassment by Rockstar Games to discontinue the originals that brought them where they are today. Rockstar removing the originals on Steam shows how greedy they are, and not offering any refunds to the so called ‘Definitive Edition’. It is a huge middle finger to the modders who actually spent their time improving the originals, even better than what Rockstar had initially “remastered” the originals. Quite honestly the ‘Definitive Edition’ is a soulless joke that looks like a mobile port with very few changes like adding checkpoints in missions and a weapon wheel. The ‘Definitive Edition’ only very little improves graphically in comparison of what modders have done in the past, and if you are expecting the old bugs from the originals to be polished or any new gimmicks to be added I feel sorry for you. 

Save your $80 CAN ($60 USD) and buy yourself a nice meal or anything but this soulless joke.

author: {'steamid': '76561198119688777', 'num_games_owned': 273, 'num_reviews': 66, 'playtime_forever': 1912, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1912, 'last_played': 1456964055}
review:
[h1]At-A-Glance:[/h1]
[b]Game type:[/b] Third-person sandbox
[b]Genre(s):[/b] Crime, action
[b]Art:[/b] Early 3D rendering
[b]Length:[/b] Medium-long (~15-30 hours, depending on what you do)
[b]Pace:[/b] Medium-paced
[b]Tags:[/b] Character-driven, foundational game, great soundtrack, violent, morally ambiguous
[b]Computer requirements:[/b] Low-end


[h1]Notes:[/h1]
[olist]
[*] Another game where the binary "yes/no" of steam reviews really doesn't provide the right context.
[*] A landmark in open-world games and game development in general - though at this point, it's primarily a game worth playing for historical value or nostalgia. Many games (including Vice City and GTAIV) have taken what GTAIII did and refined/expanded it way beyond what GTAIII was possible of doing at the time of its release. This does not diminish its importance, but it does diminish its playability today.
[*] The latter third of the game is as bad and unfinished as it was when you were 13 - and with modern eyes, it's even worse.
[*] Though groundbreaking for its time, a modern player might be surprised at how empty GTAIII feels despite being lauded for all there is to do. You will be driving very long distances to the next missions. I can guarantee there are many streets in Liberty City that you have passed tons of times but never gone down because there's no reason to do so.
[*] That first third of the game is incredible on its own. The self-contained story of escape, success, and betrayal is the quintessential GTA story.
[*] Some weirdness with playing and installing this on modern systems. Your mileage may vary.
[/olist]

author: {'steamid': '76561198271394537', 'num_games_owned': 143, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 2304, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2304, 'last_played': 1635990383}
review:
Haven’t played a GTA game in a while so I was very surprised how much I enjoyed revisiting GTA 3. I still remember how mind-blowing it was to see an open world 3D city with a vast amount of activities to be done for the first time. Back in it’s day, GTA 3 was a revolutionary game.

Back to today, and it obviously didn’t age very well, but there’s something very enjoyable in the simplicity of it. All the way to 100% completion, never felt tired of it, which is very cool.

author: {'steamid': '76561198055476415', 'num_games_owned': 209, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 5717, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 5717, 'last_played': 1635641220}
review:
The game that set the series into what it is today. It is still fun and enjoyable with a bit of tweaking. There are guides within Steam to get it up and running on modern setups with not much hassle. Specifically the Enhanced Edition 2021 guide. 

It's just a shame that it's no longer possible to purchase this classic and piece of gaming history. Even with the Definitive Edition it would be nice for this version to remain as a choice in some fashion.

Fun fact: the time between the setting that this game takes place (2001) to now is more than the time between Vice City's release (2004) and its setting (1986). 

It's got a similar feeling that Vice City brings too, in that it's very nostalgic and has its roots firmly in the early 2000s where Vice City has 80s nostalgia set to high.

Fantastic game. Would recommend on principle, though a wasted effort. Can't really recommend what can't be purchased.

author: {'steamid': '76561198980741672', 'num_games_owned': 161, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 4591, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4569, 'last_played': 1673148891}
review:
[h1]Story 9,4/10[/h1]

The story follows around Claude Speed, our silent protagonist, who has been betrayed and left for dead by his girlfriend, Catalina, the leader of the Colombian Cartel gang, which led to him being arrested by the police during a heist at the Liberty City Bank. Claude was released from imprisontment during the transfer, but he doesn't just stand still, he embarks on a quest for revenge that requires him to start over again being a lowly crook for a gang to gain a reputation and become a "made-man", but it instead leads him to be entangled in the world of crime, drugs, gang wars, corruption and even deeper betrayals with other gangs.
Overall, I enjoyed the storytelling of this game, the story of the game's simple, gritty themed, a lot of dark comedy, and with insane amount of betrayal, yep, almost all the characters in this game have trust issues, but that's the special thing about this game.
The characterization in this game is quite impressive, Rockstar can turn the mute Claude throughout the game into one of the most iconic characters in the GTA series, they made Claude a reliable right-hand man to do anything for anyone who can treat him well, he's also neutral, no background, and emotionless, making Claude the best mysterious character in the GTA series in story-wise (and also the saddest simp), besides that, they have also created paranoid and lustful version of Vito Corleone (Salvatore Leone), backstabber and "ambitious" crazy woman ( Catalina), political Hannibal Lecter (Donald Love), etc.
Lore-wise, to be honest, it's definitely inferior to the games I reviewed previously (Half-Life and Resident Evil Remastered) and other GTA games after, such as lesser myths, legends, lores, and lots of unexplored backstory, for example, GTA Vice City has around 140 creatures and people-type myths and legends while GTA III only has 17, but some of it is still tolerable, because GTA III itself is Rockstar's first open-world 3D game (It's obvious they're still experimenting with 3D universe storytelling on a simpe game engine) and the fanbase isn't as big as other GTA games after.

[h1]Gameplay 4,7/10[/h1]
 
Being a revolutionary game that standardizes the concept of open world adventure 3D video games, of course, the greatness of the gameplay of this 2001 game can't be doubted. You can walk, sprint, jump, attack and shoot people, buy guns and ammunitions, steal, drive, and blow up cars, repair and change the color of your car, carry out different types of enganging missions, have safehouses to save data, extensive and very exploreable map, get killed (not really), get arrested, and do other stuffs like a real human but in an immersive 3D simple third-person camera experience. Indeed Rockstar was really great at making this revolutionary game when the capabilities of the console engine was still very limited at the time despite the many features cut from the final game.
As all GTA fans have said, GTA III has been named the most difficult GTA game ever, the reasons are the absence of full map (only minimap), many missions and side missions that are really difficult, and some unbalanced weapon stats (the iconic M16 that has an insane rate of fire of 1800 RPM but Micro Uzi only has a rate of fire of 600 RPM), but as I said above, this is tolerable since GTA III itself is a predecessor games before other famous GTA games after a.k.a outdated.
I may have praised and criticized a lot above, but there's one thing that I hate the most about this game, especially this version of the game, which is the super annoying bugs that even Rockstar is careless to fix it, such as the "deadly slippery floor" when the player is running on an uneven surface, sometimes user interfaces becomes invisible, can't do 100% completion, the uncompletable loading when your game progress is high enough (the solution is to exit and enter the game with the Windows key without closing the game ). This is all really annoying, this game would one of the Rockstar's biggest sin along with the original Vice City and San Andreas on Steam if there were no mod fixes from the community itself.

[h1]Graphics 10/10[/h1]

In terms of graphics, this game is quite fantastic, able to compete with games released in the same year despite carrying open world adventure 3D gameplay and the limitations of the console engine at that time, an example of the ground-breaking advantages of this game at that time is the detailed damage of the vehicles, pretty realistic human motion animations, realistic gunfires, impactful effects, interactive puddles, weather system, different shades of the sky that represent the characteristics of each borough, the darkest theme among all GTA games etc. While the special advantages of the Steam (PC) version include smoothest graphics, best draw distance, up to 10 resolution screen resolution support ranging from 640 x 480 x 16 to 1920 x 1080 x 32, widescreen support, best number of FPS, realistic color grading (not too contrast), good entity design details (though not as good as the Xbox or mobile version) and the best gore system among all GTA games.
This is exactly where the initial popularization of the GTA series' iconic font called pricedown that's used in almost all user interfaces in this game, the popularization of the character's artworks used as menu or loading backgrounds, and the appropriate color selection, it already can be seen that the user interface in this game is indeed amazing to the point it's used as a user interface benchmark for every GTA games after.

[h1]Sounds 9,9/10[/h1] 

Rockstar never disappoints me when it comes to soundtracks, for GTA III theme itself, it's number 4 of my favorite GTA theme, before Liberty City Stories, IV, and San Andreas. The radio stations here are also very good, my favorites are Double Clef FM (Italian classical), Rise FM (trance), and Flashback FM (80s pop). 
Relating to voice acting, like GTA games after that, Rockstar is willing to pay a high price for the quality of their voice actors, and that's really great, examples of famous Hollywood actors who voiced in GTA III include Frank Vincent (voice actor Salvatore Leone), Debi Mazar (voice actor Maria Latore), Robert Loggia (voice actor Ray Machowski) etc. Non-Hollywood voice actors are great too, like Guru (8-Ball voice actor), Lazlow (Lazlow voice actor, himself) etc.
But there's a problem where sometimes the pedestrians' voices is cut off by a second, therefore, some pedestrians' voices became unclear to hear, especially the normal pedestrians' (non-gang and non-authority)

[h1]Replayablity 9/10[/h1]

In addition to story missions, there are other missions that you can do after completing this game to reach 100% completion, ranging from the hardest to the easiest, specifically vehicle missions, off-road missions, phone missions, rampages, unique jumps, import/ export, hidden packages, and RC vehicle missions, however, because there's a bug that makes us unable to reach 100% completion, namely stuck at 99%, more precisely in one of the unique jumps in Shoreside Vale, it's annoying, but don't think too much about it since we also won't get anything at 100% completion anyway (satisfaction only), but there are some mission rewards that will be very useful for your playthrough such as vehicle missions, hidden packages, and import/ export.
There are also 22 cheat codes that you can activate to have fun with the game, but they're definitely fewer in number than the GTA games after, as it lacks well-known cheats such as the armor cheat, infinite cheat, and anti-wanted cheat.

[h1]Overall 8,5/10[/h1]

I have a love-hate relationship with Rockstar about this original trilogy, I love Rockstar for releasing this trilogy on Steam but I also hate Rockstar because they have no intention to improve this version and leave everything to the community, keep in mind again, I played and reviewed the unmodded version.

author: {'steamid': '76561198142816965', 'num_games_owned': 374, 'num_reviews': 152, 'playtime_forever': 1216, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1161, 'last_played': 1634915998}

author: {'steamid': '76561198421019072', 'num_games_owned': 120, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 19257, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 107, 'playtime_at_review': 1246, 'last_played': 1678480376}
review:
[h1]My Definitive Review of Grand Theft Auto III[/h1]

[b]About the game[/b]

During my first play, I thought this game wasn't good enough as the other two. In part, I'm kinda right, because the next games changed most of the things and made it better. But then I release that maybe a second chance couldn't be so bad. In fact, I enjoyed my second play, also I completed some missions I missed in my first play, and then I found this was very addicting. Not only the game-play itself is easy (because at some point, the practice will make the game easier), the missions are also pretty challenging, and at some point very fun.

If we talk about the story and the characters... this is just about going to a place, listen to our boss, and then do the task, but the characters aren't that annoying, even some of them are really cool, such as Asuka Kasen or Donald Love. It is not a Robert de Niro movie with a complex story and complex characters, but the action compensates those flaws, and then you find how good the game is.

In conclusion, it's a game in the series you can't miss. Of course it's not Vice City nor San Andreas, but it's a challenging game that will make you yell 'cause of the emotion! I recommend it... of course, if Rockstar releases the game again...

[b]About this PC port[/b]

It's important to you to know that you're going to purchase a PC version of this game. The original one is from PS2, and if you ask me, you may want to think twice, because this PC port isn't that good. For some reason Rockstar delivered a broken port, and hell, they didn't try to make it compatible with new hardware, so you can't play with widescreen support and you may want to play at 800x600 resolution. And not only that, the graphics are corrupted with this 1.1 version, and it's better that you downgrade to 1.0.

Many PS2 features are missing in this PC port, there is no newer hardware support, and the new "definitive edition" doesn't help, because they're broken too. So, the only fix to this big problem, is modding the game, and yet, you may feel that some things SHOULD be here in this PC version. It's up to you to purchase this gross port.

And there you go! My definitive review...

review:
Tonight, the TV event that will make history: Liberty City Survivor! This takes reality to a whole new level. We take twenty recently paroled guys, equip them with grenade launchers and flamethrowers, and let them hunt each other down! It's the reality show where you just might be part of the action!

I was grabbing a sandwich at the Happy Blimp, and all of a sudden, these guys crashed through the window and started shooting at each other. I was so excited I didn't even notice I've been hit! After that, I was hooked on Liberty City Survivor. I watch it every day in the hospital!

The game doesn't end until there's only one man left standing! Tune in nightly, or watch the 24-hour live webcast. Liberty City Survivor: natural selection has come home. Sponsored by Ammu-Nation: remember to put litter in its place, thank you.

author: {'steamid': '76561198104033148', 'num_games_owned': 145, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 931, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 905, 'last_played': 1654226268}
review:
Grand Theft Auto III, the Godfather of 3D open-world games, and just like the Persona series, this 3rd mainline game is where the series actually started for a lot of people. I understand making a review for this game is kind of moot considering that it's delisted from Steam, but I still would like to give my thoughts on the game in case they remain any relevant to or are challenged by the supposed Trilogy Remastered version, and maybe inspire some people to take a GTA game for a spin for once

In this game, we follow our new, silent protagonist "Claude" through his misadventures as an fugitive turned hired gun in Liberty City, (which is a parody of New York City, and is also called the "worst place in America", so take that commentary as you will), looking for a way to make a killing again, and get revenge on his ex-girlfriend that betrayed him and left him to take the fall for a robbery of the Bank of Liberty City.

Now, onto the actual review, I don't think this game is any good at all if you don't already like GTA from one of the better games. It's easily the worst "modern" GTA in terms of writing, game design, narrative, etc, to the point where people consider GTA Vice City to be the real GTA 3. But, I'll lay out the pros and cons for playing such a cursed game:

[h1] What am I getting into with GTA 3? [/h1]
+ Good worldbuilding and characters, in GTA 3 the universe is as crude as crude can be. Everyone is basically a maniac or incredibly cold in what they do, yet they all come off as a badass, or somehow comedic, or just plain stupid, or in some cases all of the above, and you'll probably end up enjoying most if not all of them for it because this game series is known for making legendary anti-heroes you can't help but love.
+ Good continuity as always, you meet a lot of characters from the prequel games like GTA LCS and GTA VC like Donald Love (VC), Toni Cipriani (LCS), Salvatore Leone (LCS), etc. The Forellis are a part of Leone side of missions, which is important to note for VC as well. Even Claude and Catalina's first in-universe appearances were in 1992, in GTA San Andreas.
+ Good licensed music as always, but GTA 3 specifically has the best radio station in all of GTA in Moving Shadow Radio (MSX FM).
+ Needless to say, you get to kill people and blow stuff up, it's awesome.

[h1] What's so bad about GTA 3? [/h1]
- Silent and underdeveloped protagonist leaves us with the a lack of a main character for no good reason, and a lot of dialogue to the player is also awkward because it HAS to be all one-sided. The game keeps its composure despite this, but good lord it makes the whole game feel like fetch quests and not like you're actually doing something for yourself like VC/SA.
- Game design is really scuffed in a lot of ways; minimap is not very detailed. No expandable in-game map like future GTA games, no map blips during missions, some very important blips do not appear at all such as Ammu-Nation stores.
- Game lacks a lot of things to do in general; you're almost always just doing jobs to progress the plot, there's not much else to do in terms of side missions, finding collectibles and looking at the map. The urban setting is nice but you don't buy this game to look at street corners all day. Money is also really shallow; missions give you a bunch, but no customization or anything to spend it on, you're only using your money to buy more guns and ammo, which you can never spend too much on.
- Game balancing and mission difficulty sucks half the time. I wouldn't have beaten this game without using cheats for the last 1/3rd, that's how bad some of the balancing gets. Lots of the mission difficulty assumes you know what the hell you're doing on a mission you've never done before; a lot of these missions you have to play them multiple times to complete because 1 mistake can ruin it all for you. Retrying is also pretty tedious. I could write an essay on everything wrong in this regard, but it ultimately comes down to poor/no standards in the early 2000s.
- Standalone story writing and narrative is nearly nonexistent compared to the other 3D trilogy games, or requires playing the other 3D trilogy games or the prequel to understand. I think this stems from a myriad of issues and I could write a full essay on this too, but I'm not going to do that here. I'll just let you know that GTA games start getting real logical story in Vice City, not here.

I may be biased, but regardless of all this, I'll still give this game a thumbs up, because it has its own charm and each GTA game feels more and more like a part of a whole rather than a standalone game the more you play into the series, and MSX FM is just too good to not recommend.

review:
I really enjoy GTA III, and it brings so much nostalgia to when I was younger. Which I was most certainly was not age suitable to play this game!.... But I came out alright. I guess..... Set aside from that I lack empathy, Joking. No not really, at least not for hoomans or annoying kids (Skyrim), needless to say IT'S name!..... I'm a killer, I'm a stone cold killer! Take charge, Viking, Barbarian, of course that's me! (quote).
I have more likes than dislikes. I really enjoy everything; graphics, story, missions, characters, especially the npc quotes. Everything is the same, although I think the PC version is better, there are a few add on's that console don't. I also use to mock some of the npc to mess around, 
The only dislike I have on the game are the controls. I can't use some of the actions and input them in the controller system. I guess I just need to find the right one for my controller.

author: {'steamid': '76561198002811365', 'num_games_owned': 696, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 2924, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2924, 'last_played': 1604662875}
review:
It sucks that this gem will no longer be available for purchase in its original form.
GTA III is my 2nd favourite game of all time (behind Flashback on Mega Drive).

It's sad that a lot of younger people will never know how big a deal this game was leading up to its release.

For me it was the best example of how to take advantage of a new generation of video game consoles and make a worthy numbered followup.

GTA III took the foundations that were GTA 1 & GTA 2 and doubled down. It was my most anticipated game of 2001.

The freedom was GTA III's major selling point.
"You don't have to do any of the missions"
"You can go where you like"
"You can do whatever you want"
The pitch was you had a fully-rendered 3D city to explore. That was the draw -- the appeal. There were little to no games like it at the time. It was revolutionary.

I'll use an example.

Sleeping Dogs, a cult favourite, wouldn't exist without the True Crime series, and those games wouldn't exist without GTA III's very existence.

Saints Row is getting a reboot as I write this review. That series was made at a time where there was no new GTA title. Saints Row 1 was clearly inspired by San Andreas, which was the series swansong for that generation. It took everything GTA III and Vice City had an perfected it. Open world games today would never play the way they do without GTA III's influence. GTA III inspired a generation of games and arguably revolutionised the open-world genre in general.

I have a lot of respect for GTA III.

Sure, it's nowhere near as cram-filled full of things to do as later games in the series, but it paved the way, and to those people who are complaining that there is no GTA VI being announced and regard GTA III as the worst in the series; do yourself a favour and put yourself in the shoes of someone living in 2001 and think to yourself "it'll never get better than this", because it did, and you have GTA III to thank for it.

Visuals - [7]
Gameplay - [10]
Music - [10]
Story - [8]

Personal overall score - Solid 10/10.

I cannot wait for the definitive edition.

review:
The beginning of a dream ...
The best description that can be given: a game that revolutionized the world gaming industry. Especially in open world style games.
This game was truly a masterpiece compared to the year it was released, and during the childhood of all our contemporaries, a lot of time was spent playing this game.
A great nostalgia for fans of the GTA game series
In my opinion, this game was the beginning of making Rockstar masterpieces.
I hope the remaster will be as good as its own, compared to the year of release.
I really want to experience this game again with a more modern gameplay and updated graphics :) I hope I do not disappoint ...

review:
Легендарная игра.

Звук в игре отличный - озвучка главных героев, да и вообще всех персонажей игры, выполнена на высшем уровне. Не отстают от нее звуки большого города и местных радиостанций, где юмористические ди-джеи постоянно подкалывают радиослушателей, дозванивающихся в студию ... в перерывах между музыкальными композициями. любимые радиостанции и слушайте их, не выходя из машины ...

Legendary game.

The sound in the game is great - the voice acting of the main characters, and indeed all the characters in the game, is made at the highest level. The sounds of the big city do not lag behind her, as well as local radio stations, where humorous DJs constantly pin up radio listeners dialing into the studio ... in between musical compositions. favorite radio stations and listen to them without leaving the car ...

author: {'steamid': '76561198272958253', 'num_games_owned': 75, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 41102, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 134, 'playtime_at_review': 35491, 'last_played': 1677970655}
review:
My favorite GTA game of all time, thanks to its world, style and overall vibe, the atmosphere of this game has always spoken to me, its dark streets, the shitty weather, the incredible MSX FM, Claude's outfit, and a lot more.
Portland, particularly, being the island i spent the most time in on top of being the one with the most detail put into it, is the part of the city i'm most attached to, Saint Mark's (pre Sayonara Salvatore, at least), just feels like home. It's impressive how alive Liberty City feels despite this game turning 20 this year.
Between the original version on Ps2, the Ps3 and Ps4 ports, the iOS one and the Steam version i might have spent around 3000 hours playing it, speedrunning it and modding it installing all sorts of stuff. Now, is that good for you? Probably not, was that fun? Damn straight.
A revolutionary game that has accompanied me throughout my life, knowing that it will stop being sold digitally at some point during the next three months saddens me, the original versions of the main Ps2 era GTA trilogy should always be preserved, They are an integral part of gaming history, and seeing them being completely replaced by the Definitive Edition feels wrong.
This said, buy it before it gets delisted, it's certainly showing its age, but it's still very much worth playing if you want to experience a big part of gaming history and the game that defined the open world genre in its original form.

author: {'steamid': '76561199073008877', 'num_games_owned': 513, 'num_reviews': 106, 'playtime_forever': 688, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 660, 'last_played': 1663649054}
review:
I really like how this game is simple compared to later instalments. Not that I don't like the other GTAs, but this one takes me back to the late 90s / early 2000s atmosphere. Even with the limitations it has, this certainly made people crazy back in 2001. Now the remaster was announced, I also would like Rockstar to keep the original versions of the trilogy available for those who may still want them in the future, but I'm afraid that won't happen.
[h3][b] Rating: Great [/b][/h3]

Eu realmente gosto como este jogo é simples comparado aos posteriores. Não que eu não goste dos outros GTAs, mas este me leva de volta à atmosfera do fim dos anos 90 / início dos anos 2000. Mesmo com as limitações que possui, ele certamente enlouqueceu as pessoas lá em 2001. Agora que a remasterização foi anunciada, também gostaria que a Rockstar mantivesse a versão original da trilogia disponível para quem quiser tê-la no futuro, mas acho que não vai acontecer.
[h3][b] Nota: Ótimo [/b][/h3]

author: {'steamid': '76561198068042100', 'num_games_owned': 288, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 364, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 308, 'last_played': 1632963187}
review:
Ok, this is an old game that was doing something completely new at the time. I get that this means there are a few things that aren't gong to be as polished as they became for later titles. However, this game's driving mechanics are HORRENDOUS. First, the hitboxes for vehicles and objects are much larger than the models are. This often leads to situations where you're going at high speed for any number of reasons and you see a slight gap between two vehicles/objects that looks big enough to drive through. WRONG! Even thought the asset models don't touch each other, the game still counts it as a collision. Second, these vehicles are incredibly fragile. Most fall apart after a few hits. Third, there are simultaneously very few vehicles and too many vehicles on the road. I do not now how that is possible, but this game manages it. You don't really notice this third thing until you are unfortunate enough to get to one of this game's racing/time trial sections. These elements aren't so bad individually, but taken together, they add up to a very frustrating experience. I could ignore all of this if the missions focused more on combat ore something and, to be fair, the first part of the game does for the most part. However, there are tons and tons of racing/time trial missions which force you to engage with these shitty mechanics under a time constraint that is way too strict considering how terrible the driving is. A lot of these missions also drag on for way too long for how little time they give you to complete them. 

There's one fairly early on where you have to collect magazines that are falling out of the back of a van and you have to follow the trail of magazines to find the van. You have to use another top-heavy van that tips over and spins out constantly to collect the magazines on the trail and are given 25 seconds to find the van where they are falling out of. Each one you collect gives you +1 second to your timer. Despite this short timer, this game has you drive all over the first section of the map (for those who haven't played this yet, the map is divided into three islands). With the crappy driving mechanics that I mentioned above, this mission really starts to test your patience. The racing/time trial missions only get worse from there. 

I played this back on the PS2 and forgot how much I hated the driving. I also forgot just how much of this game forces you to interact with its worst elements. Aside from this though, the rest of the game is actually still pretty good. However, with how bad the racing/time trial missions are and how many of these missions there are, I cannot recommend buying this game. Only buy this if you have the patience to deal with bad driving mechanics for extended periods of time.

author: {'steamid': '76561198051937495', 'num_games_owned': 300, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 2027, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1771, 'last_played': 1665496715}
review:
Grand Theft Auto III is not a bad game. It was revolutionary for the time, however, it has not aged well and there isn't much to it that new GTA titles don't have. I played this game partially for nostalgia, and partially because I found a collection of mods that remaster the 3D era games (while still remaining vanilla) to look sharper and work on modern hardware.

In Grand Theft Auto III, you take control of Claude, a long time gangster who is betrayed by his girlfriend Catalina, who shoots him and leaves him to die. You survive, and go working for various mobsters. The game TRIES to have a plot, story, and characters, but almost nobody is fleshed out. Claude is mute, and has almost no character. There are examples of mute characters that work out well, like Gordon Freeman from Half Life, but this is not that case. I did not feel like I was immersed in the role of Claude, nor did he feel relatable in any way. He is simply an empty character that interacts with mostly empty characters.

The graphics and gameplay aren't bad. You have to keep in mind this is a game from 2001, and was one of the first of it's kind. As I said though, graphics and gameplay only get this game so far, when anybody has the option of playing later titles in the series.

Overall, I'll give this game a 6/10. Would be 5/10, but I'll give it an extra point for nostalgia and history. If you absolutely want to go back and play this, go ahead, but in general, I would suggest skipping this and moving on to either Vice City or SA.

review:
Finally completed it after 19yrs, woohoo!!

Although the graphics now look dated (they didn't when I started), the gameplay is still good.  I did need a mod to use the xbox controller, and once or twice I had to control my direction on the controller, whilst pressing shift to sprint, though you get used to it, and it was only for a couple of missions.  That said, there may be a way to sprint using the controller.

It's a classic, and I definitely got my money's worth out of it!

author: {'steamid': '76561198123476024', 'num_games_owned': 82, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 286, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 286, 'last_played': 1631469323}
review:
GTA III has set the basis for many of triple A games we see today. Coming out in 2001 the game is still fun to come back and reminiscence of the good ol days of blocky textures, wacky animations, arcadey gameplay and overall basics of a game of that time frame. The game is rather short and small but for it's time it is mad impressive what a developer could do coming from the Top-Down gameplay of GTA 1 and GTA 2. The same concept of those past two games has stayed the same yet with the aspect of a 3D world. 

Note: I did have to install a few mod's to make the game enjoyable as the steam version does have a few issues. There are plenty of guides on how to install them here on steam.

Story wise it lacks in length as I was able to complete it in a mere couple hours. However looking back I could've done the side stuff for a few bonuses. It's not my first time playing it either so that also could account in how I was able to beat it in such time. Gameplay was simple enough yet was a little unforgiving gunfight wise. I found myself failing missions here and there, mainly when it involved the police (May I say the police in this game are BRUTAL). Countless times I was almost in a panic as the cops tried to ram me off the road constantly. Some of the gunfights with the enemies felt rewarding as it required you to be cautious as your HP/Armor can be shredded in a mere few bursts of gunshots, so over exposing yourself in fights was definitely a no go. 

Overall there really isn't much to GTA III other then it set a very great and very high expectation goal for other game developers. Including itself. Almost cementing itself as one of the reasons why we have such good games now.  Definitely going to be returning to it again eventually as it serves as a reminder of the simpler times.

author: {'steamid': '76561198079220292', 'num_games_owned': 324, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 703, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 703, 'last_played': 1631465973}
review:
It is an old game and the first 3D GTA to be ever produced. 
Graphics were average for their time (bad compared to next year's Vice City), archaic controls, very limited options on what to do, countless bugs that slowed my progress significantly and the story line seemed to be too boring and somehow incomplete.
I felt that the whole interaction between all those characters and the general climate was too bland and depressing.
Most characters came and go without a purpose.
I cannot imagine what was the reason for making a mute protagonist back then.
For the first time on my gaming experience, I felt like I was forced to finish a game.
I don't know what could have been my review if I didn't play Vice City back then. 
Not gonna touch it again, thank you.

author: {'steamid': '76561198092320614', 'num_games_owned': 299, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 1863, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1697, 'last_played': 1677122586}
review:
Grand Theft Auto III is a timeless classic that's been one of my favorites all my life. Incredible game. I however do NOT recommend the PC version in any capacity, as Rockstar has refused time and time again to patch the game to work better on modern machines. At this point the PC version is borderline unplayable. Recently, a reverse engineering team developed Re3, a modern source port that fixes hundreds of bugs, adds widescreen support, and was soon to add fixes for framerates above 30 for the first time ever. However, the publisher Take Two is suing the developers, and holding the project hostage. Losing Re3 means that the game will remain a buggy unplayable mess on PC, and the mobile ports won't be any better. For now, the best way to play the game is to just get the game second-hand for the PlayStation 2 and play it through an emulator or on a PS2.

Take Two / Rockstar, if you even looking at this, How about you instead work with the developers on Re3 and publish this improved version on Steam on Rockstar Launcher. You are throwing money out the window not doing this.

author: {'steamid': '76561198044004981', 'num_games_owned': 235, 'num_reviews': 26, 'playtime_forever': 146, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 146, 'last_played': 1372268316}
review: Take Two Interactive has filed a lawsuit against the developers of re3, an excellent reverse engineered version of the game that fixes a lot of the issues with the game, particularly ones that arise on modern systems. This is a frivolous lawsuit; no game assets were included with re3, which amounts to nothing more than a community patch. This comes just a few weeks after Take Two also ordered takedowns of numerous GTA mods, including a port of Liberty City Stories to the PC Vice City engine; the game had never been released on PC officially. Mods allow these games to be playable to modern standards; with Take Two shutting these projects down, they're making their own games less accessible. Whatever lazy "remastered" versions they may or may not be planning will pale in comparison to the faithful work the community has been doing.

review: GTA: Liberty City Stories is a much more fleshed out and rewarding game than this, and yet there is no PC port of it, but I digress this in itself is not a bad game at its time and at its prime, but it has aged very poorly, the game play is tedious, health is hard to manage, maneuvering vehicles all feels too fragile and it makes the driving in mafia 1 look good, the 90's vibe the radio gives is great it helps reduce the nausea I feel when playing the game I don't know if its the color palette or the experimental motion blur that they added or the field of view it just makes me feel sick, the story is a bit interesting but it isn't very memorable you can skip it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198450345569', 'num_games_owned': 396, 'num_reviews': 180, 'playtime_forever': 3417, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3417, 'last_played': 1666259843}
review:
i review games on steam after i 100% complete them! check out my reviews to see all the games i have completed!

(you can still get a key of this game and the other delisted gta games off a reseller website)

GTA 3 is the first 3D open world GTA game in the series, where you play in liberty city, a setting based loosely on new york/detroit/chicago, as a guy named claude trying to get revenge after his girlfriend betrays him during a successful bank heist. this game was considered one of the best games of all time around when it first came out, and while it has aged poorly in the 20 years since it first came out, it's still worth playing through the main story at the very least. it's really easy to install really good mods that make this game extremely better visually and/or fix a lot of game mechanic issues.

author: {'steamid': '76561198170282770', 'num_games_owned': 119, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 4414, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3453, 'last_played': 1653068960}
review:
Its a little broken on modern PCs but can be fixed quite easily. This game is fun despite being very simple and not having some things that later gta games have, EG u dont have free look in vehicles and there is no free aim when firing out of them so you can only shoot left and right. The city is small but i dont think it needed to be any larger. Some of the missions are fun but a lot are tedious. There are no checkpoints and you have to restart missions if you fail them. You dont keep weapons or armour when you die. I think this game has one of the most enjoyable wanted systems as the police are very aggressive and dangerous. 
Overall, fun game, would recommend.

review: I definitely recommend it if you want to try out the old 3d gta games. It's short so you won't be wasting a lot of time playing it. Story-wise is simple enough for a gta game, its a classic revenge story. Gameplay can be frustrating at times, but I can't criticize it that much since its the first iteration of the 3D era of gta. Overall I really enjoyed, as its the first time that I actually played the game from start to completion. I really want to play the sequels now!

author: {'steamid': '76561198039515791', 'num_games_owned': 563, 'num_reviews': 20, 'playtime_forever': 2172, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2172, 'last_played': 1629328237}
review:
Good game, when you patch it with fan fixes. I originally played this game as a kid, when it was the newest GTA, and just beat it for the first time, tonight. It's harder than the other GTA games, but still real fun. Your cars are made of paper, the story is basic, and the third island was a headache to navigate, but I still had a good time, all in all.

Play it if you want to experience the first 3D open world game, to see what worked, and what didn't, and how it started a genre. Fun fact, with the camera angles, you can play this game entirely in isometric view to play like GTA 1 and 2, if you wanted. I played most of it in the standard third person perspective. 

07/10. A good game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198394820901', 'num_games_owned': 242, 'num_reviews': 32, 'playtime_forever': 214, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 214, 'last_played': 1629112660}
review: GTA 3 is a highly influential game which laid down the foundation for most of the future open world sandbox games. However I would not recommend this game unless you played it before, playing it for the first time in 2021, I think that the game has aged very poorly. So first of all you only have a small mini map and other than that you have to rely solely on your memory to know where everything is, for example to lose the police you have to know the locations of pick ups which lower your heat level and these are not shown on the mini map. Secondly I found the missions to be frustrating as there is no checkpoints and the objectives can be annoying such as the mission "Taking Out the Laundry" in which the player is tasked with destroying 3 moving vans and is given grenades. Also worth mentioning is the fact that you have to download numerous patches to get the game to work properly on Windows 10 and while these patches fixed mostly everything I still had some annoying graphical bugs which I couldn't fix.

author: {'steamid': '76561198042383071', 'num_games_owned': 548, 'num_reviews': 249, 'playtime_forever': 2601, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2602, 'last_played': 1627829748}
review:
GTA's first go at 3D gameplay? I am about it.

Although the game isn't exactly beautiful anymore I think GTA 3 deserves a recommendation because this is the real start to the series that we know today (not the top down shooter of 1 and 2). Although I think Vice City was the best while also being an early entry there is no denying GTA 3 was a first of its kind. My only suggestion would be to watch some gameplay before you buy the game so you don't buy it with the wrong expectations but if you feel like taking a trip down memory lane in the GTA series, this would be a good place to start.

So all in all 12/10 would be a busy boy again.

review:
This game is older than me.

Since I've already played through the story of V and IV I thought that I have to finish the third part of the series as well. I think it's not a must play but if you are a fanatic of the GTA games, I recommend it to you.
The graphics are of course outdated (I used a mod pack called Definitive Edition) and only the start and the end of the story is important.

But hey, this was the first GTA in the 3D era and can't tell how successful it was.

P.S. Staying up forever, with Rise!

author: {'steamid': '76561199012556694', 'num_games_owned': 183, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 1730, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1648, 'last_played': 1634958695}
review:
This game actually aged like milk and was one of the most brain-meltingly frustrating experiences I've ever had the misfortune to live through. Claude's silent emotionless face torments my nightmares to this day. Some of the missions in this game made me feel genuine despair. Like, this one where you have to find and destroy 8 vending machines serving something called 'SPANK' in 7 minutes. Or another, where you have to get on a boat (something that is extremely difficult due to the physics and the fact that if you fall in the water of Liberty City you almost immediately drown) and use a rocket launcher to shoot down an extremely fast airplane. 

The mission design in this game is the bane of my existence. That, on top of the terrible free aim, nearly non-existent camera controls when driving a car or using lock on, and the fact the slightest bump, or a turn that's a little bit too sharp will cause your car to flip over and explode made me lose sleep over this game. The countless nights where I was up at 7 am struggling to complete a mission.

Not to mention that the game forces you to play at 30 fps, or else it will be a buggy mess. Which shouldn't be a problem for some people, but I'm sure for others it's a deal-breaker. The story is nearly nonexistent, as, for some reason it centers around Claude. a silent protagonist's, quest for revenge on his now ex-girlfriend Catalina. Almost every cutscene consists of 

Claude walks in

"Oh! It's you! I work for (Criminal organization), and I need you to do some work for me! Do it!"

Claude leaves.

So that's certainly a mission setup.
I should mention, that by the end of the game I had almost 2 million dollars, yet there's really nothing to spend said 2 million dollars. There's no properties and assets and whatnot to purchase, like in Vice City. There's no cool outfits and stuff to buy like in San Andreas. No vehicles and properties or stocks like in GTA V. (Leaving out 4 because I don't remember there being much to buy post game either). You just kind of have a bunch of money for the sake of having money. Maybe to refill your arsenal every time you die or get busted (and getting busted in these 3D era games is painfully easy, so prepare to do it a lot. I mean, I eat explosions with a side of bullets for breakfast lunch and dinner why does one officer pointing a pistol at me make me instantly surrender this is cruel and unusual)

Oh, also the M16. It might be one of the most absurdly overpowered weapons in Grand Theft Auto history. The enemies in this game actually have like, aimbot tier aim. And with the M16 (Which can shoot all 60 bullets in like, under a second) you are bound to get wiped off the face of this earth and deleted, even at full heath and armor, in maybe 2 seconds. Sometimes I'd turn a corner and be dead before I could even think to look up at my health.

Also there's no map, which sucks because I have the memory of a sentient acorn so I could never memorize the map. 
I probably left out some stuff but that's the gist of it.

That being said, I enjoyed this game and I will be doing a second playthrough. 10/10.

author: {'steamid': '76561198238388924', 'num_games_owned': 419, 'num_reviews': 92, 'playtime_forever': 535, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 535, 'last_played': 1627754595}
review:
[h1] Grand Theft Auto III - 5.1/10 (8.5/10 back in 2001) [/h1]
[b] Playthrough Length - [/b] 8.9 hours

[b] Plot and Dialogue: [/b] 2.0/10, 5.0/10
[b] Setting and Art Design: [/b] 7.0/10
[b] Soundtrack: [/b] 7.0/10
[b] Graphics: [/b] 3/10 (It came out in 2001, so this doesn't really count)
[b] Gameplay and Sound Design: [/b] 5.0/10, 5.0/10

[b] Plot and Dialogue: [/b]
There isn't a plot. And the game only connects what happens at the beginning of the game at the end of the game. The entire middle part is filler when it comes to the greater  gameplay. The dialogue is pretty mediocre all things considered, nothing I remembered all too well. 

[b] Setting and Art Design: [/b]
The setting of Liberty City is done pretty well with a nice and open map. There is plenty for you to explore and it really does feel like New York City, so good job on that regard. 

[b] Soundtrack: [/b]
The radio stations in this game are the only music you'll find, except for the end credits. The radio stations are pretty good with their own variety and vibe to them, so you'll find what you like. I liked Flashback 95.6 the most and Jah Radio. 

[b] Graphics: [/b] 
The graphics are pretty bad but this game came out in 2001, so I can't really knock it for that reason. 

[b] Gameplay and Sound Design: [/b] 
The gameplay is weird on PC, as it seems that you cannot shoot while in a car. A lot of the guns in the game force you to remain stationary, when it does not make much sense for that to happen. Enemies die pretty fast to most weapons. Car driving is surprisingly good and holds up pretty well to this day. One annoying aspect is that if your car flips and lands on the roof, it will automatically catch on fire, forcing you to run out of there. There are additional phone missions besides the main missions and you can collect hidden packages around the map, which offers a good amount of replayability. 

The sound design is average, it's kinda funky at some times but it holds up alright for a majority of it.

[b] Final Notes: [/b]
This game was pretty revolutionary when it came out, going from 2D to 3D for the first time in the GTA franchise. Rockstar was clearly in its infancy when it comes to telling stories and I believe this was mostly a test to see if Rockstar could work with the new engine, and they definitely did. The game does not hold up too well to today's standards, especially when compared to games like Halo: Combat Evolved and Half-Life. This is still a good game to play and I recommend it if you don't have anything else to do.

author: {'steamid': '76561198159268598', 'num_games_owned': 143, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 217, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 209, 'last_played': 1628028427}
review:
Some classics don't live up to memory and are better left in the pass.  This, however, is not the case for GTA III. By today's standards, this game is rough around the edges, but for it's time, it was a masterpiece.  

If you are looking to play with an XBOX controller, I recommend downloading a mod.  This will give you normal controls, and the instruction hints come up as XBOX buttons.  

I ran into some issues regarding the main menu disappearing.  ALT-Tab out of the game and back in brings it back.  A minor inconvenience to an otherwise great, classic experience.

author: {'steamid': '76561197973207923', 'num_games_owned': 371, 'num_reviews': 46, 'playtime_forever': 1042, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1042, 'last_played': 1627436503}
review:
I was feeling nostalgic and wanted to revisit this game after...  20 years (Hnnnnnng!).

What was once a revolutionary juggernaut of a PS2 title now feels almost primordial. The arcadey driving and physics that send your car spinning or flipping out of control with a small tap can quickly become a frustration, especially with the AI traffic and low health of vehicles. However, the missions were still good enough for me to play through the entire game.

Finally, you [b]need[/b] mods to play this game on modern hardware. Thankfully, they are plentiful, free, and relatively easy to install. Big thanks to the modders and guide writers! And big thanks to whomever discovered the bribe star/replay glitch, hehe. 

If you're feeling the itch to revisit GTA3, or want to see what this era of GTA was about, wait for a sale.

author: {'steamid': '76561198117565450', 'num_games_owned': 30, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 1226, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1038, 'last_played': 1660586006}

author: {'steamid': '76561198124551058', 'num_games_owned': 741, 'num_reviews': 96, 'playtime_forever': 1274, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 159, 'last_played': 1637580691}
review:
A game that upon release was revolutionary, one of the first 3d open world games where I felt I could do what I want, when I wanted; an amazing experience for 2001/2002.
Through the years the game has aged poorly and requires mods and workarounds to even get running. Would love to see a modern trilogy collection that just works.
If you see on sale: the mods, albeit annoying, are simple to install. Which I think makes the purchase 100% worth it.

7/10 - Vice City and San Andreas improved the formula, this is still worth the playthrough.

author: {'steamid': '76561198891836081', 'num_games_owned': 54, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 730, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 728, 'last_played': 1626984256}
review: I can't recomend this game version as it was much too difficult to get it working properly under win 10 and much outside help was needed as far as advice and addons. As is the best resolution obtainable is 640x480 and yet with help it runs at super high def. Then cheat programs didn't work until I found the only version with very limited cheats that would work with this version. Today my Steam updated and crashes the game before it can start. Keep in mind I bought this less than a month ago so its not like I'm trying to get something working from 20 years ago. These boys set this game to be sold on this site but never bothered to make it work on the pc's they sold them for. When I did finally get it working with outside files it was stable and fun but no one should have to do anything more than hit the "install" button and now, as of this weeks update, its completely trashed again.

author: {'steamid': '76561198065051650', 'num_games_owned': 110, 'num_reviews': 22, 'playtime_forever': 2389, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2362, 'last_played': 1627299392}
review:
Grand Theft Auto 3 spawned endless imitators after it's release back when open world games used to be a rarity in 2001. GTA 3 is a unique game because it created a trophy in video games industry called "Best Open World Crime Sandbox".

It was far from being a perfect game at that and playing it today certainly showed some of it's ages whether good or bad. There were plenty of ways to improve GTA 3 and one being crystal clear was "do this but bigger" which Rockstar did with Grand Theft Auto Vice City one year later,

Today, GTA 3 might look like a disappointing attempt to win that trophy but it had created a solid foundation that launched the Grand Theft Auto series as true elite in "Open World Crime Sandbox".

author: {'steamid': '76561198017118014', 'num_games_owned': 372, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 3042, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3042, 'last_played': 1621183994}
review:
8/10

Good:
+ Reasonable and absolutely worthwhile price for such a iconic game. A must buy in my opinion!
+ One of the oldest memories I have of any video games, which makes it a truly special game in my own eyes just because of that, even though it's gotten quite old and outdated obviously.
+ Even though the protagonist "Claude" never spoke, the story still managed to be fairly interesting. Especially when you got such big names as voice actors playing cool characters (Frank Vincent from The Sopranos and Goodfellas, Joe Pantoliano from Matrix, Michael Madsen from Reservoir Dogs among other individuals).
+ Radio stations which became a thing in the later games. Not sure if it was first tested in this game but I imagine it was. Great songs available but few though (more on that in the bad section).
+ Hidden packages and side missions that can give you some gameplay advantages if needed and if that's your thing.
+ Some funny dialogues from peds and characters throughout the game, which made me laugh a bit.
+ Gloomy and dark atmosphere which sets the environment perfect for the conversations and tasks you have to do.

Neutral:
+-  A bit unstable when playing over 30 fps as far as I've read over several threads and experienced myself. I've been quite comfortable with the 30 capped fps because of how it doesn't really feel like 30 fps, at least in my own personal experience. You decide yourself if you can play as it is, otherwise there might be fixes for you available that people have manage to create. But I can't say for sure.

Bad:
- Cars blowing up way too fast and too easy. The cars can barely take a beating and so they'll catch fire in a sec after a crash or two.
- Lack of variety of vehicles like in the later games. No bikes, no helicopters and only one sort of plane that you can't really control in a traditional way because of the "learning curve" of managing the plane.
- Claude can't swim. Come on, man. Why you have to be like this?
- Lack of songs on the radio stations. It gets fast repetitive, even with the great songs available unfortunately.


*Will edit this a bit more, so not fully complete

author: {'steamid': '76561198317978226', 'num_games_owned': 14, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 1015, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 803, 'last_played': 1656375024}
review: Its definitely a dated Rockstar title, but my god its mostly all here. A map that copycats most of the major bustling cities in Northern America, fast cars and moderately difficult game-play. My biggest gripe with this game as a child and even today is the water and how it will kill you. This is also incredibly frustrating during a mission when all you can really do is watch your health drain out or load your last saved game. If you hate the swim feature that never made it into this game, I recommend San Andreas. However this games story and missions really show you how far they were willing to push this games engine at the time of release. Great title that captures the classic 3D GTA experience and 2000's culture.

author: {'steamid': '76561199020021216', 'num_games_owned': 116, 'num_reviews': 25, 'playtime_forever': 1200, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 628, 'last_played': 1657684831}
review: This Game Is The Granddaddy Of Open World. Without this your basic af Farcry 5 and Assassin Creeds would not have existed. Similar to every other GTA Game, you try to cause more havoc and piss off the local police who start chasing you in crappy police cars but since they clearly don't know what overkill is, they start pulling up in Tanks and Helicopters. The Story Missions basically are side content because clearly the main thing you should do is Commit massive acts of murder and genocide on the fictional world of Liberty City. I do warn that this game has no f*cking limits and will drive you insane because the last few missions are full of bullsh*t. 9/10 IGN. I also recommend it's incredible Prequel, Grand Theft Auto: Liberty City Stories, which has protagonist Toni Cipriani stare in a much more improved GTA however the water is still heavily polluted so don't try to swim in it unless you like Death.

author: {'steamid': '76561198845555552', 'num_games_owned': 401, 'num_reviews': 28, 'playtime_forever': 2547, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1813, 'last_played': 1637696110}
review:
NOTE: Your experience may be different than mine. I used [url=https://github.com/GTAmodding/re3/]re3[/url], a reverse engineered version of GTA III which makes the game so much better.

[h1]STORY[/h1]

This game, while not having the quality of life improvements the following Rockstar games have, this game is still a blast. The story, while not as big as other games from Rockstar, still has a great story which is still as enjoyable as Red Dead Redemption 2's. The storyline is dark and has amazing writing from Rockstar.

[h1]GAMEPLAY[/h1]

You can't aim and I had to use re3 to look around with the mouse in a vehicle. The Dodo plane, the only plane you can fly, is a chore to control. You can't swim, so getting out of the boats in this game is scary at times, and some missions are so unfair I had to use cheats. Also, the Pay 'n Sprays are not marked on the map so you have to memorize where they are, which aren't hard with the small map of Liberty City. With the negatives out of the way, I love the gameplay. Cars are so fun to use, so are the boats, and the top-down camera calling back to GTA 1 and 2 is a nice feature. Flying tanks are awesome, and the cheats are so fun to use.

[h1]FINAL THOUGHTS[/h1]

This game is one of the best games of all time. With the story and the fun, yet not as easy gameplay, I'm giving this game a 7/10.

author: {'steamid': '76561198077559458', 'num_games_owned': 461, 'num_reviews': 107, 'playtime_forever': 898, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 898, 'last_played': 1625551495}
review:
If you're used to the story-driven characters and high-action gameplay of modern Grand Theft Auto games like IV or V, this is certainly a bit of a shift away. Being Rockstar's first foray into 3D games, the missions here can feel a bit arcade-y at times. You'll have time limits, a lot of missions will involve just you going to a place, or taking a character some place. The missions here can be pretty difficult as the shooting is a bit archaic, and your health drains insanely fast. For a new fan of the GTA series, there are a few annoyances here and there—dying during a mission is a retry with no checkpoints, you lose all of your weapons and have to repurchase, the driving and physics aren't the best.

All of that being said, I enjoyed my time with this game. Once you overlook all of the "errors" of this being a game from 2001, it can be pretty enjoyable and fun. If you're a fan of new GTA who's curious, definitely give it a try. It's not very long, and pretty cheap too; goes on sale often. The entire game took me 15 hours.

Another side note is that this game was designed for Windows XP, and has a bit of trouble running on newer versions of the Windows OS. I highly recommend getting the GTA 3 fixes bundle patch from definitive-edition-project.com. It's easy to install and the game ran without a hitch for me afterwards.

author: {'steamid': '76561198912051973', 'num_games_owned': 47, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 1300, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1300, 'last_played': 1616477765}
review:
GTA 3 was a monumental achievement for video games when it released, today it's still worth playing but buy it as part of the GTA trilogy pack instead of by itself.

This game can be unforgiving compared to the more recent GTA games:
You lose all your weapons when you die
No quick save
No checkpoints within missions
On certain missions the game doesn't give you a specific location to go to

I recommend using YouTube for help with the missions (I used GTA Series Videos), that should help with the overall difficulty.

review: This game, I have in the past played over 11,000 hours and I still love this game. Even though I have not played it in about 8 years. Now I have it again, I am aiming to play it for even longer this time. It is the landmark game that started it all

review:
One of my first games when I just had a PS2 console (2004), this game really makes those memories come back again. I also just finished this game in 1 day uwu

Unfortunately in this PC version there are shortcomings such as some very annoying small bugs, the grapics are not as good as the PS2 (without the graphics mod), very bad POV, and the camera can't be moved freely while in the vechicle (on the PS2 you can).

author: {'steamid': '76561197998649851', 'num_games_owned': 1142, 'num_reviews': 91, 'playtime_forever': 809, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 809, 'last_played': 1625270152}
review:
Did not age well.
Plot is nonsensical and a lot of very good potential is missed out on, some of the more interesting characters do make a comeback, but what was there could have been so much better.

Gameplay (combat and driving) is passable, hard but fair.

AI goes brain dead at times and fails you missions.

Some missions are very poorly explained and the Briefs option in the menu is pretty much the only way to figure out what's happening.

Pedantic mission requirements, such as don't damage the car combined with AI that ACCELERATES when taking turns makes for very frustrating experiences.

author: {'steamid': '76561199070290506', 'num_games_owned': 84, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 1862, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 957, 'last_played': 1639233665}
review:
Here is a list of pros and cons for the game: 
(Keep in mind the game released in 2001 and has aged... sorta well, I guess?)

Pros:
Runs on pretty much anything
Can be quite fun at most times
Killer soundtrack
You get money for causing mayhem (albeit like $5 but still)
Funny NPC dialouge

Cons:
Flipping over a car will cause it to combust
Dying means you lose your weapons and armor
There are no checkpoints or autosaves (but this is fine since the game came out in 2001)

Other than that, the game is fun and great.

author: {'steamid': '76561198257461023', 'num_games_owned': 377, 'num_reviews': 70, 'playtime_forever': 949, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 949, 'last_played': 1625236303}
review:
A classic, another piece of gaming history, the first 3D GTA game that Rockstar Games made.
This game is very nostalgic, I remember playing this game on my old PS2 console. The graphics are okay for a 2001 game, the gameplay mechanic and physics is very clunky (well, this is a 20-year-old game), Some missions are repetitive, so sometimes you will get bored with it. You can make the game more stable and beautiful with community patches and mods, available in the guides section on steam, or you can google it by yourself.
Overall, I give this game 8/10 for the score, I definitely recommend this game if you love open world games, or just a fan of the GTA series.

author: {'steamid': '76561198354625537', 'num_games_owned': 58, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 427, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 403, 'last_played': 1625069463}
review: gta iii

author: {'steamid': '76561197996152191', 'num_games_owned': 1556, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 863, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 424, 'last_played': 1625190414}
review:
It's a piece of gaming history...but not all history needs to be revisited. 

In 2002, this was a revelation.
In 2021 it's an example of just how much things have evolved since.

Even with community patches and mods, it's still not aged that well. Go play Vice City or San Andreas instead if you want the old-school GTA experience before Niko and GTAV.

author: {'steamid': '76561198222733796', 'num_games_owned': 10, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 518, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 183, 'last_played': 1625540710}

author: {'steamid': '76561198092667528', 'num_games_owned': 281, 'num_reviews': 56, 'playtime_forever': 2090, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1091, 'last_played': 1667971066}
review:
This review is written / typed by Jiggly Roberta's Wife.

I was really looking forward to playing GTA III after playing a little bit of GTA IV and enjoyed it for what it is. Unfortunately this is pretty much a product of it's time and is extremely hard. There is still some enjoyment to be had here, though I'd say it's only for hardcore GTA fans. 

The beginning starts off great. The Atmosphere and Cityscape is fantastic, but by mid-game GTA III begins to dwindle in quality. Missions become extremely tedious and revolves around luck more than skill. Seriously, having a mission were certain NPC's die for no reason or a certain car that's critical for a mission blowing up for no godd*mn reason is a complete mission restart. Any slight screw up and it's a complete mission restart. Not going in the direction that the developers intended you to go but doesn't tell you, a complete mission restart. Going down a street and have some rando blow your car up with a shotgun and kills you during a mission. Guess what now? That's right, a complete mission restart.

There's no telling how many times I felt like ripping my tits off or finding a way to literally Fu*k Myself for how frustrating and hard these missions are in this game. If you're looking to play this game after playing something like GTA IV or V, be prepared to die a lot and be doing a lot of mission restarts.

I would only recommend this game to die-hard fans of the GTA series.

As for newcomers, I would say give GTA III a pass and either play Vice City or San Andreas instead. If you like either one of these games, then you can probably give GTA III a try.

EDIT: After the initial releases of the GTA Remasters or the "Grand Theft Auto: The Trilogy" – """""The Definitive Edition""""". The original PC or PS2 versions are sadly better than the Remaster. Get the originals instead ~ https://www.ebay.com/b/Grand-Theft-Auto-3/139973/bn_7364865

author: {'steamid': '76561199049996818', 'num_games_owned': 53, 'num_reviews': 20, 'playtime_forever': 294, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 176, 'last_played': 1657479851}

author: {'steamid': '76561198275544766', 'num_games_owned': 168, 'num_reviews': 34, 'playtime_forever': 883, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 862, 'last_played': 1625076870}
review: A classic. I was blown away by how much you could do in this game back when I played it for the first time on PS2. I love the blocky lego cars and the cartoony stylized visuals to this game. The comedy writing and voice acting is still as golden as ever. But all that aside, the gameplay has some really frustrating parts that did not age as well. The physics and combat are atrocious at times, making the latter half of the game a slog to get through. Eventually the missions become so long and repetitive that they are not fun anymore, but you need to beat them to progress on to other parts of the map, so you just repeat them over and over until you can execute them 100% perfectly. Otherwise you fail, lose all your weapons, and start over. This game is still a classic, but is probably not the most fun of the PS2 generation of GTA games.

review:
Even though this is a father to all GTA games it aged very poorly.  Lot's of bugs , glitches, annoying mechanics, half-assed, incoherent plot and uninteresting main protagonist. Probably the worst aim I ever seen in a video game and an M16 rifle which can shoot 60 bullets in 0.2 seconds. Worst of all, NO MAP and plenty of missions which really need it to actually enjoy the game.

No wonder I couldn't finish it 20 years ago.

review: It's the most primitive of the oldest 3D GTA games due to it being the first, but it gains an atmosphere from its blocky, sharp-angled turn-of-the-millenium era grittiness. The protagonist is a true nominal hero, the characters distant and mysterious, if not just plain weird, the mechanics of most staple things to do in the franchise at its most unrefined. More than a piece of history, it's a really good game on its own terms.

author: {'steamid': '76561199103005368', 'num_games_owned': 38, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 2757, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1740, 'last_played': 1658878770}
review:
While yes this game is the reason the concept of Open World games is what it is today, i have to say that 21 years later i didn't have much fun with Grand Theft Auto III. 

POSITIVES:
- Gameplay is pretty fun. If you're not doing any missions you can waste time killing peds/cops and blowing up helicopters until the army shows up. Those M16's drop your health from 100 to 0 in a matter of 3 seconds. So much so that the community never realized they had dialogue simply because of how quickly they gun you down.
-Soundtrack is my top favorite element of this game. Listening to radio stations like Lips 106, Head Radio & Double Cleff FM give me Season 1 Sopranos vibes, especially driving through Little Italy. By far my favorite radio station has to be hands down MSX FM. Thanks to this station my love for Drum & Bass from the early 2000's has been within me to this day. 
- Driving through Liberty City feels nice but mostly during daytime. My favorite districts have to be Portland & Staunton. Portland being a small commune area where most activities is dock working, construction in the suburbs and the red light district where things tend to go interestingly discreet. 
- Voice acting is superb. For 2001 the performance of the famous actor like Michael Madsen, Frank Vincent, Michael Rapaport and other did an amazing job portaying their respective characters despite the mission cutscenes being short & to the point. 

NEGATIVES:
- The plot of Grand Theft Auto III doesn't feel much like a story worth going after. It's just a small revenge story that doesn't go anywhere until way later in the game when Catalina makes very small appearances and. Everything else is just the classic formula from the first two Grand Theft Auto Games. Meet this guy, do this job, mission complete. The only difference is that in GTA 1 & 2 your bosses are mostly giving you missions through payphones whereas in III you meet them in person instead through the cutscenes. The ending is pretty mixed. Catalina's death wasn't much to remember just blow up her helicopter. I did like the relaxing tune as the news reports the events of the final mission. However i never understood what the hell happened to Maria? Did Claude kill her for being annoying? or as the rumors say it was an audio oopsie from Rockstar's part?

- Many of the missions are incredibly difficult and/or just a waste of time. A big portion of the game's missions are time based and it's really annoying since you have to worry about not making any mistakes otherwise game over. On the wasting time part, the first mission for Ray Machowski is Claude driving in circles all over staunton picking up payphones before you hear Ray's stupid audio recorder to pick up yet another phone. Until he eventually tells you where to meet him. Wouldn't it be easier if Claude could just do a big favor for Ray that way he could've earned his trust? That was the stupidest mission in the game. I read that the reason why these missions were so difficult was because of gameplay padding. I'm glad this isn't the case anymore. 

-Police AI is all over the place. This is another thing that made missions very difficult for me in this game. It seems the LCPD consists of human officers with the mentality of a raging bull. They may ride around in small cruisers, but i swear those lame cop cars are just as fast if not faster that a cheetah. One bump of a police car and you'll be sent spinning around the road and either end up in the ocean or your vehicle flipped over exploding in the process. 

I understand that without this game all the other installments in the series wouldn't have existed along with other similar games like Saints Row, however this game simply didn't age well and it's difficulty really drove me away from it. As soon as I completed the story and the side missions I had no reason to come back to it. 

5/10
I would've added a mixed reccomendation, but steam only offers yes and no. it's not the worst game but it's more of a relic of the past.

author: {'steamid': '76561198119812424', 'num_games_owned': 1390, 'num_reviews': 57, 'playtime_forever': 617, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 617, 'last_played': 1621881038}
review:
(This is my second playthrough) For the most part it holds up well. graphics aren't the worst and considering when the game released they look pretty good! Some quality of life features appear in the later games, so missing out on those kind of sucked. For example, an in game map. The last 3 story missions I found difficult because everyone just shoots at you on sight. Overall though it was a good game for its time.

Likes

story
gameplay (for the most part)
ahead of its time

Dislikes:

the last 4 missions
no checkpoints
no in game map
the fact that i have to drive all the way back to my safe house to save
cops are intense
it was on sight when people saw me mid way through the game.

Rating: 6/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198109049195', 'num_games_owned': 571, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 125, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 125, 'last_played': 1623301238}
review:
Ok so i got this escort mission; the objective was to escort 3 low poly dudes to a location using a limousine. As soon as i picked the last dude up there were 4 or 5 enemy vans out of nowhere and they started shooting and driving towards me at REALLY HIGH SPEEDS THAT ANY VAN SHOULD NOT BE ABLE TO REACH. In a fraction of a second i found myself stuck in a corner getting jammed by these vans. Shortly afterwards i fell off the map and got teleported to a safe location and finished my escort mission without having to kill any innocent dudes. 

10/10 do not mess with your memories.
