author: {'steamid': '76561197974146135', 'num_games_owned': 657, 'num_reviews': 109, 'playtime_forever': 944, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 944, 'last_played': 1604248025}
review:
I was a big fan of GTA 2 back then, and it was a big surprise when GTA3 was released. I had immediately bought the disc and played the game. It reminded me of GTA2: the mute main character, style, driving, radios. At the same time everything was on the new scale: 3D, music, hits, the solid story line. I was disappointed that no story was continued from the second game, I couldn't see Zaibatsu again (except a commercial). However, overall impression was positive.

After many, MANY years, more then 19, I played again with the graphics upgrade pack.

Well. Let's compare the reviews.

Me, teenager.

Pros.:
- Awesome music. Especially RISE FM.
- Sniper rifle. LOVE IT!
- Driving, can steal any car, drive sport cards, some of them remind of GTA2 (Yakuza stinger).
- The story is so cool!
- Very sad to finish the game. I tried to finish all the missions but... Whatever. I finished.
- I just like to drive around the city!

Cons.:
- Some missions are hard, had to replay over and over again. That goddamn truck and Colombian mafia trying to destroy it.
- Goddamn airplane mission when you need to find the boat. I almost destroyed my keyboard.
- That's it I think.

Me. 2020.

Pros.:
- Music, Rise FM.
- Versatility of finishing some missions.
- Different ways of reaching parts of the city (tunnel or bridges).
- More weapons, more missions, more characters. Characters are memorable. Even though some of them are not really recognizable from the concept arts.
- The opening and ending theme. Attaching and fulfilling.
- The attempt to add some cinematography into the game. It's not a complete attraction like GTA2, full of shits and giggles. It's more serious. Even though some missions are fun, posters (Bad Fellas, for example). All these references to pop culture and movies (the Godfather, Reservoir Dogs, etc.).
- The system of hidden packages. The more you get, the better default equipment you have near the hideout. PRICELESS! You should plan the game play. AGAIN.

Cons.:
- Overbuffed Italian mafia with their shotguns. But it may be a cons, because you have to PLAN how to play. For example, finish side missions first.
- I miss that system of gang reputation from the second game. If you kill other gang members, you may restore the reputation.
- I REALLY MISS ZAIBATSU NOW.
- The music tracks is very VERY limited. I ended up listening to nothing, because I have heard it all.
- The graphics look awful. The game is dull. Physics are OK, but the details. The game required more details I suppose.
- The story is quite short. And characters are not that attaching. It was fixed in Vice City I guess.
- No bikes.
- No fucken swimming. It's ridiculous.
- There should be payment for the hideout. Like in GTA2. Of course, the shittier, the cheaper.

Anyways. THE GAME IS A LEGEND! I will show it to my kids. Or nieces and nephews.

author: {'steamid': '76561197972100492', 'num_games_owned': 380, 'num_reviews': 125, 'playtime_forever': 799, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 799, 'last_played': 1603903417}
review:
Never manage to complete the GTA III back in 2001, due to a slow computer and and poor 3dfx card. So after 19+ year I have final manage to come beat the game. However the steam version is almost unplayable, but with a few mods from the community can fix this issue. Sadly I will not recommend this game due to the crappy ported version. 

Pros:
- Fair open world
- Great soundtrack
- Female antagonist

Cons:
- Short campaign
- No minimap
- Horrible optimized
- Various technical issues
- Horrible optimized
- Performance Isssue
- Terrible mechanics

review: Definitely a historic video game. If you're a younger gamer, you definitely need to go through the experience of playing Grand Theft Auto III. If you're a seasoned player, this game is full of nostalgia. The radio stations are full of personality, the missions make an effort to be unique, but they can be difficult sometimes because of the clunky camera & gameplay. All that aside, it's hours of fun!

author: {'steamid': '76561198819809717', 'num_games_owned': 115, 'num_reviews': 53, 'playtime_forever': 136, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 100, 'last_played': 1666652783}
review: GTA 3 is where it all started and it's a classic but out of the classic gta trilogy it definitely holds up the worst. Can be severely difficult and unforgiving at times, the characters are the most cardboard by far and the story/cutscenes can be quite weak. There also isn't a whole lot to do outside of missions also but all in all it's still a fun game and it's rich in nostalgia. The dark, murky, comic book version of liberty city can't be matched and it's got Guru from Gang Starr too!

author: {'steamid': '76561198020225761', 'num_games_owned': 1554, 'num_reviews': 131, 'playtime_forever': 2616, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2616, 'last_played': 1561153651}
review:
If you never played the very first GTA - you have no idea what release of GTA3 meant for us all almost 20 years ago. It was something unimaginable. It was not just something revolutionary in genre. Without any exaggerations it will be fair enough to say that this game was industry-changing phenomenon. There was nothing like this before. Not even close. Only Mafia, which was released later that year, came close enough to be called a worthy competitor. Unfortunately Mafia didn't get as much attention and had another priorities in general. In Mafia most attention was payed to the story, atmosphere of gangster movie and realism, while in GTA3 open word itself was the key feature.

I'm going to describe that time period in details, so if you want to hear the rest - make sure you've got a big cup of tea. The story will be long, and it even has a plot twist. Man, how many lessons were skipped, how many exams were failed, how many once happy and serene families were ruined by this game... Poor parents were searching all local computer clubs, in desperate attempts to find their brainless brats, who abandoned study and wasted last money to spend there days and nights without sleep. People really lost their mind about this game. Back then it even overshadowed CS 1.3 (wink). It was a common thing to enter a computer club and to see a bunch of totally immobile kids (like if they were glued to their seats) who totally lost count of time playing GTA3 and staring into the monitors with absolutely blank eyes. Sweet memories...

And just to let you know, computer clubs of the past had nothing in common with modern clean and quiet Internet or WI-FI cafes. Inside, many of them were rather dirty and had rather dense stench of cheap alcohol, bad tobacco and unwashed bodies. Entering some of them was like entering some cyberpunk reality, because those places were rather, lets say, spicy. They attracted "elite" from the very bottom of society who were openly trading with, hmm, all sorts of unconventional stuff. Thus, parents could rest assured that their kids are in reliable hands, hehe.

You are still on board? - Very well. Because here comes another touching passage about my acquaintance with GTA franchise, before I'll head for the conclusions about GTA3... Cold autumn of 1997. A friend of mine brought me a bunch of his discs with video games. One and a half dozen or so. Why? Da hell I know. I tried to remember but nothing substantive comes to my mind. So, what are those games? - garbage (it may partially explain my friend's generosity as well). It didn't take much time for me to put them into this cathegory. 

In this pile of trash, one game specifically grabbed my attention. Why? Because among all this garbage, this one looked even worse than garbage: broken box inside and outside, broken plastic, frontal screen was torn and dirty as if he wiped something with it... [i] what if he indeed did?!! [/i]... and depicted some low-res drunkman with a crowbar in some archaic glasses. Oh, by the way, the disc itself was full of scratches as well. So I tried to read some illegible description... dma design (nothing ringed the bell - probably developers?)... steal cars, shoot stuff, bla-bla... oh! the game's name - Grandfather Auto?... what the hell, sounds stupid - let me check it. Launched the game - ah, so that's Grand Theft Auto!

It turned out that the game was a blast. I spent maybe a week before I bothered to check the first mission, coz all this time I was just driving and shooting stuff while listening cool music. Stupid or not, but I had a lot of fun playing like that. Later on I started to fulfill actual missions, discovered paint workshops, secrets, hidden missions - great and unique experience for those times. 

Year after year, 2002nd has arrived. And GTA3 was released. And something unimaginable happend. Total disaster. The end of the world was at hand - my PC could not run GTA3... Are you crying with me? Incurable wound was inflicted and despair was absolute. Thus, I found salvation in the arms of Mafia. Mafia... worked on my PC.

Outcome is close, so check your belts... A year later I got top PC. The time has come to get what I was denied before. And GTA3 was №1 on my revenge list. So I played it. And I had some fun. But... nothing mindblowing. Incurable, as it seemed before, wound was healed and such a prominent game in gaming industry almost left me indifferent. I didn't even finish the game. "WOW effect" didn't happen. Now you understand why I was so sarcastic about those kids and their parents? Coz I wasn't a participant in all that GTA3 madness - I was merely a spectator. And such anticlimatic is the end of my story. 

Epilogue. Almost 2 decades later I decided to come back to GTA3. And this time I finally finished it and even got 100%. It seems like this time I even got more fun than years ago. Definitely great product of it's time. If you never played it, but at least played San Andreas (they share many similar mechanics) - you may check it. But if you started you acquaintance with francise from GTA4 - I have serious doubts that it will impress you anyhow.

Well, this story is not a Schindler's list, but thanks to everyone who stayed to the very end. I hope you had some fun reading this mess or at least it helped you to fall asleep faster.

author: {'steamid': '76561198129704221', 'num_games_owned': 124, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 485, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 304, 'last_played': 1631413731}
review: This game has aged about as gracefully as an egg in a cup. The physics are broken, the gunplay is inaccurate and finicky without the use of mods, the sound design makes Burzum sound like Phil Spector, the characters all look they've got serious problems, the pacing is all over the place, the missions themselves are tedious and repetitive, a lot of the humour no longer packs a punch... But Rise FM is still the best radio station featured in any video game ever and you can fly a tank with more precision than you can fly an actual plane. A true classic, immeasurably broken, but shining regardless.

author: {'steamid': '76561198974477250', 'num_games_owned': 104, 'num_reviews': 154, 'playtime_forever': 1002, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 900, 'last_played': 1609774810}
review:
GTA 3.

Should i recommend it ? I obviously have no idea because rockstar aint fixin their broke ass game.

I had to download several files in order to fix the game and make it work properly, for some reason rockstar took down several HD texture packs, or the owners deleted it.

I tried to download the multiplayer, however there is no servers available.. even tho several people said that they still play this game.

I got a texture pack, i downloaded it and then my save file got messed up, i wasted 15 hours of my life just for this game, i wont be able to get those hours again, so do NOT download any mods, you wont be able to fix your file no matter what you do, i tried everything that i can.

Overall, this game was really hated for some reason which i'm not gonna be stating here because i'm not entirely sure why people hated this game at the time.

The game is alright, all you need to do is download a few files because for like the physics, the menu being broken, etc.

Resolution is broken, i had to download another file for that.

The characters sometimes look dead, the cars are fast as hell now.

I wont be downloading this game again because of the fact that it gets broken easily just with a mod, smh.

In conclusion, Gta 3 is not supported anymore, and its broken so Rockstar wont be doing anything about it so... I'll give it a 6/10.

Yeah, i do recommend it i guess, i'm sad bcs of the fact that i couldnt complete the game, but i'll let it stay on my library and still count it as ''Completed'' because of this dumb reason.

author: {'steamid': '76561198171128490', 'num_games_owned': 65, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 3511, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3511, 'last_played': 1598039260}
review: The game ran smoothly on my 1080ti, Mick Gordon's soundtrack was absolutely phenomenal, gave me an adrenaline rush during intense firefights, glory kills were satisfying, and the game encouraged you to change your style of play whenever certain enemies appeared or if you run out of ammo (which happens frequently). If you're a fan of Doom or a fan of fps games (casual or not) I would highly recommend it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198099074028', 'num_games_owned': 1053, 'num_reviews': 104, 'playtime_forever': 1750, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1394, 'last_played': 1645598548}
review:
MAKE SURE YOU HAVE THE SILENT PATCH.
https://gtaforums.com/topic/669045-silentpatch/
I recommend also getting the enhanced edition mods if you want to make this game feel newer, however it's not necessary.

This game is a blast to play and it does have it's awesome moments, though I wouldn't recommend this if you are easily tilted. Game is hard and likes to be unfair, but if you get over all that you'll have a really nice game in your hands.

It does have it's own share of fun glitches you can try and the soundtrack is pretty damn good.
Also did I mention this is also the only GTA game you can shoot people's limbs off in? Yeah, has it's own features still not present in the newer games.

Story missions are plenty but can get really frustrating, the ending mission being the hardest.

If you want a game that captures the 2002 atmosphere, this game is just for you.

author: {'steamid': '76561198245965924', 'num_games_owned': 737, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 304, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 23, 'last_played': 1608248855}
review:
[i][u]A game in which you regain your life by having sex with prostitutes, cannot fail to be recommended.[/u][/i]

author: {'steamid': '76561197969749884', 'num_games_owned': 2328, 'num_reviews': 1422, 'playtime_forever': 50180, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 50180, 'last_played': 1599493641}
review:
GTA3 is basically the game which most massively influenced if not even started the entire era of open world games.

Looking back almost twenty years, it's still a great game, but it has aged quite terribly both visually as well as mechanically. Especially the controls have become abysmal by today's standards, even although they can be modded to become somewhat palatable.

Personally I still enjoyed giving this another extensive spin about 15 years after I last played it, but it might not be for everyone, because massive nostalgia goggles were involved.

All the same, this is a milestone of gaming history. Only Vice City deserves even more praise.

review: One of my favourite games growing up. Shame it's a broken product on Steam. None of the fixes I tried work and you can't get past the main menu. Spent two hours trying to get it to run. Please don't bother telling me "if you try this fix on page 13 of this basket weaving forum" it will work, nothing worked. Downloading fix bundles, editing files, editing shortcuts, compatibility modes, none of it. Don't waste your money. Valve has once again sold a product that does not work and it's just a matter of time before the financial authorities get their act together.

author: {'steamid': '76561198304787035', 'num_games_owned': 498, 'num_reviews': 20, 'playtime_forever': 784, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 784, 'last_played': 1598052043}
review:
The game that defined a genre, has actually... gotten pretty old.

Clunky mechanics, instant deaths that come out of nowhere, bad saving system, really short, bad acting, just pseudoinformative cut scenes (also your character doesn't talk so it's like you are this freaking mute maniac that kills everybody for money), and a story that started interesting but with a finale that doesn't really fill up anything.

It's still worth playing for the saga, and understanding how these games evolved. It also includes a good soundtrack, laughable moments and the radio broadcasts are just perfect.

author: {'steamid': '76561198155410155', 'num_games_owned': 147, 'num_reviews': 31, 'playtime_forever': 3653, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3514, 'last_played': 1655365630}
review:
THIS GAME IS NOT OPTIMIZED FOR WINDOWS 10. However it is still playable. 

Rockstar added this "Frame Limiter" option which allows you to get 60+ frames, but this doesn't work properly. All it does is speed up the game and there are other bugs that come with it like i was sprinting and my character leaped forward 30 metres ahead. So its best to play it with Frame Limiter ON if you don't want that happening to you. Your game might not even run properly if you have Frame Limiter set to OFF.
Rockstar needs to remake these old games because technology has changed, they never did that. And also because fans have connected so much with the Rockstar characters that they want to see them again in future games. They're supposed to put out remakes or sequels by now, but eh, I guess they don't care about the fans.

Plus this is a bad game lol. I mean it sucks. THE CONTROLS SUCK. It's a bad game, but I have memories of it (nostalgia) so I enjoy re-playing it. But if it's your first time playing it, I doubt you'll have much fun. Do you really think a game from 2001 will beat a game from the current era? It may have been a good game to buy when it came out and you may have a high opinion of it cuz this was one of the best game in those days, but now better games have come out. Same goes for Vice City and San Andreas. Once you play GTA V or Red Dead Redemption 2, which are mechanically better games, you cannot go back. Do yourself a favor though unless you're going to make content (YouTube or Twitch) out of this game and unless you've never played it before, buy a new (recent) game, you'll enjoy it way more.

author: {'steamid': '76561198017960107', 'num_games_owned': 1185, 'num_reviews': 21, 'playtime_forever': 81, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 41, 'last_played': 1627170533}
review:
It's a classic. Too bad Rockstar doesn't seem interested in preserving classic games and with all their Sharkcard money can't be bothered to patch this one, so for the best experience this requires 3rd party fixes and mods. Not unplayable but for me that earns games an instant No in terms of Steam recommendations for games still being sold.

If the vanilla game starts on a modern Windows OS without issues, the main menu will probably break anyway, so you'll need to try to workaround with switching to the Steam overlay and back to make the text visible to even get into the settings and change the resolution.

High resolutions like 3840x2160 work surprisingly well, the HUD scales relatively well. But even though there's a widescreen option you'll need a 3rd party fix to avoid the image getting vertically squished. Make also sure you have Trails disabled - to avoid motion sickness - and Frame Limiter enabled to avoid physics/controls breaking (such as walking on inclines or cars being unable coast or reverse anymore).

Other vanilla restrictions include severe pop-in of pedestrians and cars and missing/broken lighting/reflections.

Refer to https://www.pcgamingwiki.com/wiki/Grand_Theft_Auto_III for fixes.

author: {'steamid': '76561198826019739', 'num_games_owned': 118, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 16584, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 187, 'last_played': 1675450757}
review:
Grand Theft Auto III is a classic. I used to play this game as a teen & loved it then! I decided to buy it again on Steam. It's an excellent game & essentially put open world games on the map. It has a great story, parodying popular Mafia movies with a great sense of humour, the kind that would be so familiar to other games of the franchise, along with an amazing sound track of the early 1990's & early 2000's. It's full of action, & hours of addicting gameplay that would keep you in Liberty City for a good long time.

Some criticisms are that it was made in a time when people were still figuring out how to produce a good 3D game, so the controls are a little tough to handle. It's hard to jump over obstacles, driving is a little stiffer than the later GTA games as well. You do eventually get used to all of the controls, but it's tough if you're used to the later games, then try GTA III. The subject matter is obviously controversial too, the game is named after a Felony, but if you like R rated Action movies & Mafia movies, you'll know what you're getting yourself into.

Overall, I highly recommend this game, just like any of the other GTA games. It's great fun & if you like action, fast cars, open world, mobs & gangsters, I can just about guarantee that you'll love this game!

author: {'steamid': '76561198237680528', 'num_games_owned': 725, 'num_reviews': 147, 'playtime_forever': 162, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 22, 'last_played': 1617052943}
review:
This is the game that started it all.

Grand Theft Auto III is the perfect example of a groundbreaking title that still is just as enjoyable. Arguably the most controversial game of 2001 and the first massive success in the video game industry of a post 9/11 world, GTA III is a game about revenge, murder and chaos. Set in the fictional New York-inspired Liberty City, you take control of a mute named Claude. He and his girlfriend Catalina are escaping from a bank heist when she turns on Claude, shooting him and leaving him on the ground for the police to find minutes later. A few days later while on a transfer to the city's detention centre a car intervenes with the convoy and frees the prisoners while also managing to destroy the bridge the event took place on.

The game contains a great open world that was extremely impressive back in the year of release. It has a good story but admittedly it's not very in-depth. The soundtrack is full of fantastic songs from the main theme's relaxing piano to the various radio stations filled with a selection of liscensed and original tracks. The graphics are still pretty decent by today's standards but the character models have not aged that well. There is oodles of activities and situations to get yourself into in Liberty City.

Overal this game is a masterpiece that will keep you playing for a long time and it's something I can reccomend even to detractors of the sandbox genre.

author: {'steamid': '76561198044659970', 'num_games_owned': 128, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 3018, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1996, 'last_played': 1624047947}
review:
Just finished Grand Theft Auto III, what a wild ride! 

The year 2001 was one of the pinnacles of video game history, celebrating many awesome games from my favorite series growing up such as Sonic Adventure 2, Super Smash Bros. Melee, Final Fantasy X, Devil May Cry 1, Grand Theft Auto III, Zone of the Enders, Project Justice, Megaman X5&6, the first Jak and Daxter, Klonoa 2, and so on! I enjoy a variety of video game genres and different storytelling mediums and themes. And GTA3 is absolutely one of those games that the year deserved to celebrate. Despite not taking off at its first sights during E3, it skyrocketed commercially, and that's what truly matters!

Taking on the role of Claude; a silent hitman who is portrayed as a clueless killer that's meant to be played with through your own personal perception of whether he was a psychopathic killer, or an anti-hero who deserved the vengeance he was seeking post-betrayal, and this makes everything even better. Rockstar is a game development team that was not afraid of taking risks, so they evolved the series into the third dimension; which would become the game a majority of gamers love today, with an awesome community dedicated to the series that always discover new things about the games as well as creating mods for them. Top-down games are certainly classics that I do not neglect as a fan of retro games, however, the series needed a tone that's more than what would be a game that you'd play at your local arcade. It became a cinematic interactive game that you direct on your own as the player, and that's what made the series unique. The hitbox does certainly show it's age, and the same goes for the damage factor towards the player, but if you work yourself around these things, it's a blast to play, and a technical marvel that you have to experience!

author: {'steamid': '76561198029043851', 'num_games_owned': 146, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 500, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 462, 'last_played': 1672140284}
review: What can I say? This game is my childhood and I got too much good memories with it to diss it, but here comes. I think it's a shame rockstar games don't take time to update their old games. What this game needs is support to 60fps and hd textures that came with the 10 year anniversary edition for mobiles. I know it's possible to upgrade those features with mods but I can't help but think what could be possible if those upgrades came straight from rockstar. Anyway this game is a must play for those familiar with gta series but haven't played this. Storyline is addictive and gameplay is immersive for its age. It's the same gameplay we have grown to love with newer installments of gta. Of course we are talking about THE gta that changed it all when it came out with it's 3d graphics and immersive gameplay that we are so used to nowadays.

author: {'steamid': '76561198191784031', 'num_games_owned': 79, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 3712, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 979, 'last_played': 1624158348}
review:
I have played this game before and I didn't really enjoy it. I played all the other games in the series after this game and I enjoyed all of them. When I initially wrote my previous review, which I will leave attached at the bottom, I was p***ed about this game's content and design. I swore to myself that I wouldn't play this game again.
A year goes by and I decided to play the game again. 
Big. Mistake.
I delusionally thought that my issues about the game would be fixed by taking the time to get all the pickups and it would make the game easier.
It didn't.
I thought it would be a cool idea to get 100% in this game.
It wasn't. My blood pressure achieved new heights that would kill an elephant. 
I spent so much time playing this forsaken game that I actually think I hate it more than I did before. How in the h*** did 75% of this game get approved by Rockstar's quality division? I can't name a single instance where this game had an appropriate difficulty, even the first missions were difficult beyond compare. The missions are not capable of being done using anything, not even a f***ing controller or keyboard. The cars in this game somehow are worse than the other 3D games and even harder to control than GTA IV -- which was purposefully made difficult to control. The more I played this game the more I realized that this story sucks, there is absolutely nothing to this game other than useless drivel. 
I think I would have more fun passing a kidney stone than I ever did with this game.
Heed my warning: This game is s***. If I could rate this worse, I would do it in a heartbeat. Don't play this game.

Old review:
I got this game when I purchased Vice City and San Andreas because it was cheaper to buy the package deal than just the two other games. Since this was the first 3D era game I was not expecting the game to be like the Grand Theft Auto V. I have several problems with this game. The first is the keyboard controls are janky that one would require the growth of at least three more fingers and another hand in order to play this game properly. With this problem, I turned to my trusty Xbox 1 controller, and this is where problem two came. In order to play with my controller I NEEDED TO DOWNLOAD A MOD FOR IT. The controller setup was left at whatever it was for when the game was first released in 2002 or whenever it was. My third problem is the story is garbage. The story was not compelling whatsoever and whatever poor Claude did people seemed to get pissed off at him, despite the mute bastard doing exactly what they asked. My fourth problem is Claude DOESN'T KNOW HOW TO SWIM. He is so afraid of water that if he just touches it with his leg he dies, and that complicates things when you need to use boats for missions. That brings me to my next problem: some of the missions are so difficult that I barely finished them before suffering from a stroke because my blood pressure was so high. Speaking of rage and frustration, the cars in this game have the equivalent control of a TOY CAR. I would be driving the Securicar, one of the heaviest and most difficult cars to tip and the police are able to touch me and send that thing flying further than one can throw a baseball. 
The game design is so impeccable that I cannot find a modicum of bad things that this game has wrong. NOT. I wasted sixteen hours playing this dumpster fire of a game and meanwhile suffering from early 2000's game design. Take my advice and don't buy this game, even if it comes in that bundle with Vice City and San Andreas.

review:
Reviewing games I played a long time ago:

It was a complete revolution and I was gobsmacked when first saw and played GTA in full 3D, I didn't think it was possible to do such a thing in this scale at that time. I spent hundreds of hours in Liberty City to a point that I can still, more or less, draw a map of the city. It was also one of the first games I spend in modding, I still remember just cruising the city in a Peugeot 205 GTI, I was completely floored at the time. This version still works fine in modern PCs.

review: Between the motion blur, random cars especially cops acting like they're at the indy 500 as they cartwheel down central roads, randomly echoed voices calling you a r*tard every 10 minutes, cars randomly exploding every 30 seconds, a radio that sounds like someone calling you from club playing euro hip hop through a nokia phone, and helicopters that will either ghost through or fly directly into buildings, it is easily the most chaotic game I have ever played. I cannot believe I am not playing gta online, I don't know how they got the npcs to copy human behaviour that well.

author: {'steamid': '76561198070745882', 'num_games_owned': 122, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 2238, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1450, 'last_played': 1638707942}
review: [i]Grand Theft Auto III[/i], also known as [i]Fight 2001 Game Design and Lose Every Time[/i], is a wonderful, confusing open world game that set the blueprint for its' successors. You will cry in anguish, as you try to beat the most unforgiving missions for the [i]nth[/i] time, as you realise that all of them don't even compare to the hardest of them all - 🚑. Also, make sure to have galaxy brain level foresight to know that you have to beat the side-missions right at the beginning of the game, or else you will NOT reach 100%. Spare yourself the trouble. Do not resist. Do not struggle. Forget what you know about playing open world games. And do not play this game without patches.

author: {'steamid': '76561198040889378', 'num_games_owned': 261, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 1927, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1927, 'last_played': 1534810894}
review:
This was one of the first games I've played when I got my first PC. Back then I thought how hard was it cause each time I failed at that mission where you need to kill all the bad guys on the ship so your friend can plant the bomb there and detonate it xD

Now, this game is always in my mind. I pushed it to the limit and completed all missions required for 100% completion. It's shame that in GTA iV there are no ambulance missions and no other bonus health/armor features. 

I also need to mention how GOOD radio stations are here. Head radio, LIPS One-O-Six (106) are my favorites and honestly I've added some songs from them to my spotify. Shooting is really hard in this game. Also, some rampages on the 3rd island are like really hard to do, so this game both fun and competitive ;) 

If you played GTA IV or GTA V and you've never played this game - get it, you're missing a lot. Also it's kind of cool to know how GTA series progressed throughout these years!

author: {'steamid': '76561198018874642', 'num_games_owned': 826, 'num_reviews': 24, 'playtime_forever': 813, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 812, 'last_played': 1594343194}
review:
I didn't play this when it came out, so I have no nostalgia for it.  And let me tell you, nostalgia is about the only thing to commend this game.  Yes, it was 2001.  Yes, a lot of modern features hadn't yet become the standard.  Yes, its last iteration was top-down and they hadn't done a 3D game yet.  That doesn't mean that it's fun to play.  I suspect I wouldn't have enjoyed it back in the day, either.

This is a third-person shooter, so the fact that the shooting is terribly, terribly painful is  a problem.  The game seems to think it's Unreal, but the actual mechanics seem to think it's KOTOR.  Would you like to shoot enemies in the head?  Would you like to hit enemies at all?  Well, you can go to hell.  You're not in control.  Claude is in control.  And Claude aims like Michael J. Fox.

Medal of Honor, Half-Life, Jedi Knight, Megaman Legends...decent shooting mechanics already existed.  There's no excuse for GTA3's shooting to be this bad.

author: {'steamid': '76561198255517258', 'num_games_owned': 23, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 670, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 391, 'last_played': 1594407019}
review:
I would like to give a proper review, but to do that I would have had to actually played the game! It says 6 hours playtime, but the game says "running" and did nothing...for 6 hours!!
During this time,  I've rebooted, applied the "Silentpatch" etc, and still not running.
My PC spec could run this game in its sleep, so I don't think there's an issue there. 
I usually like the robustness of Steam and the Support, but they let me down on this title, by advising they don't and won't support it and they won't give a refund because the game "has been played for more than 2 hours"!
Buyer beware,
I'm glad I only paid £6 for this.

author: {'steamid': '76561198139271741', 'num_games_owned': 1141, 'num_reviews': 60, 'playtime_forever': 1303, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1303, 'last_played': 1595059465}
review:
Maybe this game was decent for its time, but it does NOT hold up today. For an "open-world" game, it is shockingly linear in how it lets you tackle missions. Planting bombs in cars is a totally useless feature, since for missions where you need to assassinate someone, their car just so happens to be locked. Doing certain tasks out of order will just fail the mission outright, even though the cutscene itself explains what the overall mission goal is (ex: you need to lead someone into an ambush so the yakuza can kill them, but if you kill them yourself outside of that ambush, the mission fails). Also, the general lack of QoL features will really turn people off. There's no full map, despite having the entire city minimapped, which makes certain objectives that take place across the entire city frustrating to drive through. And not only are there no mission checkpoints. not only do they not allow you to restart the mission from the start when you fail, but they don't even allow you to load a save from the game menu, meaning if you want to restart a mission without losing all the money and weapons you lost from dying, then you have to exit the game completely, relaunch it from Steam, and THEN you can play the mission again. 

Why are so many GTA games like this? Why do they have good gameplay outside of missions, but when it comes to the actual story of the game, the "open" part of "open-world" is entirely forgotten? I know it's a bit of a buzzword, but this is just dishonest game design. It's a lie of freedom and "do what you want" attitude, perpetuated largely by the fans, which tricks newcomers into thinking they'll be allowed to form strategies for missions and be creative, only for the game to pull them back by the leash, and force them to have fun THEIR way (a.k.a. the worst way). If you want to play GTA, play Vice City, play San Andreas. But do NOT play this game. At best, it is an early prototype of better future games.

author: {'steamid': '76561198110698739', 'num_games_owned': 706, 'num_reviews': 25, 'playtime_forever': 6281, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 6245, 'last_played': 1594661020}
review: As you can see, I played A LOT this game, especially considering I also completed it 100% on PS2 and Xbox. I love it, it's great. Then why the thumb down? Because this Steam version sucks. It doesn't even run on Windows 10, you have to search for fixes and mods to make it work. After that, it will actually work fine and you can enjoy it, but it will take away a lot of time to make it work and I think it shouldn't be like that. Until they fix it (so, never I suppose), the thumb will stay down. Instead: thumb up for the community and the modders, who made this game enjoyable on PC.

author: {'steamid': '76561198048109515', 'num_games_owned': 183, 'num_reviews': 21, 'playtime_forever': 1263, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1263, 'last_played': 1556594362}
review:
The best game of the 2000s. (I bought & played this game when it was released in 2001).  Believe all the positive hype – this game was revolutionary & a game changer when it was released 19 years ago.  This game set the standard for all future GTA games.  This game needs to be remastered for modern PC & gaming systems.    

This game introduced me to open world sandbox games.  Being able to play the main story at your own time & pace, and explore the map & complete side missions as a way to “take a break” from the main story was something new and very appreciated.  

This was the first GTA game to be made with a 3D-engine, a novelty at the time.  Even though the map is very small, back then, the world felt large and endless.  The map design is excellent, the way NPCs act is excellent, the soundtracks are excellent (including Lazlow!), and the gameplay is excellent.  There is so much good, you can overlook/ignore the criticisms (no swimming, no motorcycles, not being able to go inside the stadium, and no planes, except for the Dodo but flying it is a chore).  I spent a lot of time just driving around the map, enjoying the scenery, and exploring every possible place my character could access.

I played the entire game the first few times using no cheats and I’m glad I did.  It made me appreciate the game progression even more.  I used cheats later and had some hilarious times (ex: flying cars).  
Yes, later GTA games increased their map sizes, added new features, abilities, and characters, but there’s always something about GTA III that makes me come back again and again.  If you don’t have this game in your Steam Library, you haven’t lived.

author: {'steamid': '76561198132792574', 'num_games_owned': 510, 'num_reviews': 315, 'playtime_forever': 1501, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1501, 'last_played': 1592709286}
review: Grand Theft Auto III was the first 3D crime sandbox game, and mechanically it still holds up as a decent example of the genre. You can drive around recklessly and shoot guns at people and do short missions that are all remixings of the same five mechanics for cash, and these mechanics all function decently well. It is, however, pretty goddamn primitive, bare-bones, and frustrating in several ways, as befits such a genre pioneer. The stuff I described above is just about all you can do, the game world is pretty small and empty, and your map is shit-awful at telling you where you are or how to get to where you're going. More importantly, the missions are terrible; right from the start, but even more so as the game progresses, they're overlong and finicky, often featuring timers with barely any leeway or combat situations that are nigh-impossible if you just charge in like normal. You basically have to trial-and-error every single objective in the last third of the game, which gets extremely aggravating extremely quickly. The last mission is so obnoxiously designed that, after an hour of trying, I just gave up and used cheats to get through it. GTA 3 is so comically outclassed in terms of depth, quality, variety, enjoyability, and amount of content that there's no real reason to go back to it at all unless you're interested in game history. I would go so far as to say that Saints Row 2 is objectively superior in every way; if you want a good old-fashioned crime sandbox, try that.

review:
not even done with the story yet, look up guides for running the game on modern systems for unlocked framerate, widescreen support, controller support, the menus actually working support etc etc...

its a look back into the type of things that made GTA as a series, its super liberating to be able to tackle most of the missions in whatever way you want. theres a lot less hand-holding than the later titles

review: Well well well. Claude. My Man! I set off to 100% my first ever GTA game and what a blast this was. Driving around the streets of Liberty City listening to the same radio stations over and over, Starting gang wars, Doing driving stunts, Completing the missions, All was great fun (Other than the ambulance side mission which took me forever). Considering this was made in 2002. Loved every minute. Nostalgia at its best from the Playstation 2 days

author: {'steamid': '76561198004226735', 'num_games_owned': 562, 'num_reviews': 94, 'playtime_forever': 2821, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2821, 'last_played': 1395624110}
review:
Grand Theft Auto is probably one of the most iconic series in video game history. As much as I've enjoyed the GTA series, GTA3 never really struck that much of a chord with me. My favorite entries would have to be Vice City and San Andreas.

Grand Theft Auto III is a worthy title, don't get me wrong, and made the transition from top-down to full 3D TPS effortlessly.
But in terms of the graphics presentation, it has not aged well. Its visuals I think are the main reasons why I don't like it as much as the others. Everything just looks so dull. I understand it's supposed to be a gritty game, but everything really is just so dull looking and quite lifeless.

The controls are surprisingly acceptable for keyboard and mouse, although the fixed camera when driving was a bit annoying.
Also, I found the lack of a global map and permanent “locations hints” for Ammu-Nation and Pay 'n' Spray on the mini-map to be particularly annoying.

In the sound department, GTA 3 is only satisfactory, the sound effects of vehicles and weapons are acceptable, and the soundtrack is what you would expect, but the voice-overs, despite above average, are on a lower quality format, which makes understanding people really difficult sometimes.

In conclusion, GTA 3 might have been innovative for its time, but as it stands today, I cannot recommend it, since the sequels have done it bigger and better than what is presented here. GTA 3 is not a bad game per se, it’s just not a “unique enough” experience to justify its purchase anymore.
So unless you are a GTA fanatic, you’ll be better off playing its sequels.

author: {'steamid': '76561198028976276', 'num_games_owned': 272, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 29307, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 28995, 'last_played': 1672871250}
review:
Well, what can I say about a game that defined new standards in game design and changed the game industry.
Back in 2001 I can't explain how mind-boggling reading a review of this game was and looking at the screenshots - eventually playing it on my 800MHz AMD Duron + Nvidia TNT2 while getting 10-20 fps and loving every second of it.

I'm telling you this because gamer be vary, this game is a bit dated in modern standards, but nontheless is a must-play in my mind. Wholeheartedly recommended!

Tips:
- Display settings > Frame limiter must be ON, otherwise the game's physics behaves bad
- Display settings > Trails OFF - unless you like bad motion blur even for 2000s standards

review: A classic in my opinion. This game brings back so many memories from a youth. I would have preferred Rockstar would have given these games more support over the years but nevertheless with a few modifications things are as good as the old days. When you turn the graphics output to higher resolutions and with modifications this game maintains its value. Most of all the game has not lost its fun value. It held the test of time and playing through the story or running around trying to see how many stars you can rack up and still be able to evade law enforcement this game was worth the purchase in 2020 still playing!

author: {'steamid': '76561198328845531', 'num_games_owned': 121, 'num_reviews': 46, 'playtime_forever': 904, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 200, 'last_played': 1594033926}
review: Bence bu oyun kötü olmayan dönemine göre iyi denilebilecek  senaryoya sahip fakat oyunun oyun motoru olan Renderwave yani benim Half Life 2 eleştirmemde Source ile kıyasladığım sövüp saydığım oyun motoru ile yapılmıştır. Bu şu demek oluyor, 2080 ti SLI ekran kartın da olsa, GT 730' da da oynasan her şekilde kaçarı yok bir bokluk çıkarıyor. Bunların çözümleri var ben bi şekilde buldum siz de bulabilirsiniz bunla alakalı "GTA 3 Troubeshoot" yazınca baya bi video var. Ama oyunu almadan önce bu risklere bakarak alın. Tavsiyem Widescreen Fix, Silentpatch for III ve Frame Limiter Adjuster kurarak oynayın. Bu arada bahsetmeden geçmeyeyim oyunu frame limiter ile açık oynamanız gerekiyor her ne yaparsanız yapın bu frame limit adjuster da frame limiyi 30FPS olan GTA3' ü istediğiniz fps limitini seçerek oynayabilmektesiniz. Tavsiyem 60 FPS yapın. Ama bu söylediğim şeyler Vice City ve San ANdreasta da var ona göre alın.Ben bu oyuna recomended verdim fakat asıl ne iyi ne kötü gibi bir seçenek olsa ona verirdim.

review: First 3d game in the GTA series. awesome game when it came out. Was amazed with everything in it, the open world concept, people doing their thing, cars driving along. GTA 3 kind of have story but nothing major, just to keep the gameplay going/unlocking all three islands. But then if you don't want to do the story missions or side missions then you pretty much can go on a killing spree, blow things up, hijack cars, running from the cops. Awesome

author: {'steamid': '76561198192710535', 'num_games_owned': 184, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 1267, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1265, 'last_played': 1593595629}
review:
This game takes me back to when me and my brother used to play it together when i was younger. It's a really good classic game and it's where it all started for Rockstar. The graphics aren't the best but you can look past that and enjoy the cool and funny missions as you try to remove the islands of gang presence and collect guns.

Would recommend, classic game!

author: {'steamid': '76561198219731611', 'num_games_owned': 328, 'num_reviews': 171, 'playtime_forever': 140, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 137, 'last_played': 1590663582}
review:
[h1]A Good Grand Theft Auto Game...[/h1]
[i]I didn't finish the game, the way this game works. . . gives me headache![/i]

I was intended to over the game but got caught again by the aged mechanism of old games. Nonetheless, it was a very good game in Grand Theft Auto Franchise.

[i]I personally, enjoyed the car driving very much. It has some awesome control & good physics. Felt even better than the [b]Grand Theft Auto 5[/b]'s car control to be honest.[/i]

[b]My thoughts, if you are a die hard GTA fan... Sure, give it a try! You'd like it very much. . .[/b]

author: {'steamid': '76561198091337599', 'num_games_owned': 773, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 3827, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1359, 'last_played': 1626032954}
review:
Awesome game from 2001. Would recommend GTA3 to anyone curious to see what the first 3D open world game was like. The story isn't all that interesting. The missions are a bit repetitive. Controls on a gamepad are a bit wonky (a sign from the time it was made. I advice using mouse and keyboard). But it's got good humour, decent music, and you'll get the most fun out of just rampaging. 

Just make sure you get a patch or you'll have trouble running.

author: {'steamid': '76561198004492389', 'num_games_owned': 682, 'num_reviews': 276, 'playtime_forever': 499, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 463, 'last_played': 1589780626}
review:
The game that set 3D GTA, as well as all the clones, in motion. There's definitely a lot of charm that has been refined with each successive release in the series. It's a shame how little support it gets from Rockstar - and the game will not launch at all on Windows 10 without proper patching. Even with these patches, the AI is so dated by comparison that you will likely softlock a few missions toward the end (e.g: "Bait", "Escort Service") because the game wants things done in a certain play style.

I suggest downloading the silent patch as well as widescreen fix, if you intend on playing this on a widescreen monitor.

review:
Old but gold

If you are an older gamer, get it for the nostalgia, if you are a new player who can get past the outdated graphics and game mechanics the game is still a lot of fun, if you are a collector this is a classic. Anyone who gets it and want to actually play it install the fixes from this guide: https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=641839127

author: {'steamid': '76561198037347067', 'num_games_owned': 411, 'num_reviews': 217, 'playtime_forever': 2324, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1328, 'last_played': 1658826773}
review:
[b]Intro[/b]
I’m about to praise this game to Heaven and back, and I wouldn’t blame you for chalking my kind words for GTA III all up to nostalgia, but I promise I haven’t even played the game until now.

[b]The Great:[/b]
++Grand Theft Auto III's difficulty is severely exaggerated. It's a challenging game, sure, especially in comparison to the brain-dead easy GTA V (I actually do like V believe it or not lol) and as such you'll have to actually give at least half the missions in the game more than one attempt to pass, but I really
don't understand why so many of these missions are infamously difficulty within the series. Some of the supposedly hardest I managed to do in one go, even missions with timers I made mistakes in (multiple wrong turns, crashes, etc.) and yet I still got passed them in one go. The only mods I used were the SIlent Patch
to get the game running on modern platforms, the widescreen support patch and the controller support patch (which doesn't even have auto-aim), so I doubt anything made it easier.
++Vehicle handling is really enjoyable. My biggest problem with GTA V was the vehicle handling and now I realise that’s why I never enjoyed that game that much but here it’s brilliant (even if you’ll constantly flip). It’s incredibly responsive, you’ll rarely spin-out and when you get one of the fast cars, the
sense of speed is great. It’s just joyfully arcadey, which is nice since driving is without exaggeration what you’ll be doing throughout at least 80% of the time.
++The city is one of my favourites in the series. It’s easy to get around and varied enough
++Missions are really varied and well-designed. They're often short but incredibly fun. This is a bit of a back-handed compliment, but given how really not great the gunplay is, which I'm sure Rockstar knew, most missions aren't built around firefights and as a result they really let their creativity shine in
creating diverse scenarios instead of focusing on a proven formula (had the shooting been well-designed).
++This game's got a decently strong atmosphere that I love. It's dark, satirical without turning its narrative into nothing but a joke, and a joy to be immersed in.

[b]The Good:[/b]
+Graphics have held up really damn good once you get HD resolutions set-up. It's smooth yet detailed and even has some nice fake reflections here and there that still hold-up fairly well.
+Car deformation still looks pretty damn good even today. It’s more impressive than V. Seriously.
+Story-mode progressions feels rewarding as you gain access to new parts of the map and along with it new stores with new weaponry and new vehicles
+Great length to it
+The game's story is straight-forward, but it's not boring or uninteresting. The characters are likeable and well voice actored and even the mute protagonist is one seriously awesome, cold-blooded, vengeful, mercenary motherfucker.
+Sound design's good. You can tell it's GTA III just by listening to it thanks to the weird, repetitive, random NPC muttering and odd musical riffs near certain mission providers that lend to the game's slightly off atmosphere.
+The hidden collectibles, you know, those usually useless hidden items scattered around the place in every open-world game since, are actually helpful to find, as once you hit 1/10th you're granted a new very useful item at your safehouse
+Gore is awesomely brutal. Every piece of the Human body can be dismembered and decapitated with any type of weapon. It's great watching a crowd of people get blown up and have 3/4ths of their limbs removed, or to watch someone briefly hold their stump of a neck as blood pours out of their hole like a fountain.
It's sadistic in the way only video games can harmlessly entertain, and it more than makes up for the lack of ragdoll physics that make kills in the HD universe GTA games so rewarding.
+Characters are well animated, especially in cutscenes, despite character models looking like they're made-up of a more geometrically advanced version of Lego

[b]The Okay/Not Too Big of a Deal:[/b]
+-The conversational bits in the radio stations are the best bit about this game. Not even kidding. They're legitimately laugh-out-loud funny and really well written and voice-acted. The issue? The repetition is insane. You will hear the same fucking interviews over and over and you'll hear the same awful songs over and over until your ears bleed. There's about 2 songs I actually like, as well as a few musical interludes and original soundtrack stuff. The rest depresses me thinking anyone actually gets paid to produce this crap. Thankfully you can turn it off...
-+Compatibility with modern platforms sucks ass, but that's to be expected from a game from 2001... there are fantastic fan-made patches out there that make the game run perfectly on modern computers and they're easy to install. Even getting native controller support, along with on-screen correct controller prompts
and stuff like vibration support is easy to get installed.
+-Vehicles flip incredibly easily but honestly it doesn't even bother me. You're given ample time to get out of the way of them exploding (as they do once they flip) and vehicles are absolutely everywhere so you're never lost without a car. It's just something you get used to. Drive around, flip, run before it blows
up, get a new vehicle, keep going. It's just the rhythm of the game lol.
-+The gunplay as I've mentioned is pretty fucking poor. I mean, the crosshair doesn't even line up to where your shots hit at close - medium distances, but it is serviceable and it never frustrated me. In its crappiness it actually opens up different gameplay scenarios which have you
utilising long-ranged weapons and explosives in order to take out your enemies before they can really get their shots off at you. It sucks, yes, but not in a way that detracts from the actual gameplay, because the gameplay is rarely centered on the gunplay and so when it is it's a minor tactical divergence
from the other driving based objectives.

[b]The Bad:[/b]
-I really wish Pay ‘n’ Sprays and Ammunations were marked on the mini-map at all times. They’re often put in out of the way areas which can be difficult to memorise.
-Having to rebuy weapons and armour everytime you fail a mission, as well as to drive all the way back to said mission marker and then to drive to another place for the mission can get exactly as tedious as it sounds. It would've been nice to be able to just start immediately as soon as you die at mission start so you
don't waste your time, but it's not a big deal as mission markers aren't all that far away in the game world's medium size full of fast cars and smooth handling.
-There's a few extra little game modes, like side-quests from phone booths that sometimes have interaction orbs around them and sometimes don't, and sometimes lead to different missions or just replay the same ones everytime (which is annoying when you can't quit a mission without going out of your way to fail it or finish it)
and things like those set vehicles that actually force you into a whole different game mode where you're put under a timer make me wish the game told you what you're about to get into before you do. This game would've sucked for a completionist back in the day.

[b]The Horrible:[/b]
--N/A

Sound: 5/10
Graphics: 7/10
Gameplay: 9.5/10
Content/Replayability: 8/10
Overall: 9.5/10

Awards:
Runner-up Game of the Year - 2001

[b]Conclusion[/b]
Considering the age, the graphics hold up very nicely, and almost everything about the gameplay is superb. There's a lot of content here too. Fuck those who say this is out-dated or overly difficult. Neither, in my honest opinion, are true. Buy it now. It's easy to set-up smoothly on any machine and it's worth the few minutes
and few bucks it'll take to do so. I did not expect to love this game the way I do.

author: {'steamid': '76561198210568159', 'num_games_owned': 562, 'num_reviews': 68, 'playtime_forever': 1749, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1749, 'last_played': 1589265148}
review:
[i]GTA III[/i] may have been a revolutionary title back when it first came out, and whilst it’s still enjoyable for the most part, time has not been kind to it.

Coming back to [i]GTA III[/i] after all these years, the game’s many flaws are more predominant now. Driving physics are inconsistent and crashes often either end up in the vehicle coming to an instant halt, or flying through the air. Likewise, NPC behavior when driving is erratic with them changing lanes without any good reason and crashing constantly into the player. Shooting lacks any real impact and feels bland. And it also goes without saying that the game’s graphics are dated, with blocky and hideous character models. Mission structures are also very simple and revolve around the player driving somewhere or eliminating someone. Missions are enjoyable for the most part, but some are cheaply designed and completing them boils down to luck which can make the experience infuriating at times. Later levels involve driving long distances with the destination being unclear due to the lack of an in-game map. On the bright side, [i]GTA III[/i] is at its best during the driving missions and it’s obvious that it was designed first and foremost as a driving game. There is also a lot of side missions and unlike the newer games in the series, completing them was an enjoyable experience.

I had to patch the game for it to run properly on modern operating systems and to fix issues with widescreen and lighting. I did not experience any crashes or game-breaking bugs, but occasionally the sound effects would repeat themselves endlessly, and the mini-map landmark icons disappeared midway through the game. I also witnessed some hilarious clipping issues.

The weakest aspects of the game, however, are the story and characters which are not really explored much. Claude as a protagonist is also not relatable and his motives are not explained. By the end of the game, you can’t play the game for more than one minute without any of the rival gangs shooting at you which takes away the satisfaction of finishing the storyline. Also, there is noting to do with the money earned in missions, making the monetary reward of missions pointless. For all these reasons, [i]GTA III[/i] feels bland and lacks the charm of the future titles.

Overall, I found [i]GTA III[/i] immensely enjoyable half the time, and extremely infuriating the other half. The game mechanics are dated and not everyone will enjoy the overall product, especially after having played the newer titles in the series. As a result, I can only cautiously recommend [i]GTA III[/i], but for the price of admission, there is a lot of content on offer. [i]GTA: Vice City[/i] came out only a short while after this game and feels more balanced and polished in every aspect and is a much better choice overall.

author: {'steamid': '76561198355626538', 'num_games_owned': 423, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 1297, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1297, 'last_played': 1589147898}
review: GTA III is a fun, albeit frustrating, experience that is worth a try if you are a fan of the series. The storytelling, gameplay, and open world of the game are impressive for a game published in 2001, but the latter two have not aged well. You WILL need to download a small patch to make this game playable, or you will experience game breaking bugs. Still, compared to so much of the garbage of modern triple-A developers, the simplicity and arcade goofiness of GTA III gives it an undeniable charm that is refreshing. I enjoyed this game aside from some of the aged gameplay limitations and a few abrupt difficulty spikes.

author: {'steamid': '76561198185976731', 'num_games_owned': 24, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 10667, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 10100, 'last_played': 1594191962}
review:
TL;DR:

[b]Story: 3.5/5[/b]
[b]Gameplay: 3/5[/b]
[b]Graphics: 2/5[/b] (but considering the standards of the GTA series it was probably good for its time)
[b]Fun Value: 4/5[/b]

[b]Worth the purchase?[/b] Yes, especially since its cheap nowadays (especially on sale, I'm not sure if a game that's old enough to vote should still be 10 bucks but hey its Rockstar)
----

Full Review:

The game definitely shows its age but by merit of being an open world game in a typical GTA setting its already worth playing. The game's main problems are just QoL stuff that get in the way of fun; for example in GTA V you have full control over your car and you can flip it upright if its completely turned over even when you realistically shouldn't be able to. In GTA III, if your car flips over its done for and will explode after some time. Its really annoying when you're on a time based mission and flip your car, making you have to go find another. 

And on the topic of missions, they're not too bad. The way the game works story wise is that you have major plot points (just changing who you can take missions from) every once in awhile with random missions padding out the time. There are a lot of different ideas so its not always boring, and even the more menial missions like driving cars from one place to another can help you learn the map and feel more at home with the world (at least to someone like me who's really bad at navigation). I've definitely been challenged, but the open nature of the game lets you solve things the way you want. For example there was one where I had to kill a guy who was a police informant. If I did any damage to his car I'd immediately get a 4 star wanted level. So I just bought some grenades, threw them in front of his car which one shot it, and cleared the mission much easier than my first couple tries. 

At the time of this review I haven't beaten the game; I've done about half the main story missions (which puts me on the second island with all of Asuka's missions done and partway through Kenji's). I'll give a little review on what's happened so far and to be honest its not great at. You start as a guy named Clyde who escapes from the cops after being backstabbed by one of his partners-in-crime. To earn a living you work as a grunt for the mafia who are trying to gain dominance over the part of the city you're on. Honestly this part of the story was pretty fun, you really feel like you're becoming someone important as you go on. But then shit happens, you move to another part of the city, and start from basically 0 as a grunt for the yakuza who are in that part of the city (which is based off of NYC). That "twist" was pretty annoying since like I said it was fun being part of the mafia, and when the reason you have to leave is random and pretty forced. 

The sense of progression is also pretty meh, if you just play though the game's story straight the only way you really progress is getting access to the other areas of the game. The game does have these collectibles called mystery packages and the more you get the better weapons spawn at your house (which is just where you have to save your game, more on that later). I guess Rockstar wanted to incentivize exploration but it felt weird that that was the way they decided to give you weapon upgrades. You also get a lot of money, but at least as far in as I am there's nothing to spend it on other than weapons which cost like 5k max when I was running around with 400k+ at that point. GTA San Andreas at least had big investments like the safe houses around the game. The story while not the worst thing ever just feels like something you do when you're bored of running around doing criminal acts (which could be the point but at the same time you need to do it to unlock more areas to run around in).

I definitely derailed from the point on the game's QoL issues so I'll go back to that. Like I said the whole car flipping issue is pretty annoying and it sucks when its a car you want to keep (although the second island at least has a bunch of fast sports cars if that's what you like). Mobility is just ass, San Andreas did it way better. For example if you run up to a wall in SA and press jump you'll climb it, while in III you hit it and Clyde will do this weird step back animation that's way too long. Jumping will almost never get you anywhere and while there's still so much to explore, its sadly not really something you'll be doing on foot a lot. 

Another thing is the saving system, you have to drive all the way back to where ever you're living at that point to save the game instead of doing it where you're at. Personally a lot of the time I was just relieved to finish the mission I was on so I didn't care but I can definitely see others being annoyed about it. Similarly (and this one actually annoys me) there's no kind of checkpoint system for missions. Fail a long one just before you finish it? Too bad, drive all the way back to the person you're getting the mission from and do it all over again. GTA IV definitely did better with that. Hell, they didn't need to make checkpoints after every part of the mission like IV did; if they just made it so that you go back to the mission's start I'd be way more fine with it.

Water is basically the void; Rockstar only added swimming in GTA SA. So if you accidentally drive off a bridge its over for you, your health instantly starts scrolling down (plus you have to wait for your car to nearly stop before you get out unlike later GTAs, so there's no room for error). There are boats to traverse it but they're needed for like 2 or 3 missions so far. Water's main purpose is to be the artificial roadblock sectioning off other parts of the city until you complete parts of the story. 

I saw this in another review and forgot to add it in, but there are helpful places around the game like weapon stores and places to get your car sprayed (which hides you from the police). In GTA SA these places are marked but in 3 they're not. Like I said there are missions that make you go to these places so you learn in that sense but even still they should've done it.

Overall its a fun game, and you can tell Rockstar realized what made their games fun from the beginning. Because of that I think its absolutely worth your money even with the more archaic mechanics. It would definitely help to be a patient person however.

author: {'steamid': '76561198329201873', 'num_games_owned': 126, 'num_reviews': 27, 'playtime_forever': 503, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 289, 'last_played': 1597628272}
review: Lack of map in menu, and mini map icons of Pay 'n' Spray and Ammu-nation.  Graphics, models, and visuals, were dated for the time, just like GTA and GTA 2, when there was already 3D. Radio stations are very lacking, missions are extremely simple, like collect porn magazines or time will run out. I prefer GTA V's more complex missions. The AI is absolutely garbage, in races like Turismo, which took me an hour to complete, the racers will try to ram you off the road and NPC's hate you and just randomly smash into you. Claude is some weird guy who never talks, he's just a piece of crap in general. There is no motive behind Catalina's actions, just making the plot completely bullshit. The driving is painfully average. GTA: Vice City fixes all of these problems, if you are planning to complete all GTA games, just do this one first because you won't have to deal with anything bad later.

author: {'steamid': '76561198053803019', 'num_games_owned': 281, 'num_reviews': 38, 'playtime_forever': 1260, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1260, 'last_played': 1587742776}
review:
The only reason why you can like this game is being nostalgic about it.
So I guess this is the only reason why GTA III has so many positive reviews.
I tried out GTA II a long time ago, completed GTA Vice City and GTA San Andreas several times and GTA IV once, so I decided to give this game a chance. Well, now I'm not sure if I should have done it.

The main problem with GTA III is that the navigation in this game is simply horrible. There is no in-game map (only tiny radar in the corner of the screen) and design of the cities is really bad. I've spent incredible amount of time just trying to find my way to the objective.
Combine this with ridiculously timed missions and you'll get your GTA III recipe of rage and frustration.
It also has the same problem as GTA Vice City - inability to swim, but in GTA III you can't crouch as well.
Most of the missions are short, random and unreasonably hard.
Add some minor bugs (like disapprearance of unic car you parked in your garage) and dull storyline with dumb ending and here you have it.
Definitely not recommended.

author: {'steamid': '76561198230708168', 'num_games_owned': 217, 'num_reviews': 45, 'playtime_forever': 309, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 309, 'last_played': 1575674487}
review:
[h1] RESPECT "CLAUDE" [/h1]

author: {'steamid': '76561197970589211', 'num_games_owned': 1428, 'num_reviews': 28, 'playtime_forever': 666, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 666, 'last_played': 1585328567}
review:
What a wonderful game. Still one of my favourites. It carries a great amount of charm and there are a number of guides available on steam to get it up and running on modern systems. 

It has a few gameplay mechanics which you wouldn’t see these days, which can make it either frustrating or a moderate challenge. Audio is fantastic in terms of atmosphere and the radio stations available. The story is shorter than I remember but I found Grand Theft Auto: San Andreas far too long. 

This would be a great introduction to the series if you have somehow managed to avoid it so far.

author: {'steamid': '76561198369713775', 'num_games_owned': 162, 'num_reviews': 44, 'playtime_forever': 609, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 609, 'last_played': 1586795914}
review:
In this day and age, It's not worth it.

I know that this game is very old so most of my words would not be valid for those buying it for a nostalgic dive.

This game is the first game chronologically and the last in terms of the timeline. I wouldn't say the story is bad considering its age. But I forgot most of the plot already.
The cars flip very easily. There are hardly any good songs on the radio.
The cutscenes have an awful amount of motion blur. I don't even know what they were thinking.

The main problems of this game are the horrendous missions. They are incredibly tedious and very difficult. I wouldn't be surprised if you drop the game midway through.

author: {'steamid': '76561198315334238', 'num_games_owned': 769, 'num_reviews': 42, 'playtime_forever': 1156, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1156, 'last_played': 1585807417}
review:
After taking the time to finish this game i dont quite know how to talk about it, so lets start with this: its by no means a bad game, and it kept my interest up to the credits, but is it still as genre defining as people originally thought? Well, yeah this was the open world game responsible for all the open world games that we have now, and while some manage to be way better than gta 3, like Borderlands or San Andreas, there are still games coming out this year that claw at the feet  of a game from 2003, most prominent of these are Ubisoft games like Assassins Creed and Watchdogs series. This was the beginning if a genre that we still love to this day. And we have Rockstar to thank for it

So to be simple with the game, its story is pretty good, i always wanted to do campaign stuff instead of less around the map, mainly because the campaign let me explore it anyway. The start was great, the mid-story was all right and the ending was satisfying, people who finished the game know what i mean when i say i laughed near the start of the end credits. The open world was small enough to be recognisable and big enough to have depth. The characters were pretty ok and the missions were (mostly) fun. Some problems i see is that it hasnt aged well, its driving mechanics are kind of sensitive and the cars are fragile as hell. Alot of the missions were fun but were overshadowed by the worst god damn missions ever created.i will forever see the infamous coffee stand hunt in my nightmares and i couldnt finish the game quickly without using cheats. And thank god for cheats otherwise id still be trying to finish the thing. Even though it has its fair share of flaws, thats understandable as to why. Alot of older games were like this too. I would recommend buying the GTA classics bundle and finishing this one first, cause it only gets better from here

author: {'steamid': '76561199003574991', 'num_games_owned': 136, 'num_reviews': 24, 'playtime_forever': 419, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 31, 'last_played': 1586004848}
review:
Modern systems can run this game only with a frame lock at 30 FPS, otherwise the game crashes during cutscenes.
But there is a workaround to run it at 60 FPS, even in cutscenes: 
Look for "Direct X 9 Convert", put the small file into your root folder and you will be able to run it at smooth 60FPS. That's all. This file just converts the game to Direct X 9.

Don't forget to turn off "Frame Lock" and "Frame Limiter" in Options afterwards.

To improve graphics even further, I suggest to turn on Antialiasing and AF in your graphic card's settings.

Have fun!

author: {'steamid': '76561198882575002', 'num_games_owned': 43, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 2444, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2442, 'last_played': 1588818105}
review: This game is very important in the history of video games, as it made the concept of an open world very popular. But going beyond that, Grand Theft Auto III is still fun to play, even almost 20 years after its release. It might not be as amazing as all of the other Grand Theft Auto games, but it is still fun, because well, it's Grand Theft Auto. You have a lot of missions you can do (some of them are really annoying), there's a huge variety of weapons and vehicles, you can do whatever you want, whether it be exploring the city, or trying to get that wanted level higher.  You get the point.

review:
Fantastic GTA experience with captivating gameplay and setting.
While not my favorite it is a really deep game, probably why Liberty City came back in later parts of the series.
You do need to fix some graphical problems, but gameplay wise it is just like when it was released.
Story is really not part of why this game is good.
As the first 3D GTA this is really the backbone of the series.
9/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198043883441', 'num_games_owned': 200, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 771, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 753, 'last_played': 1584834646}
review:
DO NOT BUY! 

First off the game is a mess technically. Although steam did its fair share to port it, the game does not run what so ever right out of the box. You have to jump through a few hoops and unofficial patches to get it to run.

Secondly the game did not age well at all. The core gta mechanics are there but you're stuck with a mute protagonist, a somewhat dull game play, and a lot of quality of life improvements missing from the other gta. The game is frustrating to play, the moments of fun easily get taken out by the amount of pointless things you have to grind though just to get there.

This game was good for it's time but now it's just irritating to play. If you want a old school gta game, VC and SA are much much better options.
