author: {'steamid': '76561198127817295', 'num_games_owned': 519, 'num_reviews': 66, 'playtime_forever': 1444, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1443, 'last_played': 1551487460}
review:
Throughout my childhood and through my young teen years I wasn’t too fond of violent video games. Mainly for my parent’s views on violent videogames and especially the news that brainwashes parents to tell their kids that playing GTA is the equivalent of taking cracked cocaine and turn you into a vicious shooter…how times really change huh?

Now that I am older and much mature on my perspective of video games I can consider Rock Star games as something special to look back on their past work. GTA 3 is my first game to play into the series and sadly while I never played the first two games, I did saw gameplay of the games to at least analyze GTA’s style from a 2D game to a 3D game. Perhaps I may get to play and maybe review it but so far it has really aged a lot and the sky camera view is not very appealing in my opinion. I will warn you this, I may get a little bias on my review only because I have not played the previous GTA games and running this game is hard on my pc, so bugs and features may conflict on the review because I had to put a patch to run on my pc. Of course, I always try to be impartial with my reviews and try to see the best in every game as possible, hope you all enjoy the review.

[h1]From Small Time to BIG time [/h1]

	For people who grew up with the first two GTA games on the ps1, I will assume they did enjoy the game with its interesting mature style of the game of stealing cars, picking up a prostitute and shooting down police. I can only assume this is where they are starting to get some attention from the media, but not as impactful as GTA 3 later down in 2001.  For me when I see GTA 1-2 it looked more of an indie game because of its simple premise and gameplay compare to other game classics like Super Mario 64, Crash Bandicoot or Metal Gear. This is why those games aren't talked about as much as the 3D counterpart of GTA. 

Usually when I hear people talked about their first experience in GTA is usually the third game they get thrilled to bring up their experience (and San Andreas or Vice City but we’ll get there) on playing these classics. For a technical perspective, this was pretty revolutionary given how 3D open world was starting to become popular in video games. From a 2D into a 3D world of Liberty city and the things you can do in, there is quite a breathtaking the old and new fans alike….until the news media shows up and talked about it. 

I am surprised they are aware of the stupidity and hypocrisy some people see in their game and can turn it into good satire. Hell they dedicate a whole radio station in the game mocking of America’s culture of their stupidity. They even make fun of the violent video game portion before the news even begin to criticize them! That is what I call a company who are way ahead of the time.

[h1]Welcome to Liberty City: Impressions[/h1]

The city is very impressive for the time, though now the game has age because of the bugs it has; okay texture on buildings, characters/lore, and the gameplay. Though in the first hours I did enjoy the city of Liberty city, I don’t know why but playing it really felt I am living in 2001 the atmosphere is there yet I have never even touched that game when I was young. Cruising around the city is enjoyable while listening to some good radio music is relaxing. Not to mention running down people for LOL and get chased by cops was the most fun experience in the first hours of the game. Unfortunately, that ends here because I will explain later in another section that the gameplay drags my experience down.

 The story is not something to consider a classic since the main protagonist Claude is really the emptiest silent protagonist alive and the characters while they are charming they aren’t memorable in my book. Yes, compare the transition to GTA 2 to 3, this is considered a fitting transition to take in new fans while not scaring the old once, heck they even brought back the sky camera view if people are not fond of the third person view. I just think the pacing of the story seems a bit fast since in the beginning you just bail out of jail by your buddies and ten seconds later is “business as usual.” 

There isn’t much time to be invested with those characters because you are busy doing missions for them. Sad thing is that they are not to be trusted because one mission you are friends with them, the next they stab you in the back and you stab them in the back in another mission. The funniest part is that Claude’s reaction to all this backstabbing and alliance making he is like “yeah I'm cool with that.” His looks is all I don’t give a hoot as long as I complete my mission. Some characters try to hook up with Claude as if they know him but I’m sitting here like “do I care enough to care?” Oh well, I heard it will improve over the next few installments and this one considers the last “classic” of the first two.

[h1]Better catch me Cops!: Gameplay[/h1]

The gameplay and missions are fun in the first few hours but the game just drags me down with the uphill difficulty which is not my main issue of this game is the lack of fairness it has into completing certain missions. The game has no map or sense of directions you will get easily lost in this big city you are in which I don’t know why sometimes the icons appear to follow but sometimes it doesn’t as if the game just gave up and said: “eh, figure the rest of them out.” Which is a shame because a third of the game is time-trial missions and you are constantly running the clock, getting lost and cops/gangs ram you over.  Sure, there are side missions and mini-games to be entertained but the main missions are alright nothing super exciting. 

You better pray to get out of the car as soon as possible because there is no mid-air control so you better stop the car now or die. Firing weapons is so frustrating because the pistol and submachine gun you can run, but you are force to station when you get the better weapons so enemies began to easily shoot you! 

Gangs automatically go aggressive on you so if you want to go to a section of the map you better pray they don’t shoot you enough to make your vehicle explode immediately after you arrive!  Graphics rendering gets delay if you are far away given to the limitation it has but is bad because if you leave your vehicle far away it disappears. Better pray if your special vehicles don’t get destroy because if it did is gone for good. You can’t fly helicopters which cops use them but you can fly a dodo plane which sucks on getting to the air, so don’t try to get it across the ocean because Claude can’t swim.

[h1] Buy or Don’t buy?[/h1]

It has its frustrating moments on the gameplay side and the okay story-line, but for its time it’s alright to look back and appreciate what made the GTA series great. Do I think you should start with this game? Perhaps, only to enjoy what it is and not looked down on it because of the graphics. This is a 6.5 in my book, is not slightly above average but is not very good either in terms of fun. I’m sure when I get to Vice City it will be even more fun but for this, this is considered a successful experiment on Rock Star’s part in making the series mainstream of today.

[quote]If you enjoy this review then please consider subscribe to [url=https://store.steampowered.com/curator/31750985-The-Think-Lounge/=]My Curator Page[/url] for more reviews like this[/quote]

author: {'steamid': '76561198126604851', 'num_games_owned': 292, 'num_reviews': 49, 'playtime_forever': 1821, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1821, 'last_played': 1550021887}
review:
Guys I'm gonna give it to you and I'm gonna give it to you straight: this is one hot boi of a game. A true classico.

If you never actually played GTA before, most people will tell you to "just play Vice City or San Andreas". But while I do believe that the following games vastly improved what GTA III achieved at the time, its quirks and rough edges have a pretty distinct charm that is impossible to replicate.

Anyway, assuming that you are already know how much of a big deal this game was - and is - let's go for the ugly:

[list]
[*] I think everyone is aware by now that this port is hot garbo, right? And MAN, is it a chore to get this thing to run properly on Windows 10.

First of all, [url=https://gtaforums.com/topic/669045-silentpatch/]Silent Patch[/url] is a must. It actually makes the PC version worth playing, since it fixes countless glitches and oversights. If you want widescreen support (you do), download [url=https://thirteenag.github.io/wfp#gta3]ThirteenAG's widescreen fix[/url]. If you want full controller support (you do), download [url=https://gtaforums.com/topic/562765-ginput/]GInput[/url].

As always, [url=https://pcgamingwiki.com/wiki/Grand_Theft_Auto_III]PC Gaming Wiki[/url] will give you a step-by-step guide. [spoiler] Isn't it cool when developers completely abandon their older games? Massive kudos to the GTA community for keeping this game alive and kicking. [/spoiler]

[*] You cannot control the camera while using the classic control scheme. Not really. Just mentioning this because there seems to be some confusion regarding this issue online.

[*] Game's locked at 30 FPS, and if you unlock it, the physics go mental. So that's fun.

[*] It's kinda hard, but in the wrong way. You know that early-2000's "that's bullshit" kinda hard? That's the one. This is largely due to the fact that the auto aim is, well, atrocious - which [i]can[/i] be a turn off at the very beggining, when all of your weapons suck. Fortunately, the PC version includes a free-aim option. It's not a 100% functional, but it's there.

[*] Price is a bit salty for a game that's almost two decades old. Would highly recommend to get it on a sale.
[/list]

All in all though, GTA III is so much fun that its easy to overlook its (sometimes glaring) issues. Solid 8/10, would go in a wild cocaine hunt again.

author: {'steamid': '76561198179982978', 'num_games_owned': 283, 'num_reviews': 76, 'playtime_forever': 29, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 29, 'last_played': 1549652880}
review:
This game is a classic, but I cannot recommend this PC port, as it has some major issues. 

Firstly, the menus are invisible, which is fixed by shift+tabbing repeatedly until the brightness inches its way up to what is visible. Once you click on a menu option, however, the entire thing resets and you must shift+tab again to be able to see it. 

Another huge issue I have is with the framerate. The game does not force you to use the frame limiter, but in order for it to be semi-functional you must. This caps the game at around 30 fps, which is unplayable. If you turn the frame limiter off, the game freezes, crashes, and the menus break more frequently. 

The last issue I have is with the driving. Since the game came out before mouse controls were a big thing, you CANNOT look around while driving (same as Vice City), so one of the main gameplay elements of the game is dogshit

author: {'steamid': '76561198162127480', 'num_games_owned': 520, 'num_reviews': 21, 'playtime_forever': 1009, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1009, 'last_played': 1550088845}
review: Back during the ps2 era I was but a lad only of age 8ish or whatever, young boy. Anyways we had just gotten a playstation 2 and my older step brother at  the time had a game called GTA3. We pumped hours into just messing around driving cars obeying the lights, wreaking havoc, usual gta fun. Alas though at this age I could never grasp of beating a game like this in my youth or even on the ps2 with the horrible aiming. Fast track to now and when I got gta3 I was on a trip of nostalgia. First of though the game looked like straight butt. Install some mods and bing bag wahoo later im off to playing a game I never dreamed of owning present day. Anyways beat it and the end missions are straight garbage but this game is great and is a straight 3D open world classic of a game. 9/10 basic story and plot points but a stunning game in its time. I would recommend this

author: {'steamid': '76561197992229015', 'num_games_owned': 1079, 'num_reviews': 703, 'playtime_forever': 413, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 413, 'last_played': 1550237813}
review:
Playing GTA 3 in 2019 is like a blast to the past...If it's a good one depends on your level of tolerance.

Pros:
- The driving is still hella fun.
- The missions are somewhat varied and interesting.
- The "dialogue", though cheesy, can make you smile.
- It's always fun to go on a sandbox rampage.
- The radio stations.
- Still a charming city/map.
- Still works without any modifications.

Cons:
- The graphics are atrocious. Hasn't aged well. Should be apparent.
- The controller support is awful. Shooting is terribly difficult and inaccurate. Funny thing: It's even worse with M+KB.
- The game doesn't automatically save your progress. You have to go to a safe house to do that. Can get pretty tiresome. Luckily it didn't crash even once for me.
- The missions are hit and miss...some are extremely frustrating.
- No map view and no GPS system, so have fun finding your target if you're a bit lost or simply don't know where to go. This often results in a mission restart when the mission is timed.
- Frequent loss of character control. When hit with shotguns or punched for example.
- Can't swim...water = death
- The story is actually not even that good. Typical revenge plot in the end. And the missions don't really string together all that well. Feels like a lot of progression is missing. I felt a bit lost at times.
- The voice acting and sound effects are terrible. And the mixing is cruel as well.
- Why is everyone always in my way?! ;)
- Bugs.
- Mod support on Steam is terrible for this game.


No, seriously, if you want to play this game in 2019 for whatever reason (for me it was nostalgia) do yourself a favour and get a trainer. Or unlimited patience. Downloading various mods...might or might not work...Steam is a bitch about it though. Too bad. You can probably complete the game in about 10 hours without cheating. Have fun ^^

author: {'steamid': '76561198255240553', 'num_games_owned': 379, 'num_reviews': 102, 'playtime_forever': 247, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 247, 'last_played': 1530199305}

review: This Game is now considered a classic in my eyes, it was the first game in the GTA series to be played in third person view. The Games before this where played in a birds eye view which you can still play in this version. The Graphics are not great compared to games now but at the time it was released it was among the best. Its a great story to play, you start the game as an attempted bank robber who has been setup. You get caught and sentenced to prison, but you escape when a fellow inmate is busted out during the prison transport. You then begin a new career in the criminal underworld doing jobs for gangs from all around the city. The game is all open world so you can play as you want following the story or causing chaos

review:
TL;DR - only buy it for nolstagia or if you love the GTA series

A great addition to your library if you enjoy other GTA games or just want nostalgia, otherwise this game has really not aged well. GTA III is dreadfully boring and sometimes tediously difficult to a newcomer. While a decent game, you can pick up significantly better (and newer) GTA games like San Andreas and Vice City or IV and V. GTA III was revolutionary for its time, but its charm has run out.

author: {'steamid': '76561198043544245', 'num_games_owned': 135, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 2722, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2541, 'last_played': 1547850767}
review:
GTA 3, the first of the 3D GTA's one of the first as open world games and full non-linear gameplay.  

The game haven't aged well with it's graphics, sound and gameplay.  It is yet a classic, often the missions are harder than the other 3D GTA's but the 100% is the easiest.  Getting to grips with the car physics, handling and gunplay well enough, the game is enjoyable.

Best to play with mods with new build PC's, those often improve and make functional the various bugs that often makes the outcomes of Missions highly rando at times, though this is often a feature of most open worlds ever since.

Highly recommended playthrough to the end, fairly recommended playthrough for the 100%, play it for the nostalgia trip, having the game on PS2 so many years ago myself.

author: {'steamid': '76561198045358495', 'num_games_owned': 996, 'num_reviews': 118, 'playtime_forever': 792, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 699, 'last_played': 1547069817}
review:
I'm glad the GTA series has brought good successors to this mess of a game.

-Terrible soundtrack. Feels like I’m in some techno dystopia in the mid-2000s.
-Gun reticule doesn’t match where the bullets hit at times.
-AI teammates are stupid. You babysit them the entire time and have to go ahead of them so they live.
-Missions are repetitive. 
-No map and no indicators on the mini-map. How am I supposed to know where the spray shop and gun shop are without using an online map or memorizing it?

The atmosphere is alright but Liberty City feels like Seattle with triads and mafia members walking around. I’m about a third done with the game and I can’t see it getting any better.

author: {'steamid': '76561198074185310', 'num_games_owned': 81, 'num_reviews': 22, 'playtime_forever': 597, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 536, 'last_played': 1546532641}
review:
Well... it is a GTA. All the elements are there: funny radio hosts, gratuitious violence, stereotyped characters. But this game simply didn't age well. The story is short, with an illogical, anti-climatic ending. To compensate for the short story, the missions get more and more difficult, to add some gameplay time. And the lack of a map that you can check anytime you want is frustrating, to say the least.

But what really kills this game is the port. It is a BAD port. I lost the count of how many times the game either failed to initialize or to go beyond the main menu. There was a game-breaking glitch where the character would keep moving left-backwards and it could start any time. And it would happen a lot. At some point the icons of my game would just dissapear and I would have to memorize the locations of gunshops and pay n' spray's. Not to mention I had to find new ones casually finding them when passing by them. Also, for some reason when you hold a gun the mouse won't recognize some tiny adjustments to the aim, making the gunfights difficult at best and annoying at worst. 

Definetly a no go. 4/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198022419304', 'num_games_owned': 249, 'num_reviews': 81, 'playtime_forever': 2699, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1740, 'last_played': 1611592399}
review:
[h1]Sorry babe, but I'm an ambitious girl.. and you're just small time.[/h1]

Grand Theft Auto III is the more or less revolutionary, third major entry into the open-ended criminal sandbox game series, spanning from 1997's original top down entry. You play as an unnamed man in this game - later games give him the name of Claude - who seeks revenge from their former partner in crime after they betrayed and left them for dead during a job gone wrong.

By today's standards the game looks positively... poor, but for a 2001 title in an industry still reluctantly stepping into full-fledged 3D graphics, it was astonishing. Nevertheless, character models are pretty obviously composed of separated segments that are animated as need be, often wonkily and even in cutscenes, and while the draw distance is impressive for a game of its age, props and entities still obviously spawn just a short distance ahead of where you look. Small details litter the game world and help in grounding you into its satirical yet dreary and hostile-feeling atmosphere, but it does little when the big picture itself looks dated.

Audio is notably low quality, especially for voice acting, but there is good variety in sound effects, from weapons to vehicles. The radio feature remains a (relatively speaking, anyway) unspoken-of piece of brilliance: 9 radio stations, featuring a wide range of musical genres, and one hilarious talk radio show, to be listened to from any civilian vehicle. Unlike future entries, the humour in dialogue is toned down during mission cutscenes, and mostly relegated either to the radio or to random passerbys spouting nonsense on the streets.

Gameplay is understandably the meat of the game. As a transition from the top-down gameplay to full 3D, some quirks remain to tide over players of the original games, including an optional top-down camera view not seen in any future mainline games, gaining money for fender benders and exploding cars, and the protagonist actually being mute and only partaking in one-way conversations with people, generally to receive mission objectives. The missions have fair variety in delivery of a narrow set of objectives, but quickly become [b]annoying[/b]. Future GTA games are graced with things like a map screen, waypoints, more detailed and clear objectives and locations, autosaves, journey skips and mid-mission checkpoints. This game has none of that bar a useful but really restricted minimap in the corner, which doesn't even have a good coloring scheme to distinguish water from roads or tunnels. 

Missions are also made that much more annoying by being given no indication of which missions permanently disable performing others until you fulfill them or consult a walkthrough.. nor that, as the storyline progresses, gangs become permanently hostile with you, including a mafia wielding very dangerous weapons that can blow your car up or knock you out to the hospital in a few seconds. You also have a (barebones, by modern GTA standards) list of side activities to perform that reward you with in-game money and additional perks, ranging from being a taxi driver, ambulance driver or "vigilante" officer (providing a souped-up cab, health pickups and wanted level clearing bribes, respectively), to entering certain vehicles parked in specific locations that trigger minigames, and the usual assortment of "hidden package" collectibles that grant an ever expanding armory at your safehouses, which is a godsend when seemingly every other mission wants to screw you over in a flaming wreck, or just end you from onslaughts of enemies who can stun you out of shooting a tiny bit (a lot if shotgun) when you get hit.

For smaller things that can throw off even established players of newer GTA games, a big one is the car handling. They have a much wider range of variation in stats (who'd have thought a lowly looking estate can turn so quickly?) but most end up feeling like they can tip over from just taking a corner at moderate velocity. There's also NO MID-AIR CAR CONTROL, which screws you over 9 times out of 10 if you take a jump or fall badly. Land on your roof? You better crawl out of there fast. You also cannot dive out of a moving car, so you have to come to a stop - again, even as it's about to blow up. All vehicles have much more vague damage indication: while body panels come off with the slightest touch and isn't too unusual for GTA games of its era, vehicles will get some puffs of white smoke coming from the engine after unspecified and seemingly random amounts of damage... then at some point finally go "oh it's fire now, better run", with no further warning of a vehicle's damage state. Weapons have a progression system which amounts to: the pistol is useless the moment you get an Uzi, which is almost useless the moment you get an AK, which is thoroughly useless the moment you get an M16, which is only a notch below the Bazooka, and the shotgun is a poor man's Bazooka for up to 15ft (and also Claude's kryptonite).

Oh yeah, and you can't swim. The action takes place in and around two islands and one mainland segment, and boats are finnicky enough to line up to jetties and hop off as it is, so there's that.

There is easily content for dozens of hours of play in one go, and possibly hundreds more if you're bent on completing the coveted 100% Completion checklist, but this game is not for the faint of heart. Even having played newer titles in the series, III is a monster of its own. Its scale is much smaller and its delivery confusing/confused, but you'll be flipping walkthrough pages the most for this game. [spoiler]okay, the most right after San Andreas[/spoiler] Enter this then amazing, now bizarre gem of gaming, and those who can stomach it will have a pretty good time.

author: {'steamid': '76561198062813911', 'num_games_owned': 1840, 'num_reviews': 1927, 'playtime_forever': 622, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 622, 'last_played': 1546048300}
review:
[h1] DISCLAIMER: This is a full review, and NOT a first impressions review [/h1]

Grand Theft Auto III is an infamous game developed and published by Rockstar Games and is the third game in the Grand Theft Auto franchise

The game has some really nice environments and the graphics are really well designed and laid out, especially for when the game came out

The game does suffer with some repetitiveness at certain areas of the game but a fun game nontheless

The game has some poor performance issues so a fan-made fix is easily found online to fix what should have been the developers job, but Rockstar Games apparently hates PC so...

Grand Theft Auto III overall, however, is a fun game to play in short bursts and a good open world action game to play!

[h1] RECOMMENDED :) [/h1]

[b] REVIEW SOURCES: [/b]
[list]
[*] None

review:
Don't buy an old GTA game from Steam.
Cars have dark colors.
Crosshair is misaligned, especially at high resolutions.
Framerate needs to be capped at 30 fps in order to "work".
Framerate drops whenever there is a lot of things going on.

Too much work in order to fix those issues.

author: {'steamid': '76561198114563111', 'num_games_owned': 447, 'num_reviews': 250, 'playtime_forever': 1175, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1175, 'last_played': 1545306583}
review:
[b] Buy it ONLY if you're a hardcore GTA fan - or - if you, 
like me, played it when you were younger and want to feel 
some of that sweet, sweet NOSTALGIA. [/b] 

^Otherwise, skip it. Seriously. I mean it. #GTAevolution

Classic GTA. 

For me... Much nostalgia! Brings me back.
The first GTA I played... I never beat it though... 
I played it on PS2... It sadly crashed a lot...

There are only a couple of things that are good. The funny
NPC lines like, "young man", "there's no need to feel down",
etc, in reference to the YMCA song and these lines are
spoken by black dude the builder who is obviously gay...

Apart from that... It's really just nostalgia. Basically, you're 
definitely not missing out on anything by skipping this one.

Other good stuff: Atmosphere and car radio.

Yes, it's... A good game... *takes nostalgia goggles off* 
Well, not as good as the more modern GTAs for sure. 
A little bit outdated but yeah... But 'tis still a good game... 

Install some mods though and it's even better. 
That takes some combination of effort and patience though!
Is it worth it? Probably not.

Being totally honest though... It's old and it's frustratingly 
hard... And you know how a mission failed goes in any GTA 
game... You're made to drive all the way back to the mission start. 

-_-

That's gonna happen a lot.

Just... Be prepared. Better yet... Lemme give you a hand.

(I'm also pasting these here for my own future reference)

GUNSGUNSGUNS = Weapon Cheat 
IFIWEREARICHMAN = Money Cheat 
GESUNDHEIT = Health Cheat 
TORTOISE = Armor Cheat 
MOREPOLICEPLEASE = Wanted Level Up 
NOPOLICEPLEASE = Wanted Level Down 
ITSALLGOINGMAAAD = Crazy Peds 
NOBODYLIKESME = Peds Want To Kill You 
WEAPONSFORALL = Peds Pack Heat (Carry Weapons) 
CHITTYCHITTYBB = Flying Cars 
GIVEUSATANK = Spawn A Tank 
ILIKEDRESSINGUP = Change Character 
BANGBANGBANG = Blow Up Cars Around You

They don't help enough though if I'm honest.

( [b] EDIT: [/b] This trainer here is fully functional and provides some useful things like, unlimited health/ammo and indestructible cars, etc. Now you might actually be able to complete the game without slitting your wrists lol: https://www.gamepressure.com/download.asp?ID=58401 )

Things I really don't like: Cars damage way too easily (one little bump
and the hood of your car is gone), missions are unimaginitive/repetitive, 
controls/combat clunky, driving sucks, police are absolutely bonkers, etc.
Oh, and an infinite number of constantly respawning gang members which 
try to kill you while you're doing a mission and who make it 10x harder than
it has to be. That 'Turismo' (racing) mission, for example. I'm remembering
why I never completed this game all those years ago lol. F u cking terrible.

Sounds like any other GTA... Right? Believe me... All's worse in GTA III...

[i] Driving on ice. [/i] 
Oh noes. The nostalgia has worn off. At least now you have the truth.

[b] Recommended mods [/b]

1. CLEO (I can't remember what this is exactly but I think it's required to use some mods)

2. GInputIII 1.11 by Silent (awesome mod that enables you to use your Xbox 360 controller)

3. http://gtaforums.com/topic/555946-reliii-gta-3-natural-hd-textures (basically, muh gfx)

4. Uninstall

[h1] 5/10 [/h1]

--

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=SocCv14crus

author: {'steamid': '76561198027820173', 'num_games_owned': 80, 'num_reviews': 27, 'playtime_forever': 21, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 21, 'last_played': 1530963118}
review:
When I play this game, I always wonder, how the game would look like if game developers had a little more time to fine tune it into the quality of the game that came a year after. I do not want to say that the game as such is bad, I am sure you will enjoy a lot of fun while doing missions or just cruising around the city. However, I cannot get rid of the impression that game developers were pushed by deadlines and simply did not have time to fine tune the game and so in some cases they were forced to delete content or find shortcuts to problems that required a lot of time. I think that the most notorious Rockstar´s shortcut is a main character Claude Speed, who does not talk and it even when dying. If you are willing to accept such budget cuts and only focus on the storyline, you will surely enjoy the game.

Rating: 7/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198277819971', 'num_games_owned': 104, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 1593, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 30, 'last_played': 1654939321}
review:
I've been waiting a long time for GTA3 to go on sale and I'm sorta glad I did because I would've been really annoyed if I'd paid full steam price for this game, why let me tell you why;

The game wasn't made for modern operating systems I understand that and this was way before the likes of Windows 7 and Windows 10 were even thing but that doesn't excuse the issues I've faced;

1. If you display resoultion is 1920x1080 for example like my current resoultion is, this game is going to launch at a whopping low resoultion, you need to install additonal fixes made by users with free time on their hands if you want to fix this issue and good luck if that even fixes anything, even after installing the supposed fixes I'm still facing issues. 

2. When you get to the Main-Menu (where the load, new game buttons are etc) the entire menu is completly invisible... as in you can't see any text but you can still highlight the menu buttons where they should be if this damn game was working as it was suppose to. 

3. Audio SFX at main menu missing or broken but with the supposed fix I installed when pausing the game during Gameplay the Audio SFX works fine for the time being. 

4. I don't know If it's to do with the GTA3 Steam fix I installed but whatever the hell it is and what's causing It is definitely annoying, Car colours are broken and all of the cars seem to be dark black or dark, no I didn't enter the cheat code for all black cars if there is one for GTA3. 

I have an older retail version of GTA3 that worked fine on an old Windows 8.0 computer a couple of years ago without fuss or issue but I simply purchased this for convience. My advice if you have a modern computer & system is to avoid this game and don't bother applying fixes, it's a waste of time and after applying them your still faced with more issues. 

If you have an older computer running the likes of XP or below then you shouldn't have trouble running this game unless the steam version much more terrible than what I truely think it is. If the steam version still runs terrible on older systems then just go buy yourself a retail version (hoping it'll be 1.0) and request a refund out of this game. If it requires so many additonal hoops and fixes just to play the game and it's still buggy you should be entitled to a full refund.

author: {'steamid': '76561198227533140', 'num_games_owned': 106, 'num_reviews': 35, 'playtime_forever': 89, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 89, 'last_played': 1542107984}
review:
+ Good Story.
+ Not a complicated Story.
+ The main mission is fairly easy (except missions that use big car, because it's easily to flip).
+ Easy to find Hidden Packages.
+ Easy to find rare Cars to bring to Import/Export on the Harbour.
+ Have an adrenaline mode.

- Bad handling.
- Cars are easily to flip, damage and then exploded.
- No full Map on pause menu.
- Hard to do Side Mission such as Vigilante, Paramedic, etc after finishing the Main Mission (Because all the gang now have used ak-47 and shotgun).
- Sometimes, the legend icon on the map are disappearing. 
- Easily to get caught by police.


That's all for me now.
I'm actually not sure to recommend this game. Because I don't really like the game mechanism.

author: {'steamid': '76561198035345202', 'num_games_owned': 1370, 'num_reviews': 81, 'playtime_forever': 683, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 683, 'last_played': 1519437937}
review:
This wasn't a great port to the PC by any means. It has its issues with graphics and controls. But the game is still very playable on modern systems (Windows 8/8.1/10). Playing it with mouse and keyboard instead of a PS2 controller took some getting used to. But in the end, it works out well enough. And it's still a GTA game, with GTA storylines and characters.

It's a solid game, and goes for a huge discount during Steam sales. Pick it up, if you're a fan of the series.

7.5/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198848660624', 'num_games_owned': 34, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 1140, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1086, 'last_played': 1562018769}
review:
The PC port of this game is a "fixer-upper", meaning you have to find the community-made patches and implement them yourself (easy-to-find, easy-to-do btw).

That being said, this is probably my favourite GTA. I loved GTA SA, but GTA III holds a special place in my heart as both the first GTA I've ever played (back in the day on PS2), as well as the first 3D GTA. Sure, it's a little unrefined here and there, with glitches and mildly irritating missions, but the storyline is very interesting and engaging (more-so once you're done with Portland) even though the protagonist is silent. The gameplay is fantastic, there's plenty to see and do. Yes, the graphics are dated, but they look pretty good for being made in 2002. After 10 mins in game, you won't notice anyways. 

This game is a homerun in my book, along with the other 2 entries into the 3D era of GTA (III, VC & SA). But on top of it all, this is also the game we have to thank, because it gave us GTA:VC, GTA:SA, GTA IV, etc. 

Even today, it's worth every cent. Tied with GTA:SA for the best anything that Rockstar's ever released.

200/10, the most wonderful game to satisfy the Nihilist inside us all.

author: {'steamid': '76561198383076366', 'num_games_owned': 180, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 2334, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2320, 'last_played': 1601134521}
review: GTA III, no doubt the game that defined open world. The first GTA to be open world and still came with 3 different maps; set in the classic Liberty City. What the studio managed to do all the way back then is just unbelievable. It's something the British can pride on - Rockstar North (Dundee, Scotland). The game introduced many new mechanics which still define today's GTA games. It may be a forgetten game as with all old games, but no doubt a key game to impact the games industry. Who could live with a GTA without punching people to the ground; stealing cars and radio stations. As far as the gameplay goes, it's still a great game to play today. The radio stations are just brilliant and shows how much effort the developers put in back then into making the radio as enjoyable as possible. Definitely recommend even today and gives you that feel of nostalgia. A game to be cherished.

author: {'steamid': '76561198128929351', 'num_games_owned': 117, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 1076, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1073, 'last_played': 1578853131}
review:
Hey guys let's talk about this game for a bit.

This is the very first GTA many of us OG players have played on their little PS1s. It showed us that the world was more than: "do what you're told son" and it takes you on a journey of self-psychological discovery. 

When exploring the world, you'll notice that the graphics aren't great, and that turns off many players that have bought this just to say you own it. Worry not, back in 2001, the developpers somewhat knew it wouldn't age that well! The game then and made sure that the cartoonish style is funny-looking, you can tell with the personas that are depicted in the game!

It's all in good fun, and I think in 2018 this game has aged better than GTA 5!!!!!

review: Although it hasn't aged well with a limited world and simple (sometimes even repetitive) missions, it's still a classic. It runs surprisingly well on modern machines with a few easy-to-fix bugs, and the difficulty's also quite high for a GTA game so get ready to die a lot. I'd recommend it if you've played it before and want the nostalgia feels.

author: {'steamid': '76561198287569736', 'num_games_owned': 53, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 1782, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1728, 'last_played': 1515985578}
review:
GTA III

I really am not sure about this game.
It kinda sucks but it is amazing on the other hand.

As we all know GTA is an open world third person shooter and so on.
But GTA 3 is the first title of Grand Theft Auto in 3D perspective.
It is literally the beginning of GTA as we all know it today and it feels great to dig into the roots and see how it all started

Technically it is a mess compared to todays games, you cant really beat it without loading a save. 
You die, mission failed all weapons gone, all of them expensive af. You even have to pay to do missions like 500k once. You die, the money is gone. 
Have fun gathering it all again with taxi missions and what else you can do. 2k in 5 minutes. You would have to grind for every try and sometimes 4 tries are normal.
You cant sprint as well and the aim on range is a huge mess, you have to aim a little right and a little bit dow to hit the target.
The lack of a cover or even sneak mechanics hurts and there is no map. I got used to remembering everything you know you get it after a while. There are some significant spots like e.g. central park.
So the map is missing but thats ok. 
The physics are funny how your car jumps up when crashing into people and it feels weird but you get used to it as well
But think about when it came out. 2001. I rember trying this game very hard on my first real smartphone 14 years later.
I didnt even make it to the second Island back then and thinking about the pain even on pc makes me think how I even enjoyed it like that on a phone. It really was horrible due to the buttons on the screen and in your fov...
But I see that it was the best way possible and it was a hell lot of fun I can tell you that.

The graphics are so classic. Dont break the game down on its graphics its just nostalgic and it feels like an open world max payne 1...
It was such a huge jump back then. 
Compared to now it looks edgy, flat and grey af. Its funny to see the propably first lens flares in game history. I really can imagine how everyone was like: "wooow" in 2001.

The story is lame but fun.
It is like "I dont fckn care about your shit" when you play it today because it simply cant bring up tension, we are all supersaturated because of AAA cutscenens and movie like action that this would be crap if it came out 2017.
But it is so much fun going all the way down to the toilets in central park to meet a corrupt cop in there whos been waititing for you exactly there for days.
And these faces that look all the same. Also the feeling of beating missions by tricking the game somehow, taking advantage of bugs, driving the dodo like a car on the streets of LC and so on.
I really love it just because of memorys and that feels great. Its just part of me somehow, I couldnt let go on that.

And you have not lived until you flew the dodo all the way over to the ghost town :)

So I recommend this game for everybody who wants to check out GTAs roots. Everybody who knows it from his childhood wouldnt read this review because he knows the game.
If you want all your action, fun and nice grafics and high end quality you should look for something else .
7/10


Playtime of one playthrough + screwing around alot: 30 hours

author: {'steamid': '76561198047169991', 'num_games_owned': 1228, 'num_reviews': 160, 'playtime_forever': 807, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 786, 'last_played': 1638044592}
review:
Early memories from my childhood caused me to buy this one in a bundle a while ago. Take this with a pinch of salt since I did  use some essential mods to run the game on my modern system as well as add controller support.

Graphics

So I kept these unmodded and I have to say visually it is stunning. However, the game was released in 2002 when widescreen wasn't really a thing, so the widescreen option will just stretch the whole image rather than actually rendering the game at the proper resolution, but this can be fixed with a simple google search for "widescreen fix". 

Anyway, the visuals set a dark and rough tone consistent with the game's theme. it hasn't aged well over the years but being able to customize the PC version a little bit I really enjoyed the option to disable trails. Trails is a very early implementation of motion blur and it does look cool when driving fast, but most of the time can be frustrating and even a little nauseating. Maxing out the draw distance (which if you can handle windows 10, you can definitely handle!) allows you to see from one island to another, no more heavy fog which was used on consoles to optimize the hardware. Even with this in mind, the xbox version is superior graphically as it features much better reflections, models and textures.

Audio

Radios are a little bare compared with Vice City, but there's definitely a radio for everyone. 80s, 90s, Gangster Rap, Techno, Drum n Bass/Garage etc. theres some songs from scarface, the classic radio suiting the mafia vibe too.

Gunshots echo in the streets as escaping engines roar and panicked screams fill the air. It's wild, violent and beautiful all at the same time. all of this great sound design lays out the foundations of GTA's 3D games starting right here.

Gameplay

The world is your oyster, you can do anything you want! be a taxi driver, a paramedic or a vigilante. or just beat the crap out of that old lady. she looked at me funny i swear! but yeah, it's good old sandbox fun. GTA 3 practically invented it, probably. Must admit, that it does get really difficult should you really really annoy the police or get far into the story missions.

Driving AI is pretty decent, civilians come to a dead stop if you are in front of them, they awkwardly swerve should they hear an emergency siren, and anyone hostile to you will plow into you until you're dead.

On foot though! oh boy. they get stuck on absolutely everything should they have to follow you. I did discover a few other minor bugs such as standing in certain places when a cutscene triggers can get you stuck out of bounds until you restart, without a way to save. rest in peace.

In conclusion, this game is absolutely amazing for its time and is well worth checking out if you've enjoyed modern GTA tites. It'll require a bit of tweaking if you're on a modern system and you'll need some essential mods such as silentpatch otherwise the game will ask for disc 2 when you start it, or that it couldnt find video mode 640x480 or something. I'd really recommend checking out PCGamingWiki and their article for GTA III if you want to get this running or are having any issues. Classic GTA but one of the hardest out of the 3D titles. 8/10.

review:
For many of us this was our first installment of steal. I remember being a small naked boy playing this game after begging my mom to let me get an m rated game from eb games. I can now re-live these memories on PC as a much larger naked boy. The preferred method is to link your PC to a tv and play with an Xbox one controller using ginput. Apply a widescreen patch and baby you're stealing in a resolution your naked boy eyes can't even comprehend.

The game is also harder than I remember.

author: {'steamid': '76561197979971311', 'num_games_owned': 529, 'num_reviews': 40, 'playtime_forever': 1630, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1624, 'last_played': 1568835358}
review:
This is the game that started it all. 

I remember seeing ads for this in a video game magazine when I was a kid and couldn't contain my excitement. Here we are however many years later and still a great game. 

Game mechanics are a little bit clunky such as aiming and mission replays when dying but nothing a great few mods can't fix. Just got done enjoying this game with the Xbox Version mod plus a multitude of other great mods such as autosaving to make replaying this less painfull.

Make sure to follow this amazing guide for a great re-play-through:
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=720574899

author: {'steamid': '76561198399075178', 'num_games_owned': 88, 'num_reviews': 30, 'playtime_forever': 1427, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1427, 'last_played': 1536017614}
review: 7.0 out of 10.0. I was never a fan of GTA III but figured I would give it another shot in 2018. To be honest the story is pretty average as by this time the whole Mafia story line is pretty much all but played out now in 2018. The graphics did not age very well with this game very much. Now you can still manage however going even from GTA VICE CITY back to this is very noticeable. The fact that the main character does not talk at all is very odd and just brings down the story in general. Not many other choices like the other gta games either. I know that it’s unfair to compare this game to the others as this was the first open world GTA game developed but this review is reflected for the year 2018 not release. One big flaw running this game on windows 10 would be that I had to find a complete work around to be able to save and load the game properly but I’m even surprised this game is even able to be loaded for me to play at this point of its life. I would recommend this game only if it went on sale for $5.00 or less. Just not a huge fan on gta 3 but it’s ok.  The lack of choices ingame compaired to the other GTA games is one of the biggest downfalls I have for this GTA game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198064608698', 'num_games_owned': 160, 'num_reviews': 46, 'playtime_forever': 1326, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1325, 'last_played': 1535182130}
review:
The most nihilistic game of all time, far more than the other GTA games. Claude is a silent protagonist, we as the player only know he is a convict who's only real motivation is revenge. You as the player have no allegiance to anyone, you betray your bosses and have no sympathy who you hurt or steal from. Later GTA characters like Trevor, Niko, and Tommy all had real motivation behind their misdeeds that surprisingly went beyond just mayhem and therian lies the true beauty of GTA 3. Not once is the main character shown expressing any source of emotion or empathy. That fucking snake without a tongue quite literally steps over corpses of main characters to get to his next payday and will play any group against each other for his own gain.

Grand Theft Auto 3 is a sociopathic dream, all of the satire on the radio still holds a mirror to a technologically obsessed society of narcissistic reality tv addicts. Hell, you even end up killing the female lead Maria after spending 500k to get to her because she had some annoying dialogue. GTA 3 changed gaming forever and it did so with the player being an instrument of true evil. 

Take a 1000 mg of Equanox, crank the Rise FM and butcher some Columbians with 8 Ball in your bullet proof Cheetah already.

author: {'steamid': '76561198113101783', 'num_games_owned': 392, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 2516, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2277, 'last_played': 1630270136}
review:
I have many fond memories of playing this game on my dad's ps2 when I was 4, I never really tried to progress the story back then, I mainly just messed around with the physics, and tried to get as many stars as possible. But, not too long ago I revisited this game. I loved most of the game while playing it. Although the game does have some problems, which I was probably too ignorant to realize when I was younger. (I just want to go on record saying that I have beaten all of the missions). There is one Asuka mission in particular at the end of the game that is a real pain in the a**. Some of you might know what im talking about, but for those who dont im talking about the infamous, Expresso 2 Go mission. Im quoting GTA Wiki here, "Cruise Liberty's districts to find Espresso-2-Go stalls and destroy them." Now, this might not seem too difficult. But when you destroy your first expresso stand the timer starts ticking down, and you have to find the espresso stands yourself (the map doesn't tell you where the stands are). This means you have to drive around blindly looking for the stands. Thats bad enough but if you ram into the first 3 espresso stands your car catches on fire, and you're forced to get out, unless you want to kill yourself and fail the mission. Once you get out of your wrecked car you better find a replacement quick or else you lose precious time. There are 9 stands that you have to destory in total 5 on Staunton Island,   2 on Shoreside Vale, and another 2 on Portland. When you destroy an espresso stand you dont get any extra time or anything extra, the time continues to tick down, if you destroy all of the stands on an island you dont get any extra time either, this means once you take down all the stands on an island, you need to know where the nearest bridge or tunnel system is or you will waste some more precious time looking around for one. Overall the game is aight but the mission is f*****g donkey a** p***y likin dog d**k monkey c**k p***s s**t.

P.S. An easier way to do the mission is to find the stalls beforehand so they show up on the map, and go to portland to destroy the first stall, so you can destroy the stalls in a sort of sequence

author: {'steamid': '76561198293235835', 'num_games_owned': 90, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 20, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 20, 'last_played': 1513866310}
review:
i love grand theft auto 3, it was the the first game i had ever played and was bassically my childhood when i was in nursery. my dad had an old direct xbox (original xbox) and because i was so young i had no idea what to do and didnt actually complete any missions. The only thing i knew how to do was get the pistol that was on the bridge at the start of the game. and because i had no idea how to get to other missions, i replayed the same mission over again, which is why i actually called the game "you better drive brother" instead of gta because at the start of the game when you are on the bridge, that was what he would say. It would be fair to say this game was my childhood. 

So after i saw you could download it on steam i instantly bought it. That's where the problem began.

It wouldn't let me launch the actual game and instead would just crash. I had to enable direct x 9 and in doing so completely ruined my pc where the resoluton would remain in 640x480 so i had to reset my pc. 

If you are planning on buying this game with a computer above direct x 9 i wouldnt bother.

I think there are some emulators that run it better than the steam version, or you can just get it on console.

author: {'steamid': '76561198009584499', 'num_games_owned': 1261, 'num_reviews': 68, 'playtime_forever': 643, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 643, 'last_played': 1533637564}
review:
[h1][b]DISCLAIMER[/b][/h1]
[b]The review you are about to read is based on my own experience with the game and my own personal judgment and rating system! No third party has impacted anything said in this review. This review is also 100% spoiler free, so you don't need to worry about that either.[/b]

[h1][b]Gameplay and Movement Controls (18 out of 20)[/b][/h1]
[b]Let's first get this out of the way, this was the very first 3D GTA game and the developers did a pretty darn good job at it. Yes, you can't use your mouse to look around while driving. Yes, the movement controls are not as precise as they can be with some minor problems here and there. If you're expecting flawless gameplay experience and excellent control response that we have come to expect from modern games, you won't by any means get that in this game. This is a timeless classic and there are many problems with the movement where you'll more often than not find yourself reaching for a sprint or a big map buttons which simply aren't there. Cars are also going to blow up as soon as you hit someone or something a few times. While GTA3 lacks a lot of modern gameplay features it still manages to hold up and deliver an enjoyable experience throughout the entire game. This is a game that set the path for all sandbox and open-world games that came after it.[/b]

[h1][b]Graphics and Sound Quality (20 out of 20)[/b][/h1]
[b]Graphics are great considering that this game came out in the early 2000s. Yes, the texture quality isn't that great but there are a few mods that will help you improve the quality of the textures and graphics in general. GTA 3 has not aged well, and mods that are available out there for this game (are necessary) will take your experience to a whole new level. The soundtrack doesn't include a lot of songs so you will find yourself often listening to the same songs over and over again. Since I'm a big fan of Scarface, there's a radio station called 'flashback' which loops a few songs from the movie which I was listening to 95% of the time. As for the quality of the sound effects and audio in general, it holds up pretty well considering that this came nearly twenty years ago. If it wasn't for mods, I don't know if I'd find the courage to replay the game after all these years. Big thumbs up to the modding community. Voice acting is also perfect in general.[/b]

[h1][b]Performance and Optimization (16 out of 20)[/b][/h1]
[b]Oh, here we go. Performance is probably one of the worst things about this game. It really, totally and clearly wasn't meant to be played at framerate above 30. If you unlock the framerate then you're in for some nasty game breaking bugs such as cars not going in reverse, broken physics, crashes before the start of the missions etc. As for the optimization, it's a game that was released on PS2, so... not that demanding, but you can forget about 60 frames-per-second because it ain't happening. You'll be forced to play the game at 25-30 frames-per-second and that's it. I've seen some people locking it to 62 frames-per-second and making it run without problems - but I simply couldn't make it happen. Even locking it to 50 frames-per-second broke the game. Frame locking didn't really make much of a difference for me, they managed to make it playable and enjoyable even on low framerate due to the motion blur they added on top of everything.[/b]

[h1][b]Story and Replayability (14 out of 20)[/b][/h1]
[b]I can't say that the story isn't interesting, but it lacks that feeling that any of the characters are very important. The main character you're playing isn't even talking in the game, which is frustrating, at times. There's not much of replayability either since once you finish the story, there's not much you can do in the open-world of GTA3. There's just one last cutscene which plays out at the end and that's it - onto the credits. After the story finishes you can enjoy the free roam, but I'd rather drive around in GTA: San Andreas if I really have to and if my PC couldn't handle anything more modern.[/b]

[h1][b]Animations and Interaction (20 out of 20)[/b][/h1]
[b]I would be totally mistaken if I didn't say that the animations are awesome and done perfectly considering the number of resources the developer had at its disposal. There's one thing everyone needs to understand, that being the fact that GTA3 had to be released on the PS2. Interaction is decent, it's true that you don't have the access to a big map of the city, nor do you have any indications as to where are the things located on the map. Sometimes I've found myself driving to one part of the town just to realize that the mission I'm looking for is in a completely different city. That just adds up to the immersion and enjoyment that you have to actually think where you're going instead of just looking at the map all the time. I've just there and then realized how much actually we rely on the mini-map and GPS in modern games that we completely miss what's happening in the world around our characters. I will consider turning off the hud and the maps completely when I play such games from now on.[/b]

[h1][b]Final Score and Conclusion (88 out of 100)[/b][/h1]
[b]As the very first 3D GTA game I must say it's a great experience to see what the developers created from the ground up. I definitely would recommend you picking and playing this game if you haven't already. Since this is once in a lifetime experience for most people, if you finished it a long time ago, go on and jump into it once again to refresh your memories. It's simple, play it, enjoy every second of it and appreciate the fact that GTA3 made way for all the modern sandbox games.[/b]

author: {'steamid': '76561198262626587', 'num_games_owned': 527, 'num_reviews': 371, 'playtime_forever': 925, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 17, 'last_played': 1574815500}
review:
What Is GTA 3 ?

I still remember playing this one back then during the PS2 era when I was finished with VC and San Andreas just out of curiosity and while I do respect GTA3 for being a genre-defining and completely revolutionary back then, it became obsolete because of its sequels, they improved in every single aspect from GTA 3, unless you want to try it out of curiosity to see what the first 3D GTA game played like go for it, GTA3 is bland, the main character is a mute which is not a bad thing, however after what you saw what the series has become this at first is a huge turn off and the story doesnt help, the gameplay is very primitive compared to what it sequels offer and the lack of vehicle diversity is another annoyance, the mission design is also another flaw, GTA Vice City has made such a HUGE jump after 3 and pretty much set the bar for what future GTA games would be, 3 is not a bad game at all, infact, its a great game, just severely dated and overshadowed by its sequels especially Vice City which was built on the foundation that 3 was set on and went completely above it by imensurable ways, I've tried to finish GTA3 for years and I keep losing interest because of how dated it is and how it doesnt hold a candle to its sequels, which is understandable, I respect it but why I am writing this review ? simple I got the collection because I wanted to play VC and SA again which were my favorites ever and this came with them, so yeah unless youre someone curious about classic GTA stuff go for it, play GTA3 but if you dont want a bland, simplistic experience that got overshadowed by the improvements made in the future games, just ignore it, theres nothing to see in GTA3 at all, it belongs to a museum, youre interested into seeing how the first 3d GTA game is ? watch a video, playing this game is an absolute nightmare, games just like people can age and some do age pretty bad and faster than other games from their same period, just skip this.

author: {'steamid': '76561198097157198', 'num_games_owned': 56, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 5742, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1972, 'last_played': 1654414569}
review:
GTA III is the open world sandbox game that started it all in the modern era of games. I remember getting home from school and rushing to play the game and vent my frustrations of the day on the people of Liberty City, but as I grew up and played GTA 3 from time to time, I realized how good, innovative, and truly remarkable the game was.

I just finished playing it again today and I had always written off the story as inferior to Vice City and San Andreas, but after this latest playthrough, I really like how Dan Houser made all these factions and gangs in the story and how everything in the underworld of Liberty City revolves around the conflicts between these factions. You see some of it in Vice City and in the beginning of San Andreas, but by GTA 4 and GTA 5, the element of gangs and factions and the conflicts between them is largely removed.

GTA 3 plays great on the PC and looks as good as it can for modern times with HD screens and high frames per second. Turning off the frame limiter and driving around has never looked so smooth, it felt like I was playing a totally different game to what I played on the PS2 in 2001. I was surprised at how well it ran on modern PC's, so as long as you're using a Windows 7 or 8 system, I can tell you it should run just fine.

If you're ever feeling nostalgic or if you're a younger person who probably wasn't even born when this game came out (I can't believe I'm actually saying this) and you want to experience the beginnings of GTA, then GTA III is a must play. The music selection is really limited compared to later entries in the series and you can pretty much see each polygon that makes up the game world, but there's still fun to be had in GTA III.

( which is actually not true you might not get all your money back but whatever ) They unknowingly hype it up to become the must have game of the time. Playing it today brings back great memories of killing hookers, cursing the very exsistence of RC cars, listening to Flashback for the hottest jams or listening to Chatterbox and only vaugely getting all the jokes.

Anyone who complains about Wrong Side of the Tracks doesn't remember some of these extremely punishing missions though.

review:
Grand Theft Auto III on the pc is a videogame featuring mint juleps of spectators!
Enemies with sworn alliance unfair AI frequencies and sequences that jump you
a boulder to rage about!

It lifts a floppy area considerably a map with trickling centers that give
you the edge of rolling laughter and nostagia amazement!

The music is generally provided into different genres and its a
subside to alot of notes when the difficulty ramps up into a stable 
of misery spikes hitting your back with a leaning preference!

The gameplay is fun and charming with vehicles that can explode within seconds
and it really gives the challenge hint but i dont like galloping and crippling
graphics that are poorly designed and the simple minded gameplay can be frustuating
to alot of gamers!I raged on 20 missions total and it really blew my mind
into fury anger bits of punching a brick wall as i bleed with insanity measures!

Other then that if you like a height of extreme difficulty then this game is
right up your alley and on the list of being one of the best games of all time!

Good controls with blood-sugar servings!
All i can say is the game is dispensing pleasure to the most part!
If you can handle some wrecked gameplay that gives you a head thump
up your bummy apple pants then this game can really give you
a sensation of being a overall classic!

But if you like a game that is decently made to be fair and not complex!
Then pass this one up,play vice city or some other grand theft auto
to bitter your flexing tastes!

I give this game a 8.7/10 its good but i wish they took more time
to fix the errors what vice city and san andreas did and that is why
they're ultimate classics love the burrito master

review: I mean it was quite good, but then again it wasn't. I understand why I didn't think it was that good because I've played most of the newest ones and they have changed a lot. But seriously there were soo many problems 1)the cars catch on fire way to fast 2)There is no lock on aim 3) I had to do like 5 missions again which took me around 4-6 hours to complete 4)you have to play with the settings to be able to play it because when you load it up you can't see any of the options like Start game, New game or settings. but i mean it puts you into  a new game when you first play it so you can just go into the menu and change it then. Another big problem is, when you leave  Portland and do the first mission for the Yakuza, It is sooo dangerous to go back to that island because everybody is trying to kill you, but I guess its better than what it used to be, because one group doesn't have shotguns any more they just have micro-SMG's. But; like I said earlier on your cars blow up way to easy so it is a real pain having these groups attacking you. Also, a problem that only bothers me because I've played soo much GTA 5 (460 hours) it is really annoying that you cant flip your car back over. Oh! also a massive problem is the fact that you cant swim and there are so many boat missions, so if you fall in you are going to drown. To finish it's an alright game, the main reason why I had so much trouble with it is that I'm used to the newer GTA's where things are made so much easier for you. I would recommend if you've played other GTA games and not too long on GTA 5, but if you have only played gta5 and spent loads of time on it, then don't buy it unless you really want to. I also think it is the perfect price at the moment (£5.99) because for what you get, you probably won't regret it. Also because its such a challenge you will feel so good once you've finished it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198313282796', 'num_games_owned': 145, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 7691, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4505, 'last_played': 1608501049}
review: Ve yıl 2001… Liberty City’deyiz… Suçluların, kaçakların, kimseye acımayan mafyaların, çetelerin mesken tuttuğu karanlık bir şehirde… Kimseyle dost olunamayacağını, kimseye güven olamayacağını öğreneceğiniz acımasız ve tehlikeli bir şehirde… Kalabalık, metropol bir şehir olmasına rağmen kendinizi yalnız, tek başınıza hissedeceğiniz bir şehirde… Herkesin tek amacı para veya uyuşturucu olan bir şehirde… Ama biri hariç: Claude… Onun amacı ne para, ne uyuşturucu, ne de bu şehrin hâkimi olmak. Onun tek derdi, yıllar sonra kendisine tekmeyi basan sevgilisi Catalina’yı bulup hesap sormak… Bir intikam yolculuğuyla başladı Claude’un hikâyesi. Bu yolculukta kimi zaman mola verdi; pek çok insanla tanıştı, başka işlerle meşgul oldu. Ancak asıl hedefini hiçbir zaman unutmadı… Lafı daha fazla uzatmadan; işte Claude’un, işte Liberty City’nin, işte GTA III’ün hikâyesi…

author: {'steamid': '76561198040708449', 'num_games_owned': 794, 'num_reviews': 100, 'playtime_forever': 426, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 238, 'last_played': 1649197407}
review:
My first ever PC game, and i'm very happy with my choices. 

GTA III is set in a cold, dark city with 3 seperate islands. 

You play as Claude Speed, a man of few words, doing dirty work for some very unsightly people around the 3 islands.

Good replayability value, and lots to do alongside the normal story.

author: {'steamid': '76561198104392527', 'num_games_owned': 682, 'num_reviews': 334, 'playtime_forever': 2342, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2341, 'last_played': 1558746195}
review:
It's been a long time since I'd first played this game, but I still enjoy it like I remembered. This game definitely kicked off a trend of open-exploration / "free control" games, and it's easy to see why. GTA III wasn't exactly a big focus on the story. You have a good understanding of everything going on, but it's pretty bare-bones and sarcastic with nothing being too important.

And yet, the game is amazing fun for what it is. Played it with a few graphic updates and it's funny to see that even driving a car in this game seemed easier and less annoying than it did in GTA IV (at least to my memory).

There's not much I can say here for a "new" view on this game, something so popular for so many years. But I think it hit some good notes to really get the Grand Theft Auto series going fully. This game is definitely more difficult than some of the later games, but in some ways it is more weirdly "realistic" in that sense. One simple detail is that more difficult police show up earlier here than they seem to do in later games, which would make sense if you have a maniac on the streets.

And the other aspect is the gangs themselves: once you anger one, then their territory is now more dangerous for you. I like the aspect that the gangs remember you and will attack, but I don't like the fact that just driving any car through the area instantly triggers it. If I'm in some car with tinted windows, do I really want gangs to be clairvoyant and know that it's me? Thus it's a good idea with bad execution, but that's understandable given this is an earlier game.

All in all, I got 100% in this game and will be looping through the rest of the series again trying to do the same. Good fun to play again. Looks like I'll be in Vice City next!

author: {'steamid': '76561197983152533', 'num_games_owned': 749, 'num_reviews': 225, 'playtime_forever': 567, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 567, 'last_played': 1521060900}
review:
Some games get older like wine. This is not one of them.

When I was a kid in summer of 2002 there were 2 things I did. Played football outside and this with my then brand new computer. Dat nostalgiiaa!

However, when I decided to play this old school gta -games again I dare say that this one has not survived as well as Vice City and San Andreas and it is simple really: While the game was phenomeniall the story telling and the missions where quite blank, one-sided and linear. There is not much dialogue preventing to get introduced deeper in the characters and their dimensions. Moreover the jobs are always driving and shooting while in a VC there is much more diversity already.  The Taxi and Vigilante missions are there though and they are always fun.

GTA 3 is history, great milestone and open-world genre's godfather which always should be remembered as such. However its value of entertainement has faded in time and in its current state I cant recommend it so much anymore. However if you are a fan of the saga and still haven't played this I recommend to purchse this from sales just for references.

author: {'steamid': '76561198038047204', 'num_games_owned': 297, 'num_reviews': 58, 'playtime_forever': 940, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 940, 'last_played': 1525375539}
review:
The game is a mess by today's standards. I'm talking like, intended design (no map, no blips on radar) and overall physics and how the game caluclates things.

If you play above 30FPS, you're in for a treat; you can't reverse most cars, if you walk down a flight of stairs you're going to at least lose half of your health, if you play widescreen, your aim reticule is off.

I mean, on one hand, I still appreciate this game to this day it's old, It's still got charm - but how R* is still selling this as broken as it is, I have no idea. It's very legacy indeed and as such you need to read into it and modify stuff for at least 20 minutes if you want an optimal experience. As far as I know, there's no missions that break if you play beyond 30FPS, so the game is completable.

EDIT: Game broke at two seperate missions because the frame limiter was turned off, thanks a bunch Rockstar. So no - the game is not completable without turning it on at some points. But how is the user suppose to know when to toggle it on? I lost at least 3 hours out of my 16hrs played because of bullshit like dying because you walk down stairs and the unexpected crashes. I've listed the missions that crash below.

Mission  #1: S.A.M
Mission #2: last mission (by Catalina)

I heavily recommend installing the following:

[olist]
    [*]SilentPatch
    [*]Thirteennag's Widescreen fix
    [*]GInput (if you plan on using a controller)
    [*]1.1 patch (comes with Steam, not with retail versions)
[/olist]

Expect dated gameplay, it's a 2001 game, but for anyone that's a long time fan, it's a good couple of hours, there's like 70 story missions. Sadly, in the state it's being sold at the moment, I can't recommend a purchase.

author: {'steamid': '76561197995603429', 'num_games_owned': 225, 'num_reviews': 29, 'playtime_forever': 710, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 710, 'last_played': 1523913282}
review:
I recently did another run through the entire story, about 15 years after I last played this game. What an experience. I had completely forgotten the raw yet so amazingly pleasant experience this game has to offer, with its crude humour and really funny game mechanics. By standards of today, yes, this game is dated and clunky, but I'd still consider it a must and true pleasure for any fan of the GTA series. It's one of those old style games where you still need to memorize the map. Rather than limiting, I found that this increases the immersion. On average, the missions are also harder (even if often a lot simpler) than those of the more recent GTA games.

Note that you will need to install some patches to make it work on steam, but there are plenty of guides to get you started on that. Besides the silent patch and widescreen fix (which are essential), I also highly recommend that you install some additional mods. The limit adjuster increases the view distance drastically, making it much easier to navigate around the city. I also highly recommend the skygfx mod, which adds some extra special effects, as well as the ginput mod which allows you to enjoy the game properly with a gamepad (if you have one). With CLEO, you can also install the frame limiter patch, which allows you to play the game at 60 fps without having to suffer from physics bugs. Finally, there's also a CLEO mod for allowing camera control whilst driving (as in GTA IV and upwards), although I don't recommend that when playing through the missions as I found that it breaks at least one mission.

To conclude, despite the dated controls and graphics, I would still highly recommend this game, for its great story full of hilarious stereotypical characters, challenging gameplay, awesome map, and wonderful gameplay mechanics.

author: {'steamid': '76561198177338555', 'num_games_owned': 62, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 1442, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1442, 'last_played': 1513734970}

author: {'steamid': '76561198065542696', 'num_games_owned': 200, 'num_reviews': 39, 'playtime_forever': 898, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 898, 'last_played': 1524818521}
review:
Pros:
+ Interesting story with creative missions. If you've ever played a GTA game before, you'll know what you're in for with this title: Lots of killing rival gangs, planting car bombs, blowing up stuff, robbing banks, and so on.

+ Voice-acting is solid for the most part and the graphics are alright.

+ Sizeable map with tons of areas to explore and quite a number of side missions

Cons:
- Clunky controls, ESPECIALLY in gunplay. There's some sort of widescreen bug that causes your character to not shoot acurately so you need to compensate by aiming to the lower-left of your target. Plus, a lot of the better guns lock you in position when firing, so you can't run & gun, which is pretty silly and makes you super vulnerable to enemy fire. 

- Poor vehicle handling. Driving in this game is like running on an ice rink.

- No map in an open-world game, really?

- Bland protagonist. He doesn't talk at all and has no memorable traits whatsoever. He's pretty much just the errand boy, really.

- Game crashed once while I was doing a mission.

Verdict:
Despite its numerous flaws, it's still really fun completing the various missions and exploring the relatively big map. However, keep in mind that several of its features are pretty dated, and don't hold up well by today's standards. I still can't believe you can't access the map in an open-world game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198063860079', 'num_games_owned': 217, 'num_reviews': 33, 'playtime_forever': 2197, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1348, 'last_played': 1598484328}
review:
Unless it's for nostalgia or to complete your GTA collection, do yourself a favor and don't pick this game up. It's completely outdated, on all platforms. Even mods can't save this game. The story is good, the radio is good, and the atmosphere is great. But the gameplay itself is horrendous in this day and age.

 You'll frequently encounter bugs and issues more than you're able to beat the game. On top of everything else, there's no MAP.  This game is indeed a masterpiece and perhaps one of the most revolutionary games in history, but it doesn't automatically mean that it's a well aged game that comes close to today's standards. Save your money and purchase Vice City or San Andreas, at least those games are playable. You're not missing out on GTA 3, trust me.
