author: {'steamid': '76561198171679002', 'num_games_owned': 33, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 858, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 858, 'last_played': 1522024215}
review:
The only reason this game has mostly positive reviews is because of nostalgic players. 

Seriously, when this game came out 17 years ago, it was probably pretty revolutionary with its open world and near endless opportunities for mayhem. But that's pretty much where the fun wears off.

First and foremost, if you download this game through Steam, you'll need to download a third party patch just to be able to properly read the menus. This is absolutely unacceptable to release a game that can't even feasibly be played out of the box. 

The PC version of the game has terrible controller support, even with third party software emulating keypresses. It's so bad that I'll just tell you right now, don't even bother trying. Just use the mouse and keyboard. When you do, you'll realize that the person who set the default keyboard controls apparently never used an actual keyboard because the setup makes absolutely no sense and you will almost definitely need to reconfigure it to have anything close to a decent gameplay experience.

Let's get to the main issues that prevent me from enjoying this game. Well, GTA is a series known for allowing (and encouraging) you to engage in criminal mischief inside the virtual city that particular game takes place in. As a result, most of your time playing will be spent running away from the cops or maybe even going toe-to-toe with the police force (which is almost never a good idea in any of the games) and seeing how long you can survive. This is usually a lot of fun.

Not so much in GTA III. For one, losing your wanted level is nearly impossible once you get past 2 stars. Police will pursue you to the ends of the virtual earth and back again, and no matter which car you're driving, they will ALWAYS be able to catch up to you, and will ram your car into the next dimension until it explodes or you fly off a cliff and into the river. Attempting to drive anywhere with the cops on your tail is an exercise in extreme patience. You will be gnashing your teeth and cursing every time you try to move in a straight line only to be rear-ended by an invisible police vehicle and sent careening into a crowd of pedestrians, trying in vain to re-orient yourself toward your objective as every cop in the tri-county area charges you with the kind of fervor that is typically only witnessed by wild animals protecting their young from predators. I will say this, and I will say this with utmost confidence: it is simply NOT possible to clear your wanted level after 2 stars without picking up police bribes or using cheats. The upside to this is that when completing a mission clears your wanted level, you feel a mild sense of relief wash over you that I imagine is pretty close to what actual criminals feel when they successfully evade police in real life. Seriously, the cops in this game are BRUTAL.

The next issue I have with this game is that many of the missions simply don't tell you enough information about what you actually need to do. There is a mission later in the game where you are tasked with destroying coffee stands around Liberty City because they're actually acting as covers for drug dealers from a rival faction. Sounds simple enough, except no one tells you where these coffee stands are, much less that you actually have to traverse all three main areas of the city to find and destroy them all. And by the way, you have 8 minutes to do so. The only assistance you get here is that the targets will show up on your minimap once you get close enough, but unless you go online and find a map, you're basically driving around blind hoping that a little blue square pops up on your radar. Keep in mind this game was originally released before the internet was practically a household necessity, so I can only imagine what kind of fresh hell those poor folks had to endure back in the early 2000's.

While I was playing through the game, I never once felt any particular attachment to any of the main characters. I imagine this was different folks playing this game when it was first released, and it probably doesn't help that I was basically trying to push through the game as quickly as possible once I realized I wasn't enjoying it that much, but a lot of the story missions seem to try to force the player to make tough decisions regarding their allegiance that I just kinda of steamrolled through.

Bottom line is: GTA III has NOT aged well at all. If you're feeling nostalgic for an older GTA game, maybe try San Andreas or even Vice City.

review:
Game: Grand Theft Auto III
Genre: Sandbox Action
Developer: Rockstar North
Publisher: Rockstar Games
System: Steam (PC)
Year of Release: 2002
Length of Playthrough: 18 Hours

Total Score: 73/100
Value Score: 7.3/10

• Story: 7/10
• Characters: 7/10
• GamePlay: 6/10
• Graphics: 6/10
• Sound: 8/10
• Music: 7/10
• Length: 7/10
• Replay Value: 8/10
• Player Value: 7/10

[u]Pros[/u]
+Multiple costumes
+Decent story and cast of characters
+Big size world for time of release spread across 3 sections which gets unlocked

[u]Cons[/u]
-No in game map (you have to rely on the radar)
-Icons for shops, etc disappear and you have to manually find shops like for ammunition
-Limited cheats (Vehicles) unless you use mods
-Usage of mods requires some third party programs
-Mods need to be enabled to use controller properly and to have weather effects
-Frustrating missions - some of the hardest missions in the series

author: {'steamid': '76561198255924552', 'num_games_owned': 333, 'num_reviews': 58, 'playtime_forever': 1470, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1470, 'last_played': 1520549040}
review:
A frustratingly difficult and brutal, yet highly satifying and very fun game. Solid soundtrack (I'm looking at you Flashback FM), amazing story (didn't see any of those twists coming) and some very interesting characters. Ironically, the silent protagonist Claude is the most interesting, as his motives and actions are so unpredictable; which make him such a brilliant and dark character. 

If I had to rate this I'd give it a 9/10, only losing one mark due to how insanely fragile cars and how annoying the controls are at times, even when using a ps4 controller.

author: {'steamid': '76561197987435696', 'num_games_owned': 519, 'num_reviews': 20, 'playtime_forever': 577, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 577, 'last_played': 1516747778}
review:
I did this game on the PS2 back in the days and I finished the main game with this Steam version.
I recommend it, but it's more because of my nostalgia than anything else.

The game is old now and didn't age well at all: clunky controls, poor music choice (although I like some of it), bad sounds (no work has been done here for this version), bad graphics (again, no work done here for this version), scenario not interesting at all (personally, I don't care in GTA games).

Besides all these cons, I still enjoyed doing this game again. It was the first GTA in 3D and still has the vibes of GTA 1 & 2 in its ambiance. (BTW, if you never played GTA 1 & 2, try them ASAP). I had a good experience and I will probably play this game again in the future.

If you didn't play it back in the days, I don't say I'd recommend it as its gameplay will probably frustrate you (especially if you played any of the more recent GTA games)

author: {'steamid': '76561198176959619', 'num_games_owned': 168, 'num_reviews': 58, 'playtime_forever': 382, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 378, 'last_played': 1521973366}
review:
I'm glad the atmosphere is so compelling in this game.  There are so many gameplay issues you can't take missions seriously at all.  I die every five minutes because of the horrible camera, or random events like a citizen pulling me out of my car in the middle of a car chase mission.  Or get to the end of mission and...SUPRISE you need to be drivng a Traid fish van to finish.  Driving through the city to start a mission and BOOM a van sideswipes me out of nowhere, I'm driving slowly, but I instantly flip upside down causing the car to explode like it was full of semtex.  I'm only done about ten missions and the music is already getting too repetitive. 

I know it's a timeless classic, but it is looking (and playing) really bad by today's standards.  The epic voice actors are the only thing keeping my interest in playing.

author: {'steamid': '76561198301359776', 'num_games_owned': 233, 'num_reviews': 24, 'playtime_forever': 532, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 387, 'last_played': 1519480134}
review:
This game was good for it's time but it really didn't age well since there is no check points in missions or restarting them so you have to walk 15 minutes to the same place to start the mission over and over and over again which is really really really frustrating

Most of the missions are time limited and very hard so with no checkpoints and restarting missions you waste a lot of your time

There's no camera movement while driving and everyone on the streets attack you AND THERE'S NO MAP VIEWING(meaning you don't know where the f*ck you are half the time)

Aiming was terrible for me too

review: This game was a technical marvel and breath of fresh air when it first launched in 2002. However I'm still gonna give this a thumbs up for the game that helped popularize the sandbox game genre.

review: Wow, this plays terribly on my Alienware Aurora GTX 1080 Win10.  Invible Menus until you Alt+Tab or Xbox Button on controller, and even then they are really faint.  For that reason, it makes configuring the controls nearly impossible.  I can only barely control this game with an xbox controller.  I tried using Controller Companion which usually helps in most cases, but with the menus barely visible, I can't even determine & map all the keyboard settings well.  The on-screen map flickers sometimes, some lights flicker, and in the few seconds I played it, I saw a glitch where a gun wasn't in someone's hand, just floating there (or maybe a hand was missing).  In any case, I decided it isn't worth it.  In my opinion, this game shouldn't be for sale on Steam anymore if it plays this badly on modern PCs, or Steam should help fix it.

author: {'steamid': '76561197973644224', 'num_games_owned': 930, 'num_reviews': 42, 'playtime_forever': 1655, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1624, 'last_played': 1518039443}
review:
The [i]Grand Theft Auto[/i] game series should only have limited appeal to me, given its reputation for gratuitous violence, amoral acts, unpleasant characters, you-name-it. Having dipped into [i]Grand Theft Auto V[/i], I decided to give the series a try, starting with [i]Grand Theft Auto III[/i]. You play the role of minor gangster who works for various criminal organizations, going on missions to steal and/or kill, and usually driving around the city in a stolen vehicle above the speed limit, through red lights, through pedestrians. Although the game is a bit dated in 2017, it introduced me to many innovative, calling-card features of the series. Although the crass presentation and heavy emphasis on stereotypes is not intended to be taken too seriously, I can understand why some players might be put off. For my part, I found the game entertaining and humorous (in a rated R kind of way) and even challenging at times.

[b]Gameplay[/b]
Combat and movement on foot were a bit awkward in this game but also in-line with other games from the same time period. On the other hand, driving around in the city was surprisingly fluid and responsive, aside from a few glitches and camera angles. Most of the game involves undertaking tasks from various gang leaders, and these tasks frequently involve driving from one location to another or performing tasks while driving around the city: the kind of stuff you would expect a low level gangster to do on behalf of Tony Soprano (plus the token stolen vehicle). Although the missions are pretty basic on the surface, most are actually quite fun, perhaps within the greater context of the story and the setting. And quite a few missions are downright challenging, which can be an issue since there is no way to adjust difficulty.  I was able to complete all the main missions (and phone missions) in the game, albeit with some help from the internet for the more challenging ones.

[b]Characters/Customization[/b]
The protagonist, Claude, is a low level gangster who is hired by a number of shady characters throughout the game to do their dirty work. If you want to get picky about his story, you argue that there does not seem be any real motivation for him to do these favors for them (except perhaps a long game of revenge), but he does them nonetheless, perhaps for the money, except he doesn't really buy anything in the game, except weapons and ammo (and new paint jobs for his vehicles). So, yes, he is pretty forgettable - I probably will not remember his name next week - but there are other characters voiced by Hollywood stars, but I would not call any of them particularly memorable either, even if you recognize the talent behind their voices. The best characters in the game - by far - are the DJs on the various radio stations that you can listen in your car. And while some of the music does get repetitive after 27 hours of play, the songs, commercials, and soundbites are surprisingly catchy and entertaining. 

[b]Story/Atmosphere[/b]
The story is set in a fictional American city that is subdivided into three major areas connected by tunnels and bridges. The city design is phenomenal. There were times when I was hoping for a map that I could pull up beyond just the minimap, but over the course of the game you become pretty familiar with the layout. It is effectively an open-world setting. At the start of the game Claude is betrayed by his partner during a heist and is sent to prison. After he escapes, he continues his life of crime by working for various gangsters. The city, the gangsters, and the radio stations cover the whole ethnic spectrum of American society where each group is represented by its criminal stereotypes (e.g. Japanese Yakuza, Italian Mafia, Colombian Cartel, crooked cops, etc.). There really are no good guys in this game.

[b]Graphics/Sound[/b]
Graphics are a bit dated in [i]Grand Theft Auto III[/i], but the sound and especially the music are excellent. There were a few visual glitches here and there but no gamebreaking bugs that I recall. I did apply one of the unofficial patches through the Steam community.

[b]Replay Value:[/b] The cities of [i]Grand Theft Auto III[/i] are basically an open-world setting, and you could just go drive around, mess around, even after completing the main story. My Stats say that I only completed 42% of the content, so clearly I left a lot of optional challenges and content undone. But rather than stick around in GTA III, my plan is to move onward to Vice City. 

[b]Overall Score:[/b] 7/10

[i]Played in 2017-2018.[/i]

author: {'steamid': '76561198386499036', 'num_games_owned': 359, 'num_reviews': 35, 'playtime_forever': 556, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 397, 'last_played': 1551543272}
review:
GTA III takes place in Liberty city, in the year of 2001, and we play as a silent bank robber named Claude, that was betrayed and shot by his girlfriend, and after escaping a prison transport, he wants revenge.

+ it was a MASSIVE revolution in the open world games back in 2001, blew everyone's minds and shaped the industry to the open world era and the "GTA clones".
+ First GTA ever to be fully 3D 
+ Good graphics for the time (looks dated now, but tolerable)
+ Great gameplay for the time
+ Good arcade driving physics
+ Rockstar's first try of a story for the GTA series, and even if it's not great like later games, it was a nice start, with charismatic characters and voice dialog
+ The open world, now considered tiny, felt HUGE at the time
+ Good selection of weapons
+ Opponents can be dismembered by shots, something that is only possible in this game on the GTA series so far
+ Iconic cars like the banshee, Infernus and the Stallion were born in this game
+ There is a plane on the game, named "dodo" (a bird that couldn't fly), and it fits the name very well, since flying this thing is a challenge on its own. It's basically a minigame.
+ Nice soundtrack (Flashback FM is the best radio station, with the whole scarface movie soundtrack)
+ huge mod community



- Missions get quite hard at the end and can be frustrating, because of the respawn system (the hardest 3d game of the series IMO)
- You can't swim
- Motorbikes, helicopters, and planes (proper planes) were not present yet
- gets stretched visuals on widescreens (To fix this I recommend the widescreen Patch by ThirteenAG)
- The shotgun and M16 are very OP, and can kill you or blow up your car in a few shots (annoying on late game)
- by the end of the game, mostly everyone hates you, and cruising the map in certain areas can be very dangerous and annoying

I also recommend the "silent patch", by silent, that fixes many bugs of the game
Overall, this is a piece of video game history, a masterpiece of the early 2000's , a must have for GTA fans and fans of open world games in general

review:
The main character is a role model of all bad a**es.

What does he do when someone tells him to steal something?

He nods his head.

What does he do when someone tells him to plant a bomb somewhere?

He nods his head.

What does he do when someone tells him to slaughter dozens of murderous criminals all by himself?

He nods his head.

What does he do when someone screams at him to finish some impossible task or he'll be put to death?

He nods his head.

And what does he do when his ex-girlfriend who has tried to leave him for dead or murder him a bunch of times gets in a chopper and tells him she's going to destroy him??

HE NODS HIS FUARKING HEAD.

author: {'steamid': '76561198053795456', 'num_games_owned': 116, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 748, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 748, 'last_played': 1516602233}
review:
This game is... almost 100% pain. Hasn't aged well at all. Played up until mission [spoiler]'Bait'[/spoiler] and gave up afterwards, referring to Youtube to complete the story. Gameplay and mechanics are irritating and Liberty City is quite boring. Dissapointing considering the praise it gets. Here's some key points:
[list]
[*]Graphics and animations are semi-decent
[*]Main plot is underwhelming
[*]Lacks relevant features including map, map markers ([spoiler]Pay'n'Spray and Ammunation[/spoiler]), ability to swim, bailing and shooting out of cars and more
[*]Poor game choices including constant street gang attacks, overpowering weapons ([spoiler]M16 and pump-shotgun[/spoiler]) and police AI
[*]Radio stations are repetitive and forgettable, aside from [spoiler]Game Radio and perhaps Chatterbox[/spoiler]
[*]Worldspace has lifeless atmosphere and lacks individuality
[*]Not much worth exploring or doing aside from main storyline
[*]Game also has widescreen issues, missing console features and many bugs, but can be settled with the 'GTA III Reborn' patch; [b]a must have[/b] if you intend on playing
[/list]
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=720574899

author: {'steamid': '76561198003174259', 'num_games_owned': 1663, 'num_reviews': 299, 'playtime_forever': 52, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 52, 'last_played': 86400}
review:
[h1] The Classic GTA [/h1]

[b] What I Liked [/b]

Clocked in dozens of hours on the console, so that's why I picked it up here.

[b] What I Did Not Like [/b]

Well, it's dated.  The gameplay is there, but the graphics aren't.

[b] Why I Stopped Playing [/b]

I made this purchase based on nostalgia, and that's it.  I don't recommend buying it for that reason, only if you want to play the game that started it all for the GTA series.

[b] Disclaimer [/b]

I have been a gamer for over 30 years.  I tend to play mostly PC games.  I also bounce around between games A LOT.  I may purchase a $60 game and play it for 2 hours or spend $10 on a game and spend 50 hours on it.  Even if I played a game a short time, it does not mean it is bad.  It just means another game caught my attention.  I also complain about flaws in games a lot, even about the littlest of things.  Keep that in mind when reading my reviews.  If I do not have a complaint, then the game must be special!

author: {'steamid': '76561198353978732', 'num_games_owned': 167, 'num_reviews': 52, 'playtime_forever': 991, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 773, 'last_played': 1520615141}
review:
Honestly, being the first game in the GTA franchise to take place from a third person perspective, use 3D graphics, and not just be a cops vs. robber, you can't expect much out of this. It came out in 2001 for the PlayStation 2 and original Xbox so obviously it aged very terribly as one can easily tell from the blocky crapfest of graphics, slippery driving and terrible shooting controls, and extremely hard or super easy missions (mostly just driving and killing). There just isn't much content that you can enjoy off of and this pales in comparison to later games like Vice City and San Andreas with more content, better controls and gameplay, extensive settings and plot, and have withstood the test of time more. 

To be fair, the voice acting and execution of the cinematic cutscenes are well done and ahead of its time as you wouldn't expect such good presentation from 2001. Also, many of the issues that myself and others complain (i.e., game-breaking bugs) are only exclusive to the Steam version whereas the remastered ports for console and mobile have better visuals, controls, etc. After all, this was the first GTA game to try something different and would later be expanded and improved upon in Vice City and especially San Andreas. But hey, at least this game works after some work arounds with the files unlike the PC port of GTA IV.

I wouldn't really recommend nor not recommend this, but sadly seeing how there doesn't exist a "neutral" option when making these reviews, I have to recommend against this game. Just buy this game on a sale if you really want to play this game, though better to just save your money and buy the newer GTA games (except IV because of its poor optimization) instead. Or you can just buy GTA 3 on the Google Play or Apple Store which RockStar actually optimized it for more modern systems. Speaking of optimization, you'll need to configure your PC or even tweak the files before even playing as this was meant to be only played on Windows XP and older OS.

review:
Game is absolutely amazing, till you realize how shit the mechanics of the game are. There are some missions, where you either get melted by auto aim bots, or the physics of a car put you in a non stop flip and you blow up. I grew up with this game without playing the missions, and i enjoyed it. But the missions are just absolute garbage, and extremely boring. 

Pros:
Childhood game
Its GTA!

Cons:
Its an old ass game, so dont expect much!
Game mechanics.
Extremely buggy when you mess with the display settings. (download zipfile to fix menu and load times and also fixes some in game bugs.)

author: {'steamid': '76561198068978307', 'num_games_owned': 817, 'num_reviews': 51, 'playtime_forever': 817, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 409, 'last_played': 1578975352}
review:
If you have Windows 10, Get a Patch and you're good to go.
Some aspects of the shooting haven't aged well. Plus, the driving feels like you're on ice. 
But there's something magical about playing GTA III again.
It's aged like swiss cheese honestly, but it's still pretty tasty. 
Just exploring this incarnation of Liberty City again is beautiful honestly.
Also hearing stuff like "Yup I've been drinking again" or "In the navy!" Takes you back to a much more simplier time.
When video games were getting more advanced but we were blurring that fine line between advancement and nostalgia.
Overall, purchase GTA III to see a relic of how modern video games have shaped up to be in nearly 17 years.

author: {'steamid': '76561197978907605', 'num_games_owned': 610, 'num_reviews': 80, 'playtime_forever': 201, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 182, 'last_played': 1554857605}
review:
There's a couple of mods that you should probably get just to make it somewhat more playable (in terms of controls and UI and resolution type stuff), but it's still a pretty solid game.

It doesn't exactly live up to the nostalgia obviously. You'll probably play this game for an hour or so before having an itch to play the newest GTA game. It's sad, but these games didn't really age well and a lot of the mechanics are overly punishing. Like, I don't remember this as a kid, but good luck completing most of the later missions without failing them a dozen times first. I totally forgot how unforgiving this game was.

Still fun, and usually on really deep sales, and for that reason alone I can recommend it.

I still have an audio issue I can't resolve. It's almost like when there's too many things taking up the channels the audio crackles (ie: if I have the radio on, I crash into a pole while simultaneously hitting a person, the person's scream/shout will crackle like hell.) It's very possible the original game was like that, both on PC and on PlayStation, but it's a bit annoying and doesn't feel good for my speakers.

If you didn't play through this game previously, like in your childhood, you'll probably really not enjoy it. Most younger people who see this (who have played modern GTA's) think it's really unfair and antiquated. And I mean, it is, but it's historical and kinda neat in its own right.

author: {'steamid': '76561198397718315', 'num_games_owned': 103, 'num_reviews': 36, 'playtime_forever': 3645, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3579, 'last_played': 1513392922}
review:
I really like this game,this wonderful classic game,and this is the first time I play it.I have only played GTA Vice City when I was a kid(GTA3 was released in 2001 and GTA Vice City was released in 2002).

Pros:
+I had to try to adapt to its graphics of old times for a few hours,then I found this game is really fun.as the gameplay itself is similar with the sequels,I think its graphics won't be a big problem if you want to play it nowadays.
If you love gta5,I think you will also love gta3 only if you can adapt to its graphics.
+Wonderful story-line with many interesting missions,some missions are a little difficult,and you can finish the mission by different ways.
+A big and well designed opening world map which depicts the whole city of Liberty City(is that city real?).
+There are many gangs in the game,such as Italian Mafia,Triad in China Town,Japanese Yakuza,Columbia,Yardie,every gang has its unique cars and outfits...So you get more enemies except cops. 
+There are many hidden contents waiting for you to explore on the map.weapons、money、hearts、stars...That's fun.
+Many kinds of weapons and cars.
+Awesome raido songs! I love the songs "I am hot tonight" and "She is on fire".

Cons:
-Can't check the map of the whole city in the game,and many important places aren't marked on the mini-map. 
-Can buy guns in the shop,but can't buy and change outfits in the game.

Pros or Cons:
+/-The protagonist Claude never said even a single word.

Overall rating:9.2/10
Honestly,gta3 is outdated now,but it is one of the best games in 2001.and if you can adapt to its graphics,this game is still very fun to play.

author: {'steamid': '76561198036824329', 'num_games_owned': 316, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 23, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 23, 'last_played': 1334127600}
review: "Grand Theft Auto III" is a classic that created a whole new genre of video game that dominates the industry today. I first played this game on the PS2 when it was still fairly new and spent dozens and dozens of hours playing it to full completion. While it looks and plays fairly crudely in 2017, I believe it is still a worthwhile use of your game-play time. It remains a fun experience once you get back into the 2001 mindset. The atmosphere and world building is still impressive today as well as the amount of missions and side-quests to accomplish.

author: {'steamid': '76561198072061907', 'num_games_owned': 365, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 4937, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1861, 'last_played': 1644224198}
review:
Grand Theft Auto III is the perfect example of a groundbreaking title that still is just as enjoyable today. Arguably the most controversial game of 2001 and the first massive success in the video game industry of a post 9/11 world, GTA III is a game about revenge, murder and chaos. Set in the fictional New York-inspired Liberty City, you take control of a mute named Claude. He and his girlfriend Catalina are escaping from a bank heist when she turns on Claude, shooting him and leaving him on the ground for the police to find minutes later. A few days later while on a transfer to the city's detention centre a car intervenes with the convoy and frees the prisoners while also managing to destroy the bridge the event took place on. 

The game contains a great open world that was extremely impressive back in the year of release. It has a good story but admittedly it's not very in-depth. The soundtrack is full of fantastic songs from the main theme's relaxing piano to the various radio stations filled with a selection of liscensed and original tracks. The graphics are still pretty decent by today's standards but the character models have not aged that well. There is oodles of activities and situations to get yourself into in Liberty City.

Overal this game is a masterpiece that will keep you playing for a long time and it's something I can reccomend even to detractors of the sandbox genre.

review: This game put GTA on the map for me.  It was light years ahead of GTA II in every way.  If you want to go back to the roots of the GTA franchise, you should play this game.  It might be considered easy by today's standards but has a great storyline with a lot of famous voice actors.  Graphics look impressive for its age & it won't take you years to complete.

author: {'steamid': '76561197994235337', 'num_games_owned': 585, 'num_reviews': 54, 'playtime_forever': 978, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 978, 'last_played': 1510464013}
review: I'm not sure why i decided to install gta 3 and play it but i'm glad I did. I have fond memories of playing it on the ps2 and returning to it on the pc I had a blast. The graphics are obviously a little lacking, you start seeing the same pedestrians and cars quite frequently and objects in the distance pop in and out all the time. Once you get past that and the bumpy start to getting it running well on pc the actual gameplay is a lot of fun. Missions for the different groups, doing your own thing stealing cars, attacking various people finding strange places and secret packages and a story that escalates in an interesting way is all pretty good. My main issue playing the game was aiming weapons with the controller i'm using but you get used to it.

author: {'steamid': '76561197979568263', 'num_games_owned': 457, 'num_reviews': 283, 'playtime_forever': 2721, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 336, 'last_played': 1590095502}
review:
I may have spent a lifetime in Liberty City. I couldn't stop playing it and exploring every nook and cranny. Hell, even searching for hidden packages was addictive, after all you had freedom! I also remember how humours it was, taking into account this is a trademark in the series, nevertheless GTA 3 had a darker, more industrial and lethargic feel to it. This game was fantastic and still is considering how much of a game changer it was. What The Matrix was to the movies, GTA 3 was to the gaming industry. The soundtrack got me into drum & bass and dub as well, driving away from the cops while listening to MSX and chilling with K-Jah. 

Highly recommendable classic.

review:
The best version of GTA III out there. Though the Xbox version has slightly better graphics, GTA III for PC controls a thousand times better, since the concept of free aim and camera control were apparently foreign in early 2000s console titles.

Much more playable than console versions, but nothing mindblowing if you have already played it elsewhere.

review:
The first "real" GTA as we know it today.  So much better than the top-down GTA and GTA 2.

8/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198238867674', 'num_games_owned': 169, 'num_reviews': 26, 'playtime_forever': 68, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 36, 'last_played': 1505334124}
review:
If you ever see the GTA Trilogy go on sale and think it's a steal of a deal, it's not. 

The only game that was a semi-competent port is San Andreas. GTA III and Vice City are god awful on Steam.

Controller support is awful. Yeah, I can plug in my Xbox 360 controller and I can move around and everything, but I can't look around, and the buttons are all jumbled around. B is to accelerate, A is to shoot, Select is to change the radio, clicking left stick changes the camera? Awful.

And the graphics settings are terrible. There's only draw distance, frame limiter, widescreen, and resolution. The game looks atrocious. Literal PS1 textures, what in the hell. They don't use the Xbox version's textures, and they even removed some things too!

Those reasons alone are good enough for me to say don't buy this game, emulate it for free. 

If you ever see the GTA trilogy on sale, just get San Andreas on its own. Even then, I barely recommend that awful port, bt it's not as bad as this one. Only get this if you don't mind using the keyboard and mouse, and don't mind the ugly textures.

Great game.
----------
~Pros~
One of the best GTA games (apart from SA and 5)
--

--
Missions are great.

---------
~Overall~

review:
This game is really good, but it's sad when the PC port is the worst version, the PS2 version is less polished, but looks nicer, the XBOX version is amazing. I'd recommend buying the XBOX port, this is still a good game, but it feels rather dated, even compared to Vice City, cause it suffers from the problem GTA IV had, where everything is brown, black, gray, and rather dull.

Bottom line, you should play this game, but it's probably the worst port. Worse as in a little bit. Not Doom 32x bad.

author: {'steamid': '76561198059193121', 'num_games_owned': 153, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 1601, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1601, 'last_played': 1505865474}
review:
The story follows the notorious tiger pocher, Angus del Varen. On his adventure to the city Brazzaville, of Congo. On a lone job to catch a beloved local tiger, he is caught by rights groups and is sent to prison. He is bailed out by a mysterious benefactor known only as "Jade". She strikes a deal. If he catches 2 female tigers and a rare male albino, his debt is considered repayed. The first poach goes smoothly but he miscalculates the sedative. The tiger escapes his van and runs through the city until it is captured by a woman in a green dress. The benefactor tells him the catch was close enough and the tiger is now in her custody. The next poach starts with a rival gang, the Wet Vipers, in the downtown area sabotaging his gear. After all his gear is defected, Angus is forced to kill the co-leader of the Wet Vipers using only a sharpened ivory toy and then abduct the tiger barehanded. Suspecting trouble, Jade sends the girl in the green dress once again. This time they take down the tiger together and she kisses Angus before flying away with the tiger in a helicopter. Angus demands answers from Jade. She declines but the assistant calls his cell phone anyway. They arrange a date. She discloses her name: Angel. She knows about his debt and would like to help him capture the albino which is now in captivity. They go back to Angus' apartment, filled with supplies and they have sex after planning the next job. The next morning they both gear up and head to the enclosure housing the albino tiger. An elaborate plan to sneak in as a animal caretaker and a vet goes as planned until the Wet Viper leader arrives posing as another vet. A shootout in the tiger enclosure leads to Angel shot in the arm and the Wet Viper leader dead. Viper goons begin entering the captivity and forcing staff out at gunpoint. Angel asks him to take the albino tiger and leave her. He declines, stating that he is in love with her. He picks her up and shoots his way out the back entrance. In a wild car chase they lose the Vipers and police. Angus takes his new love to the hospital where she recovers fully in 4 days. When she is able to leave, Angus admits they cannot be together because he did not capture the 3rd tiger and thus cannot pay his debt to Jade. He walks away and returns home, quickly packing to flee the country. When he arrives to his most recent stolen car, Angel is sitting in the passenger seat. He tells her let him go. She grabs him and kisses him, revealing that she is Jade and that the debt is repayed because he saved her. They flee to Nigeria and start a new life.

Also the steam moderator who deleted my last review can eat my ass

author: {'steamid': '76561198074690200', 'num_games_owned': 898, 'num_reviews': 144, 'playtime_forever': 1129, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1129, 'last_played': 1500328436}
review:
+ The map looks really nice, feels like an actual place and feels bigger than the VC map due to verticality
+ The cars control really well, in my opinion better than in SA and VC
+ The radio stations (except for the horrible sounding techno-reggae station) all sound great 
+ Pretty easy to mod
+ Dismemberment System from Soldier of Fortune due to the usage of the GHOUL engine
+ Mostly great voice acting
+ Great cutscenes
+ Some really well made missions

- Not a port of the Xbox version which had actual shaders and a bunch of other improvements
- Pretty bad PC port (Easy to fix that with mods though)
- The lack of an actual Map is incredibly annoying, I'd rather have no minimap and a real map.
- Some missions don't show you the actual objective and you have to find it yourself (which becomes quite tedious without an actual map
- Some missions are unneccesary difficult due to rètarded A.I or just feel not that well thought out in general 
- Every radio station only has 5 songs and about 3 voice lines, the Radio stations also all have atrocious sound quality 
- The cutscenes before missions are incredibly brief and characters mostly say in 2 words what you need to do, the lack of exposition hurts the already bad story even more.
- Claude's motivations aren't really comprehensible, he doesn't act the same way consistently [spoiler] Claude is a cold hearted killer the whole game and doesn't care about anything but money but in the end he suddenly cares for a woman that he never showed any emotions for and starts collecting money to ransom her out? [/spoiler]  ( a problem later GTA games also have) 
- The game in general feels quite unfinished, when flying over Skyscrapers you will notice that many of them don't have an actual roof and the ones that do mostly only have a cosmetic roof you can't stand on because it has no collision, scattered over the entire map there are white lines visible where two parts of the map come together, the game always hardcrashes at certain locations (Leone's house after [spoiler] he dies [/spoiler]) which makes a certain mission unbeatable unless you cheat.
- The lack of the ability to swim isn't a problem in VC due to water only being between the two cities but here it is because Liberty City has quite a lot of rivers that you can accidentally fall (or drive) into and while I almost never died to water in VC I died to water in GTA 3 quite often. Also since there's no option to jump out of a moving car, you can't escape in the last moment like you can in VC.
- It's pretty short and the story is just good enough to not be atrocious.
- Absolutely no memorable characters

Overall this game was a good entry into the 3D universe but it's not necessarily worth playing even if you're a GTA fan. It was probably a 9/10 back in 2001 but gets dragged down by parts incredibly awful mission design and definitely didn't age as well as San Andreas or even Vice City.
5,5/10.

author: {'steamid': '76561198040948764', 'num_games_owned': 207, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 230, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 148, 'last_played': 1523480728}

author: {'steamid': '76561198342591034', 'num_games_owned': 73, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 13, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 13, 'last_played': 1500060601}
review: GTA games like these were the best. It was not confined to gaming physics, not obsessed by making things life-perfect. It was about a man with a cube hand, a cylindrical rocket launcher, a car that steers like a housefly with a pentagon shaped steering wheel. It was about the crap mouth to voice sync. It was about being a little kid killing people. It was about doing the most heinous crimes in the most magnificent way possible. Sometimes, crap is better. It is not a HD game abiding by the laws of physics. But boy is it amazing!!! Although the graphics seem dated by today's standads, for many, this was their first introduction to the Grand Theft Auto franchise. To myself and many others, this game and the others bundled within the Trilogy Pack, will forever hold a special place in my history of gaming :') Peace!!

author: {'steamid': '76561198089251936', 'num_games_owned': 278, 'num_reviews': 20, 'playtime_forever': 7, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 7, 'last_played': 1499152511}
review:
I remember playing this game a lot when it first came out. It was fun and exploring an open world, at the time, was something completely new and fresh, Obviously the open world aspect is nothing new anymore but I still recommend this game if you are nostalgic for that time, like me.


However


if you intend on playing this game with a controller, you are better off playing one of the console versions. Like, say, the Playstation Two version, for example. I tried playing it with my wired Xbox 360 controller and let me tell you, the controller support for this game sucks. You can't control the camera and barely any of the buttons work. Not to mention the controller menu doesn't do a good job of listing anything. Everything goes by numbers and shit. Now I know what you're thinking "Well this game is really old. Of course it would go by what those controllers had back than" and let me say Postal Two is just as old and it does a good job of showng what does what. X button is X button. Left Trigger is Left Trigger. All it would take is a small update and badda bing-badda boom, you can tell what does what.



In general, if you are nostalgic and want a trip to the past, buy it. But if you intend on playing with a controller, look elsewhere.

author: {'steamid': '76561198323225723', 'num_games_owned': 199, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 596, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 8, 'last_played': 1635878865}
review:
Grand Theft Auto was use to be an arcade type of game in the 90's, but it wasn't so much popular as it is today. Grand Theft Auto III changed gaming for the best! This game took elements from the first four games and expanded further from 2D to 3D, and from Arcade to an Open World. This game is amazing! The story is really great, the missions were awesome, the characters have great personlities, and the best part about this game is that you can freely do whatever you want. Kinda like the last few entries.

I would highly recommened this game to anyone who has never played a GTA game. The game is dated, but there's a lot of replayability with it! A ture classic of the series! I wonder if Take Two ever plan a remake of this game. If that happens, I'll flip!

The only problem I have with this game are the controls though. Using a Dualshock 4 works but the only problem is that there's no option for you to control the camera on the remote. The only way to control it is the mouse and I find it very uncomfortable to use the DS4's touchpad to control the camera, so I wouldn't reconmmend using it. 

Buy this game! You'll never be disapointed!

author: {'steamid': '76561198399056278', 'num_games_owned': 14, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 354, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 352, 'last_played': 1564594860}
review:
It feels so primitive playing all these years later. Every adjacent game added more and more features, while also fixing several issues. Though this was a massive upgrade from the first 2 games, it's hard to tell if it's aged poorly or not.

On the contrary, the PC version is infinitely better than the PS2/PS3 versions. The graphics, framerate, and features are all a step up. I somehow managed to nearly 100% this on the PS3 despite it's sloppy performance. Considering how cheap this is, and the fact that you can use a PS controller if you don't like the new controls, in this day and age I'd say this version is the best choice.

author: {'steamid': '76561198207583911', 'num_games_owned': 78, 'num_reviews': 40, 'playtime_forever': 284, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 258, 'last_played': 1487290626}
review: This is the first GTA game that wasn't a top down arcade game. Without it we wouldn't have: San Andreas, Vice City, 4, 5, or Episodes from Liberty City. The game it's self is pretty good too. Only real problem is that the controls are ehhh, but it's nothing that takes away from the game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198301740422', 'num_games_owned': 9, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 1082, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1072, 'last_played': 1555839564}

author: {'steamid': '76561198081332666', 'num_games_owned': 513, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 1373, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1373, 'last_played': 1498718413}
review: Over my 22 hour love-hate relationship with GTA III, I can say it's a game that shows age in gameplay and graphics, but I would definitely consider it a classic. If you've played later GTAs before this one it definitely takes getting used to since there are less features and the gameplay is a bit clunky. I will cut it slack since it is an old game, and I suppose it was a fun challenge at parts as opposed to an often brutal one. But make no mistake, if you love older games, this is a must-have.

author: {'steamid': '76561198134410497', 'num_games_owned': 34, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 20, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 20, 'last_played': 1498766178}
review:
Had a LOT of issues getting it to run on Win10. Kept getting Directx errors ("requires at least 8.1 to work"). Finally got it to work in Vista Compatility with 640x480 resolution enabled. Also had to go into Control Panel > Programs > Turn Windows Features on or off > Legacy Components > enable DirectPlay. Seems to work okay (honestly, I've only done one mission because I spent all of my time just trying to get it to work), I have music and sound effects but I don't hear voices. 
This fix also worked for GTA VC (except I ran it as Win XP SP2 for compatibility)

author: {'steamid': '76561198135635361', 'num_games_owned': 406, 'num_reviews': 85, 'playtime_forever': 997, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 41, 'last_played': 1677229272}
review:
I had a problem with this game where it would tell me I'm not running DirectX version 8.1 or higher, but I was running 12.

In the comments someone posted a solution.

[quote=Seohnstaob]Change compatibility to Vista or earlier and check the box to run 640x480 resolution. Control Panel > Programs > Turn Windows Features on or off > Legacy Components > Directplay 
That's how I got mine to work, hope that helps.[/quote]

______________________________________________________________

It's hilarious how most, if not all, of the other recent reviews are people downvoting the game because of Rockstar's decision to remove OpenIV.

But I think they should've complained on GTA V and IV, because they're isn't really any unbiased recent reviews. But here's one.

So basically, after a cutscene, you are placed straight into a mission. The game gives you a little tutorial before getting you to drive to a certain location. The graphics are good for 2002, the sound is good, never heard of any of the songs, but I don't like the lack of waypoints, as I have no idea where I am going, and how easy the cars are to damage, and flip. I ran over someone and even the ambulance that arrived was beat up.

Well I can't get past the first level because of me damaging and flipping my car so... Well, at least the explosions are cool.

author: {'steamid': '76561197995211244', 'num_games_owned': 1006, 'num_reviews': 107, 'playtime_forever': 93, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 67, 'last_played': 1557963211}
review: This is the original PC version with no modern enhancements.  GTA3 itself is a good game, but there's no cloud saving whatsoever, the controls are iffy, and the graphics are the same 2001 graphics from the original release.  Why's that bad?  Because somehow, the mobile version has said enhancements.  It's a weird day when a classic game like this is better played on a phone than on PC. So this desperately needs an update, but don't count on it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198019292264', 'num_games_owned': 152, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 8, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 8, 'last_played': 1497873913}
review:
GTA3 was where it all really really took off. 3D game world, full free roam after completing the game, fab storeline and missions, way better controls than GTA1/2, and a tour de force when release on PS2 first. But the game is really a 20-30 hour experience as is. 

With modding, the game has an unbelievable extended life that console platform players wish they could achieve on the PC.

I love R* and all the Grand Theft Auto family of games, but lets be real here. R* banned all modding recently in their nuclear management decision to curb cheating in their more modern GTA franchise starting with OpenIV. With OpenIV, modders and the Grand Theft Auto Community, you have a game that can be played for years in SP mode for GTA4 and 5.

When Take Two (publisher) decides to monetize on that goodwill withOUT creating any additional content or assets for the SP user base, trying to force those user online and destory it at the same time, I cannot recommend ANYONE to put their hard earn money into buying ANY Take Two Published games.

It is exactly like a politician taking away your RIGHTS - RIGHTS mean something that you have with no questions asked - since modding and OpenIV does not HARM the purchaser, publisher or online experience whatsoever. The mods ONLY work in single player. It is absolutely one of the main reason gamers even buy GTA in the first place.

Again for the reading impared, OpenIV CANNOT and does NOT allow any of its modded contented to be used online or interact with that post apocalyptic Detroit where no Robocop can be found they call GTAO. 

Before anyone disputes this, lookup what OpenIV actually DOES, and note there are CONSUMER FAIR USE LAWS in most IP protected countries that allows private modding for personal use. 

So NO, I do not recommend anyone to buy ANY Take Two published games including GTA series from R* until they change their shill corporate policy towards the community that built them in the first place.

If I can I would REFUND all my Take Two published games and delete it off my HD right away.

author: {'steamid': '76561198170074143', 'num_games_owned': 305, 'num_reviews': 21, 'playtime_forever': 1755, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1628, 'last_played': 1545278686}
review: Get the game, just not Rockstar's Steam version. The car textures are all black or extremely dark. I know that there is a fix for the bad blackish steam textures, but there shouldn't have to be one, because it shouldn't be a problem. For a game that still has support (updates still come out every now and then), the fact that Rockstar can release a game on steam with such a basic and glaring issue, and let alone refuse to fix it, boggles the mind. Rockstar isn't known for it's dedication to it's PC ports, but come on! It's a texture error for christ's sake! Get just one guy and tell him to fix it, so you can include it in the next update, he'll be done in less than an hour! Easier still, since you are so lazy, just download one of the fixes on the internet and repackage it as a bug fixing update, so the customers don't have to jump through hoops to make the game work right! Pathetic, careless handling of an extremely important classic.

author: {'steamid': '76561198046830919', 'num_games_owned': 195, 'num_reviews': 35, 'playtime_forever': 1443, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 768, 'last_played': 1635577024}
review:
Almost every mid-end game story mission feels like a chore. Cop AI is ridiculous, and cop cars will bumper car you at high speeds at almost every turn during a chase with 3+ stars.

Money is pretty much not a problem at all as missions very quickly give larger amounts of money, but the mini map doesn't tell you where the ammunation stores are at, so you'll have to remember where they are if you have to pick up weapons for a mission that requires you to enter a gunfight.

You may often find yourself wanting to quit and reload the game in order to keep your weapons, rather than continuing after a death, because as stated earlier, ammunations are hidden from your mini map.

Future games in the series have less and less of these issues stated, but with nothing to reference back during III's initial release, this game was better received back then than if it were to be re-evaluated by today's standards.

author: {'steamid': '76561198053744908', 'num_games_owned': 970, 'num_reviews': 38, 'playtime_forever': 1173, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1173, 'last_played': 1527194994}
review:
Glancing through some of the other reviews here on Steam, it would seem that there are numerous instances of crashing on start-up or difficulties launching or playing the game. After 20 hours of play time (story completion plus a few bits ‘n’ bobs), running on Windows 7, an AMD graphics card and a Dual Shock 3 control pad, I experienced no glitches or game breaking difficulties. Furthermore, after adding in a couple of mods (a controller mod and silentpatch), controls were no problem at all, effectively restoring the game to its original state. Textures and colour were all as expected with no unexpected glitches or rendering errors with the game or menus, and once the resolution was adjusted in the game options GTA 3 worked fully.  There are many more mods available to enhance the PC experience, some more recommended than others, but with a couple of minor tweaks GTA 3 was 100% playable. However, Grand Theft Auto 3 is 15 years old, the series’ first foray into 3D and it really shows.

GTA3 tells the story of silent protagonist Claude, who is betrayed whilst attempting a bank raid and subsequently arrested. With things looking grim for him, a stroke of luck sees his prison transport attacked by a Columbian cartel, and Claude makes a hasty escape onto the streets of Liberty City. And so begins Claude’s ascent through the various criminal elements whilst he seeks revenge against his double crossing partner. In its purest form GTA 3 is a crime sandbox with variations upon the now established chase/destroy/escape/escort mission format. This being Rockstar’s jump into 3D many of the modern conventions are missing or present in an incredibly crude form. Whilst Liberty City is an impressive construct for a game of this pedigree, exploration is strictly limited to outdoors, with entry to buildings something that would follow only in later entries to the series. Graphically what was once a marvel to behold clearly shows it’s age, but going in with few expectations they are more than serviceable and do not impact upon enjoyment of exploration.

What is infuriating is the incredibly limited mapping system present in the game. Landmark Icons are all but absent, with markers arbitrarily disappearing as the story is completed, and with no in-game map available (a mod is available to correct this) sometimes navigating through the city, especially in time limited missions can be incredibly frustrating. Whilst vehicle physics are dated, and at times almost comic book in their over action, once accustomed to the at times ‘floaty’ handling driving around the city is mostly pain free with around 50 different cars available. Piloting the boats is somewhat less satisfying (although there are very few missions that require this), and the only available plane, the Dodo, is nigh on impossible to use effectively. Furthermore, swimming is not yet possible and Claude is unable to make a hasty escape from damaged cars, requiring them to be virtually stationary to allow egress. Radio stations, whilst somewhat less stunning than in the newer games, breathe character into the city’s population, and giving the player such an easy way to manipulate their in-game soundtrack was a masterstroke, although not yet the finely polished feature that it would become.

Perhaps the most frustrating thing for a modern gamer is the targeting system utilised for armed combat. With no player controlled camera, and only a rudimentary lock-on system, combat becomes more luck than skill, with hasty target shuffling in vain attempts to knock out as many threats as quickly as possible. Whilst later GTA games have become known for their storytelling, here, with a silent lead, it can be difficult to adequately track the what’s and why’s of what’s going on. The plot is shallow and barely satisfying, but nevertheless is adequate in dovetailing one mission to the next. Given the mission structure, progress is often incredibly frustrating, with large elements of trial and error. The difficulty is pitched at a relatively fair level, with few missions acting as a barrier for very long, although the occasional timed objective, in conjunction with the absence of map can be soul destroying for its duration.

It’s a shame that Steam has no neutral rating because that’s firmly where I feel GTA 3 belongs. As a snapshot in time it’s an experience worth having, but as a game that’s worth committing time to it has long been surpassed by its successors. Personally I don’t regret seeing the roots of 3D GTA, but unless you have a similar desire I’d recommend that you skip forward to Vice City, or better yet where the series really came together, San Andreas.

author: {'steamid': '76561198040855477', 'num_games_owned': 117, 'num_reviews': 74, 'playtime_forever': 943, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 943, 'last_played': 1507353546}
review:
[h1][b]Grand Theft Auto III[/b][/h1]

[h1]Pros:[/h1]

1)Spectacular graphics
2)Interesting plot
3)(Some)funny missions
4)Italian dubbing (for mafia)
5)(Some)Pleasurable radio stations

[h1]Cons:[/h1]

1)(Some)Boring missions
2)Inefficient map
3)(Partially)Stupid Artificial Intelligence

[b]Pros explanation:[/b]

1)[i]Considering the release date, I think it's safe to say that the graphics is undoubtely on a high - very high level.[/i]

2)[i]On the overall the plot is interesting and captivating. Yeah, there are some boring missions, but almost all of them aren't plot related and are not a must-do, so you can skip them if you want.[/i]

3)[i]On the other side, there are some missions that are indeed very very funny.[/i]

4)[i]This was a tidbit. I am italian and as soon as I heard the sicilian dialect from the mafia characters I ended up being pleasurably surprised. These are, in my personal opinion, the details that allow a game to be on a higher level than the other ones.[/i]

5)[i]This is about personal taste but I can definitely say that there's basically a radio station for all the tastes and, of course, I found the ones I personally like.[/i]

[b]Cons explanation:[/b]

1)[i]See point 2 on "pros explanation" section about the missions.[/i]

2)[i]The map has been probably the most annoying thing of all the game, because on the GPS the only shown icons were the safe house and the mission symbols (no hospital / weapons shop / car repainting location). There isn't even a key that allows you to see the whole map from the game and this "forced" me to download from the internet and print it.[/i]

3)[i]The artificial intelligence on the overall works properly, but for some reason the enemies (only mission related) do not shot you unless you are very very close or you shoot them (and sometimes even if you do it, they keep standing still). Also they act strangely even in close fights (howewer this happened only in one mission). [/i]

[b]Final considerations:[/b]

[i]On the overall I definitely suggest this game to anyone who likes the genre. The flaws are definitely unimportant and pass almost unnoticed during the playing sessions, making the experience fun and captivating.[/i]

[h1] Personal scores [/h1]

[table]
[tr][th][h1]Personal scores [/h1][/th][/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]Graphics[/td]
        [td]8[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]Plot[/td]
        [td]6[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]Gameplay[/td]
        [td]7[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]Sound[/td]
        [td]7[/td]
    [/tr]
     [tr]
        [td]Music[/td]
        [td]7[/td]
    [/tr]
[/table]

[h1][b]RESULT: 3.5 / 5 [/b][/h1]

review: It kills me having to downvote this game. GTA 3 was my second ever GTA game back in the day on the PS2 (I started with Vice City). GTA 3 is such a nastalgic game for me and that's why I decided to purchase it for PC. Unfortunatley this is one of the worst PC ports I have ever played. I would actually deem the game UNPLAYABLE. First, the menu is invisible. If you want to change graphics settings or play a differnt save from the main menu, too bad. Second, there's a glitch where every car in the game has a weird black shadow on them, you can't even see the cars. It's a sad and truly pathetic effort by Rockstar and it's piss poor of Steam to allow this game to be up for sale. Rockstar please fix. Until then DO NOT make a purchase with this game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198041731600', 'num_games_owned': 792, 'num_reviews': 143, 'playtime_forever': 1806, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1775, 'last_played': 1492310253}
review:
I grew up playing GTA3 when it came out on PS2.  Back then, it was awesome.

Now, not so much.  Many cars have high centers of gravity such that they easily roll over when making turns, the surfaces result in your car crashing from the slightest of bumps, and cars are very fragile such that they blow up relatively easily not to mention they catch on fire and explode if they're rolled over which can kill you very easily, especially if a gang is shooting you and the police decide to shoot at you because you ran over a gang member. 

The compass doesn't show points of interest outside of mission origins such that you have to pause the game and refer to an online map to catch your bearings if you want to find health, armor, gun shops, pay and sprays, or safehouses.  The targeting system the PS2 version came with is broken since you either use standard controls which don't target or classic controls which do but don't allow your mouse to freely aim.  A lot of the missions are ridiculous as well in that they're timed while you have to weave through congested traffic and the computer gets insane handling.  

Lastly, many players complain of launching bugs.  I had a few myself, but thankfully got around them.  The menu button labels start transparent and gradually fade into appearance.  The game itself will freeze you computer in the intro screens unless you launch in compatibility mode as an administrator.  The game also defaults to poor resolutions that many players are unable to play without.

15 years ago, this game was the bomb.  Now, it just has a lot of flaws that aren't worth dealing with.

author: {'steamid': '76561198046675266', 'num_games_owned': 1511, 'num_reviews': 1065, 'playtime_forever': 44, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 44, 'last_played': 1491693274}

GTAIII is a great game that started a lot of what GTA is now, amazing.

7/10[/h1]

author: {'steamid': '76561198143875641', 'num_games_owned': 317, 'num_reviews': 42, 'playtime_forever': 2863, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 796, 'last_played': 1659059639}
review:
"no more ultra-violence in video games"

ESRB came into every single home like a plaque, then rockstar took on the media with two of the most controversial video games to this day, that was manhunt and Grand theft auto three. 

GTA 3 is based on the work of R* and turned heads in so many crowds, it had such success that the media tried shutting down violence in the video game industry, unfortunetly Rockstar made one of the most successful games that forged a generation of veteran gamers, GTA 3 hold's a special place in my memories, where you can hijack the banshee from across 8 Ball's garage, put a series of gamebreaking cheats to turn this sandbox into the most exciting game for it's time.

the GTA veterans will appreciate the trilogy over the recent installment of GTAV which was also a outstanding piece of work by R* games. 
10/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198299115903', 'num_games_owned': 68, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 5766, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2268, 'last_played': 1563377876}
review:
After spending many hours playing this game I finally decided to give it a review. I played this game mostly on the phone and later decided to buy it on pc. There are a few differences that I noticed while playing the steam version like:

The car textures are all dark. Yeah it's not a big problem, but it could be annoying.
There are a few glitches that I encountered, pretty big ones like cars being stuck in air and cars being stuck in buildings. There were a few crashes when I tried to skip the intro sequence but that's about it. Keep in mind that gta 3 is an older game so you will probably encounter something like that  if you are playing the game the on a modern system.

Now about the game itself.  Gta 3 is an open world action-adventure third-person shooter video game developed by DMA Design and published by Rockstar Games. And the question is it is worth playing it ? The answer is yes. Every gta game should be worth playing even though you got gta 5 and 4 this stills holds up well in my opinion. The characters, the atmosphere and the city itself is memorable. But those things could be the only good things about the game. Because it doesn't have much to offer nowadays. You can't customize your character, there's not lot of weapons and you can't even swim ! The funny thing is you will receive a lot of money. Already for the first mission in the game you will get 1500. But you really can't spend money on a lot of stuff. But something about the game to me is just magical and I don't know what it is. You will probably hate this game if you have already played more advance gta games. The game does get difficult especially in the end but you once played that mission enough times you will get good at it. But it's not the mission that are difficult. It's the side mission and collectibles that are required for 100% completion in the game if you are the guy who wants to get everything out of the game. Exploring is fun even though you can't do much in the city it's still fun to find a weapon or a collectible of which there are total of 100 hidden collectibles in the whole city ! 

So that's about it. Hopefully this review helped you a bit to me this game is definitely one of my favourite games and hopefully you will give this game chance !

author: {'steamid': '76561198233046884', 'num_games_owned': 42, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 11496, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 7473, 'last_played': 1676961330}
review: GTA 3, when released in 2001, changed the entire gaming landscape. Around 1999, shortly after the release of the top-down GTA 2, Rockstar decided to cash into the trend of 3D gaming, and started development of GTA 3. What was once a cheesy, cartooney 3D city evolved into the living monolith the 3D Rendition of Liberty Ciy was. Taking place in 2001, while robbing a bank, an unnamed thug (known as Fido in game) is fatally shot by his girlfriend, Catalina. This man goes through various friends, enemies and betrayals to get to his goal of killing his girlfriend at a dam in a dramatic final mission. Liberty City is a giant. Consisting of three large islands and a huge green inaccessable countryside, Liberty City is stunning visually. The game has a decent array of weapons, with some of these weapons being an overpowered shotgun and Carbine Rifle, a sniper rifle, an undersized AK-47 and a well rounded Micro Uzi. With these weapons come mechanics. Though GTA 3 has generally solid mechanics, it does have setbacks, like inaccurate auto targeting (Classic Control Method) and the inability to crouch. Driving mechanics are quite good, with a big heavy army truck being hard to spin out following a fender crash, and a Viper based sports car spinning two 360s as the result of such collision. GTA 3's radio selection, while not nearly as good as the one in Vice City, is still decent. I was often listening to Head Radio, Double Clef, K-Jah or Flashback FM. If you loathe the entire game's soundtrack, this PC version supports custom radio stations, which can be accomplished by dragging your mp3s in the folder of the same name in the game directory. Additional PC features include choosable skins for the player, and full aiming with any weapon, something the PS2 version of the game did not support. There is alot more content and easter eggs in this amazing game that will keep you busy. Though you will find more fun in Vice City, that is not putting down GTA 3 at all. Even if you do get bored of the main game, the PC versions of both games support major mods, like the RealGTA mod for GTA III. No matter which way, GTA 3 is worth the wait and the money.

author: {'steamid': '76561198073097275', 'num_games_owned': 34, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 1269, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1241, 'last_played': 1389585293}
review:
A classic. I remember staying up late at night playing this on a rented PS2. It changed the world of gaming forever with its approach. The world is big (not as big as new GTA versions but it was at the time), the options are seamingly endless, the sand in the sandbox is deep (again not as much as new GTA games but was very much so for the time).

The fact that the character you play speaks no words is in itself, a very interesting dynamic to the game. It makes you more aware of the other characters, the missions, the world; everything is embellished with great detail because of your silence. You carry out bloodthirsty murders, arsons, and robberies with cold indifference to your actions. It's kind of chilling to think about.

The violence of the game was disturbing to lots of people and it is pretty bloody. The concept of a free-range murderer is kind of frightening, but the game is very much a game so there is nothing to worry about. Have fun blowing cars up. It's just a game.

The story is very obviously borrowed from gangster movies like The Godfather and Goodfellas and such. This is a bonus though, as everything seems very familiar to you, like you are already a made man.

Excellent game, and playable all the way through.

10/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198029981072', 'num_games_owned': 73, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 97, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 93, 'last_played': 1580327575}
review:
In 2001 Rockstar Games released one of the most ambitious games they had ever released to the public. Grand Theft Auto III was the first game ever to start what has culminated today in one of the greatest games known in videogaming. Being the first open world game to feature polygonal tridimensional models, it started a trend that would continue to evolve until this very day. Rockstar Games is known to many as a Publisher that invests everything in their games because they want to excel in what they do and they want to deliver to the public. With GTA III it is shown how that set of mind started and how each Publisher and/or Developer should treat their IPs. 

GTA III has a fun story plagued with satiric comments to Pop Stars and the way of life of the era it is situated in, in this case the 2000's. If you've not played this game at all, I won't spoil the story, but damn it's 2017! You better start playing it! 

While right now GTA V surpasses in every way the now outdated GTA III, it still is a fun game to play to reminisce about how it all started, and let's be honest, doesn't matter how polygonal the city or characters are, it's always fun to smash your car against other cars and shoot everything that moves, because GTA is mayhem and that's why you are going to buy this game! 

So, ready to go back to Liberty City my friend? 

8/10 

Buy it, play it and don't regret it.

author: {'steamid': '76561197986511953', 'num_games_owned': 741, 'num_reviews': 311, 'playtime_forever': 2449, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2000, 'last_played': 1616461734}
review:
Grand Theft Auto 3 is well regarded as a pioneer in the third person sandbox game genre. It can be compared to other genre defining games like Wolfenstein 3D and Dune 2 before it. 

The core foundation that GTA3 rests it's hat on is simplicity. It has a very simple premise, after being betrayed during a robbery you set out for revenge in Liberty City. The story is full of mostly entertaining characters and mostly fun missions. That simplicity works double for the gameplay.

GTA3 introduced and perfected a gameplay loop that the franchise has still kept for the most part. There's a set of story missions you undergo inorder to unlock further parts of the game and see what happens next in the story. Alternatively you can ignore the story and explore the city at your leasure. While doing sidequests like driving a taxi cab or looking for hidden collectables. This core gameplay loop of missions, sidequests, collectables with a freely explorable open world wasn't a common thing at the time, and it blew people away with how impressive the whole experience was. At the same time though because there have been so many games based off it, it occasionally feels like it lacks an identity compared to the glut of sandbox games that came after it. 

This is fundamentally the base game that all future sandbox games jumped off from. It's a game I like to go back to every so often to remind myself where it all started. And to remind myself that Rockstar set the bar pretty high from the start and just kept going from there.

author: {'steamid': '76561197971266985', 'num_games_owned': 197, 'num_reviews': 31, 'playtime_forever': 3176, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2171, 'last_played': 1575104214}
review:
Anyone wanting to know how to make a open world shooter, GTA3 should be lesson #1.

Liberty City is split into 3 islands. Each with their own neighbourhoods. Each neighbourhood has its own look and gang.

The side missions, alone, make for great fun: drive a taxi, be a vigilante (hunting bad guys in car chases), drive an ambulance or fire engine.

The story missions take you on an interesting journey, working your way up the mafia ladder (for starters).

The downsides are the lighting seems way too dark on most models. Also, lighting normals seem to be non-existant. This seems to be a thing for this era of game. I don't know whether it is that normals are broken, or they just are not there.

Definitely recommended, if on sale.

author: {'steamid': '76561198043803212', 'num_games_owned': 1744, 'num_reviews': 65, 'playtime_forever': 425, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 61, 'last_played': 1499406498}
review:
Unplayable. Past versions of this game may have worked good on consoles, But this pc version has many faults.
- Menu screens can dissappear so u dont know what your doing on menu
- Mouse doesnt recognise games screen edge on dual monitors so when you turn mouse in game you end up seeing the mouse appear on 2nd monitor, and when u click (such as to fire gun) you end up clicking the other monitor and minimising game.

You would think ROCKSTAR would have patched these two main issues. But 15 years and nothings been done, and the forums are filled with post about these two issues. If you own it try get a refund from steam, they shouldnt be allowed to sell faulty products.
Definitely makes me not want to pay $80 for GTA V if they cant even release patches for minor issues in their well known game franchise.
